proctext.para: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

talk.start.para: â€”Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

petition.title: Arms Trade
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned petitioners draw to the attention of the Senate the central role played by the arms trade in creating an environment in which armed conflict such as the Gulf War can occur.
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should demand that the Australian Government:
(a) outlaw sales of armaments and arms-related technology to overseas organisations: government and private.
(b) lobby internationally, including at the United Nations, for the banning of sales of armaments and arms-related technology.
(c) cancel the AIDEX 91 arms bazaar.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
petition.presenter.block:
by
Senators Kernot
(from 93 citizens) and
Vallentine
(from 78 citizens).

petition.title: Tobacco Advertising
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we the undersigned call for urgent action by our Federal Parliament and all government agencies concerned with Health and Sport to impose an immediate ban on the incidental advertising of tobacco products on television and provide for alternative funding to replace tobacco sponsorship. That tobacco sponsorship of sporting events and participants openly flouts the 1976 Federal law prohibiting tobacco advertising on TV and radio. That our Parliament immediately end this association between healthy sports and the deaths of 18,300 people in Australia each year from tobacco-related diseases.
And your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.
petition.presenter.block:
by
Senators Sherry
(from 25 citizens) and
West
(from 127 citizens).

petition.title: Electoral Advertising
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled; the petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we call upon the Senate to reject legislation denying Australians the right to advertise electoral material on radio and television, believing such bans amount to a denial of free speech, an unfair advantage to an incumbent government, and denial of information to print-handicapped and other Australians.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

petition.title: Telecom: 0055 Services
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. Telecom is selling 0055 telephone networks to private contractors who provide offensive and sexually explicit recorded messages to the public.

2. The providers of these services are advertising in the pages of Australian newspapers in a manner which is designed to titillate and attract calls from the whole community and thus play on the curiosity of children.
3. These services degrade and humiliate women and portray them as sex objects, and they destroy the innocence of children.

Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, immediately call on Telecom to so regulate the conditions under which these services are made available, that women are no longer portrayed as sex objects, degraded or humiliated and that the innocence of children is protected.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

petition.title: Wealth Inquiry
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned shows:

That in Australia, the rich are getting richer while poverty is increasing, as shown by recent research that 10% of the population own 50% of the wealth while people in poverty have increased from 1.5 million in 1982 to 2.1 million in 1986.
Your Petitioners ask that the Senate should:
request the Australian Government-
to establish a Wealth Inquiry as a first and essential step to the achievement of a more just society;
and that this Inquiry should seek to establish-
* the current distribution of wealth, how it has changed over time and the causes of these changes
* the effectiveness of the Australian taxation system in raising revenue at all levels of taxpayers' income and assets
* the measures which should be taken to achieve a more just society

petition.title: Nuclear Warships
petition.para: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
We are concerned about the dangers posed to the people and environment of Western Australia by the entry of nuclear-armed and nuclear-powered warships to our ports.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray;
That you ban nuclear-armed and nuclear-powered warships from entering Australian ports.

petition.title: Uranium: Mining and Export
petition.para: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That your petitioners request that the Australian Government take steps immediately to stop the mining and export of uranium
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

debate.title:
APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL (No. 2) 1990-91
APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 4) 1990-91
APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 5) 1990-91

proctext.para: Consideration resumed from 28 May, on motion by Senator McMullan:
That the report of Estimates Committee B be adopted.
REPORT OF ESTIMATES COMMITTEE B

talk.start.para: â€”The Committee will now consider the estimates of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade.

speech.speaker: Hill Sen R.M.

talk.start.para: â€”I entered a number of reservations to the Committee report in relation to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (DFAT). I want to explore a little further this morning two of those reservations. The others could be explored, but I will not do that on this occasion because of pressures of other business. The first matter concerns the management of the Department. Notwithstanding some improvements, the evidence is that much improvement is still to be desired. However, I believe there is a better mechanism for pursuing those ongoing concerns, and I will continue to look at that other mechanism for doing that. Therefore, I do not intend to deal further with that issue this morning.

speech.para: The second reservation is the ongoing concern of damaging leaks from the Department. Despite the expressions of concern by the Secretary of the Department to the Committee, who referred to feeling a sense of shame, and the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans), who acknowledged in the end that he recognised that the problem was serious and indicated he was doing his best to counter this stream of leaks from the Department that had occurred over the past year or so-in fact, he indicated that a great deal of injected momentum from him had been added in the past few days before the Estimates Committee which he believed would reduce the possibility of this occurring in the future- the leaking of confidential documents from within the Department that can be damaging to Australia's interests continues.

The mechanisms that have been put in place are therefore clearly inadequate. It is astonishing that so many of these abuses have been referred to the Australian Federal Police, yet no action has been taken in the vast majority of cases. With the added mechanisms that have been implemented within the Department to deter these abuses and investigate the past abuses, no finding or action has been brought against any person.

The latest in this sequence that I noticed was reported only on Monday of this week in the Australian Financial Review. It concerned what was described as a `confidential Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade cable', involving the Singapore armed forces (SAF) in Burma. Apparently the cable states that the SAF had deployed intelligence gathering teams to the area and that they had used their own vehicles. The assessment of the officer in the cable is quoted in this report as indicating, if the reports are true, that the intelligence teams are operating in conjunction with the Thai armed forces.

The leakage of such a cable clearly is damaging to our interests with Singapore and Thailand. I will not say `with Burma', but one must wonder what the governments of Singapore and Thailand think of DFAT and the Minister's administration of the Department when they should be embarrassed by what should be internal assessments made by Australian foreign affairs officers being put on the world media through further illegal leakages from within the Department. There have been many instances that I and others have brought to the attention of the Minister over the last year or two. I doubt whether there is much point in my even asking the Minister what he is going to do on this occasion because no doubt he will simply say, again, `We are doing our best'. This is evidence that something is seriously wrong. We do not know exactly what it is but it is not being resolved.

The third reservation that I have put down to the report concerns the ex gratia termination payments to Ambassador Burke. It is still our belief that that is a correct expression of what Ambassador Burke received. However, I do not want to take it any further today. Our position has been made clear in the past. The fourth reservation concerns activities by Mr Burke outside the scope of his duties as Ambassador to Ireland. I want to ask the Minister some further questions because there are unanswered issues in that regard.

The fifth reservation concerns the proposed human rights visit to China. I trust that progress is being made to ensure that those on that mission receive the necessary level of access for them to perform their responsibilities in a way in which their assessment and conclusions can be treated seriously by the international community. If they are not, it will simply be a matter of embarrassment to Australia and counterproductive to the goal that we would all wish, and that is, to see improved human rights in China.
The next concerns funding of activities relating to the Australian People for Health, Education and Development Abroad in southern Africa, which is a matter that is being pursued elsewhere.

The next concerns aspects in relation to Mr Burke's telephone accounts in Dublin that I do want to raise this morning because of inconsistencies in the evidence that was given to the Committee from the documents that were later tabled by the Minister in this place.

I return to the first of the two issues which I want to explore further concerning the activities that the Government endorsed for Mr Burke that went beyond his responsibilities to Ireland and the Holy See. In particular, I want to ask the Minister about the visit by Mr Burke to Geneva which was endorsed specifically by the Minister and noted on a document which the Minister tabled in this place.

For some time, the answer of the Minister was largely that all of this information had been given to Mr Peacock. Now that I have been able to obtain the document that, in fact, was given to Mr Peacock, I find that that is scanty, to put it at its best. The Parliament still does not know the purpose of the visit by Mr Burke to Geneva when he was Ambassador to Ireland-a visit which, apparently, was with the mining magnate Mr Hancock to meet with Soviet officials about some business activities.

Everyone would acknowledge that that is a strange assignment for an ambassador to Ireland and the Holy See, but we do know of the previous close relationship between Mr Hancock and Mr Burke. We now know, of course, through the revelations of the Royal Commission into Commercial Activities of Government and Other Matters in Western Australia of the huge financial support that Mr Hancock had given to Mr Burke when he was in office as Premier of the State of Western Australia.

What I want to know is: what was the purpose of that mission? What did it cost the Australian taxpayer? Were there any Australian officials present other than Mr Burke, who seems to have been described quaintly as having an official capacity? It would be interesting to know in what official capacity Mr Burke was to attend this and other meetings in Romania. I say that in passing. What I really want to know is: what did it cost? Specifically, what was the purpose of it? What was achieved by the mission? I presume that Mr Burke reported to the Department on the achievements of the mission, as he was apparently doing it in the Australian Government's interests; and, if he did so report, I would ask the Minister whether he would table a copy of that report.

speech.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: â€”Let me say at the outset that I am indebted to Senator Hill for confining the compass of his questioning relatively narrowly because of the time constraints that do afflict the Committee in dealing with the Estimates as a whole. However, I will respond very quickly to a couple of his opening references to matters he is not now pursuing.

speech.para: On the subject of leaks, I say again that I do take very seriously indeed the leaks that have occurred. I think the torrent seems to have been reduced to a trickle as a result of various steps that have been taken. That is not to say that trickles themselves cannot be damaging, and I do deplore the latest example which occurred earlier this week. I can only repeat the language I have used on other occasions, that we are doing our best, again, through such resources as are available to us to trace the source of this particular leak and ensure that it does not happen again.

Leaking is something of an endemic phenomenon in government, as all of us on both sides of the chamber know. It is particularly a problem in the foreign affairs area where there are just so many documents that have a high level of classification and sensitivity across such an enormously varied range of subject areas and that cover so many parts of the Department and posts overseas. So it does become rather more difficult than in many other areas of government to keep this under control, but we are trying.

On the subject of the human rights mission to China, I hope to be in a position within the next few days to make an announcement at least about the composition of the delegation that will be going and the time frame of the visit. Discussions are still proceeding with the Chinese Government about the details of the program, but I have every reason for confidence at this stage not only that the delegation will be seen as highly expert and highly credible but also that the degree of access that will be achieved will be such as to ensure that the mission does secure its objectives. I think it better to let specifics on this wait until a little more detail is to hand, but I hope to be at least in a position to announce the composition of the delegation before the end of this week.

As to the first of the queries that have now been raised about Mr Burke and his role as a representative of the Australian Government in relation to eastern European trade and commercial matters, the general character of that role has, I think, been amply described in previous exchanges in the Estimates Committee. But, as to the particular trip that was made to Geneva from 10 to 13 September 1988, the details that I am able to give Senator Hill at the moment are simply as follows.

Although it was originally anticipated that there would be a meeting between Mr Burke, Mr Hancock and Soviet representatives on the subject of commercial prospects in eastern Europe, the intention of that meeting being to take advantage of Mr Burke's considerable expert experience and contacts in developing mineral sales in eastern Europe, in fact, for reasons that I am still not entirely clear about, the meeting with the Soviet representatives did not transpire. There was simply a detailed exchange between Mr Burke and Mr Hancock, which took the form of a detailed debriefing by Mr Hancock in relation to his discussions in Romania and Czechoslovakia, which had taken place previous to the meeting in Geneva. It was a debriefing on Mr Hancock's most recent discussions in Romania and Czechoslovakia.

I am advised that the substance of that debriefing, which contained, overwhelmingly, material of a commercially confidential character, was reported in detail by Mr Burke to Canberra in cables at the time and was taken into account in not only departmental data building but also departmental planning for potential activity in that area. So it was in the nature of a relatively straightforward and uncomplicated meeting of that kind. It remains the case that the only other visit that Mr Burke paid to eastern Europe was the one that has been the subject of detailed previous explanation.

On the subject of cost, I am not sure that we have that information to hand. We should be able to get the information. I am certainly happy to supply it to Senator Hill as soon as possible. If someone could set that in train immediately, I would be grateful.

talk.start.para: â€”Before I call Senator Hill, I mention that I probably should have called Senator Burns earlier to move an amendment. On the assumption that there will probably be little, if any, debate on the amendment, it might be best to ask Senator Burns to move his amendment now.

speech.speaker: Burns Sen B.R

talk.start.para: â€”I move:

speech.para: At end of motion, add ``, and that the following matter be referred to the Procedure Committee for inquiry and report:
The need for a single authorisation and uniform set of conditions to apply to all Estimates Committees for the broadcasting, recording and rebroadcasting of their public proceedings''.

I support that on the basis of a unanimous attitude by Estimates Committee B, which made the recommendation in its report and on behalf of which I move this proposed reference. The Committee believes that uncertainties and inconsistencies currently apply to the broadcasting of Estimates committee public proceedings. The Committee noted that the order of the Senate of 23 August 1990 allows individual committees to authorise broadcasting and determine the conditions by which such broadcasting of their proceedings may occur. The Senate agreed to this order following consideration by the Procedure Committee which dealt primarily with the broadcasting of standing committee proceedings.

Since September 1990, some Estimates committees have authorised the broadcasting of their proceedings, but with differing conditions being applicable. There are no guidelines to determine which committee will actually be broadcast. Estimates Committee B therefore recommended that the Procedure Committee should examine the need to have a single authorisation and a uniform set of conditions to apply to all Estimates committees for the broadcasting, recording and rebroadcasting of their public proceedings.
Amendment agreed to.

speech.speaker: Hill Sen R.M.

talk.start.para: â€”I note the Minister's answer to my question regarding the visit to Geneva. It follows from that that the colour of the visit is now very different. The document which was written for the Minister to approve relating to the visit to Geneva implies that there was a need for Mr Burke to visit Geneva because that was where the Soviet representatives were with whom he was to speak, together with Mr Hancock, in relation to various commercial prospects.

speech.para: The question therefore is whether the Minister was misled. Were there appointments made with Soviet representatives? Who cancelled the appointments? What were the projects concerning Soviet representatives that the Minister authorised Mr Burke to go to Geneva to negotiate?

speech.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: â€”My authorisation for Mr Burke to go to Geneva was simply based on a one-line reference in the submission to the effect that this was part and parcel of the role that was generally proposed. At the time of authorising the visit in question, I knew no more about it than that which I had previously conveyed to the Estimates Committee. It is only very recently, in the light of the subsequent scrutiny of all the various visits that it has come to my knowledge-and, indeed, the knowledge of the current desk officers in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade originally briefed me on this-that the visit to Geneva was much more limited in its scope than I had previously understood was intended to be the case.

speech.para: I have the detailed reporting cable in front of me which Mr Burke sent back to the Department. As I have said, it does contain some commercially confidential material about particular projects-material which, on the face of it, seems to be commercially confidential.

talk.start.para: â€”Soviet projects?

â€”No, they are essentially projects in Romania and Czechoslovakia, as I have indicated. I confess that I remain somewhat puzzled as to the intentions of the meetings with Soviet representatives. As it turns out, the meeting is perfectly self-explanatory. Mr Hancock and Mr Dowding, the then Western Australian Premier, had been together in Romania and eastern Europe. They were taking the opportunity afforded by this meeting which occurred in Geneva to fully debrief Mr Burke about what had flowed from those visits and about the various aspects of them which, in the judgment of Mr Hancock and Mr Dowding, could be helpfully pursued by some assistance at an Australian Commonwealth Government level utilising Mr Burke's experience. That was what actually happened. It was not in accordance with my, albeit somewhat attenuated, understanding of what was going to happen. But what did happen was perfectly consistent with the role that was envisaged for Mr Burke, which was the central thing that had been approved a few days earlier.

speech.speaker: Hill Sen R.M.

talk.start.para: â€”I think the Minister is suggesting that he was misled. It is interesting to note from the Minister's annotation in which he approved this visit that approval was given not only on the basis of the minute but also on the basis of a telephone call between him and Mr Burke. I do not know whether Mr Burke expanded upon the purpose of his visit to Geneva. Clearly, if we are interested in the Australian taxpayers' position, I would have thought Mr Hancock could have gone to Ireland to meet with Mr Burke to debrief him if that was to be the purpose of the meeting. On the face of the documents, it would appear that Mr Burke built a case for the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade that it was necessary for him to go to Geneva because of the presence there of certain relevant Soviet representatives. One must now doubt whether there was substance in that case.

speech.para: There is only one other issue. The Minister has given information on the visit by Ambassador Burke, as he then was, to Romania in April 1989 which, I concede, was undertaken with Australian officials. But I ask the Minister about another proposed visit of which we were unaware. Apparently, there was another visit to Romania proposed for July 1989 which failed to eventuate only because of illness. Who was to attend on that visit and what was the purpose of that proposed visit?

speech.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: â€”I am sorry; I simply do not have the information available as to that proposed visit in 1989. No doubt it would have been the subject, had it got closer to actual fruition, of detailed arrangements of the kind that occurred in the case of the earlier visit to Romania. I will do my best to find out and give Senator Hill an answer on that question, but I cannot do it on the basis of resources available to me at the moment.

speech.para: I make one further point about the Geneva visit. Senator Hill referred to my annotation on the submission to me of 6 September, which has been tabled previously, about my having had a telephone conversation with Mr Burke about this matter. I say clearly for the record that that telephone conversation, as I recall it, did not cover in any way the question of a visit to Geneva. It was about the larger concept of Mr Burke being involved in the role that is described in that particular memo. My only knowledge of the visit to Geneva was the one paragraph reference to that at the tail end of that submission to me, which said:
Mr Burke has sought approval to agree to a request from Mr Hancock that he join Mr Hancock in Geneva on 12 September for a meeting with Soviet representatives on various commercial prospects.

That was the sole extent of my knowledge about that. Whether the departmental statement was based on a departmental misunderstanding of what Mr Burke had proposed about that Geneva meeting or, rather, whether the concept of the meeting changed as it developed, I simply do not know. I do not have information about that and I suspect that it is probably lost in the mists.

talk.start.para: â€”I will move on to the other issue that I want to raise concerning the incredible telephone accounts of Mr Burke from Ireland. Arising out of the Estimates, I ask the Minister whether the log of the calls has now been produced. You might remember, Mr Chairman, that an error occurred in the information given to Estimates Committee B. The Committee was first told that there was not a log and subsequently this was corrected. Has the log now been produced? Has it been delivered to Mr Burke, as Senator Evans said it would be, in order that Mr Burke might verify the proportion of the calls which were personal? Has the log been personally inspected by the Minister? Is the Minister satisfied that the claim by Mr Burke for personal calls is a fair assessment on the basis of the information contained in the log? Finally, has Mr Burke now confirmed, in accordance with the Minister's written request, that the 9.87 per cent of calls which he previously estimated were personal is accurate?

speech.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: â€”My understanding is this: the detailed call logs in question have been received by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade from the Irish authorities. That happened on 13 and 14 May. The logs in question relate to telephones, first, in the residence in Dublin, secondly, the telephone in Mr Burke's vehicle and, thirdly, his direct extension of a particular telephone in the chancery itself. We were not aware until very recently that a call log was also available for the private phone in the chancery.

speech.para: The call logs in relation to all three of those telephones have been received and were sent to Mr Burke on 17 May under cover of a letter from the senior officer in the Department concerned, which letter asks Mr Burke for his assistance-with his memory now aided by these calls logs-in identifying which of the calls in question were official. Mr Burke has not yet replied to that, unsurprisingly, since it is only a few days ago. Obviously, quite a large exercise is involved in scrutinising the detail of this and determining whether his previous recollections were accurate and whether the contribution that was paid was an appropriate one. We expect, obviously, an answer from Mr Burke to these questions reasonably shortly, but we have not received it yet.

I have neither personally seen the log in question nor do I think it is appropriate that I see it. There is an entirely legitimate privacy issue involved in terms of access to this. What is important is that the procedure be a sound one and that we be confident that, in the final wash-up, an appropriate division has been made between the private and the official calls. I am devoting all my attention at the moment to ensure that a satisfactory process is adopted in this respect. The first step is to await Mr Burke's reply.

talk.start.para: â€”Could I assume that the log would be made available to the royal commission and/or the Auditor-General, if requested?

speech.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: â€”There is a privacy issue involved here, particularly so far as any possible subsequent public disclosure of this log is concerned and that matter would have to be carefully addressed. If one is concerned, as I am, about the process issues involved, it may well prove to be appropriate at some stage, if prima facie questions of accuracy are involved, for the Auditor-General to have access to the log in question. But I guess that that is a matter for further consideration by both us and the Auditor-General in the light of the response we receive.

speech.para: As to the royal commission's access to the log, that would presumably be for reasons other than to do with the proper accounting for telephone calls. As such, I do not think it is appropriate that I comment upon it except to repeat the point that there are very obviously privacy questions involved here in the disclosure of telephone numbers called by a person over a period, particularly obviously those calls which are claimed to be of a private nature. Very serious issues of principle are involved here which would have to be very closely addressed by all those concerned if there were to be any question of possible public disclosure of the logs in question.

talk.start.para: â€”I will not pursue that further at this stage, other than to say that I recognise the privacy concerns involved. I want to ask the Minister why it was-and we only learned this not from the Estimates Committee but from papers tabled subsequently here in answer to a question-that the contribution for private calls as assessed by Mr Burke was not in fact paid for the years 1988-89 and 1989-90.
â€”Could you repeat what you have just said?
â€”Why had not the private contribution been paid and why did not the Government or the Administration take action to ensure that the private contribution was paid?
â€”In relation to the residence phone or the chancery phone?
â€”The residence phone-the 10 per cent unique deal that was agreed with Mr Burke.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: â€”I am not sure about the premise on which that question is based-that it has not been paid. My present understanding is-unless it needs to be amended-that a private contribution was paid. The only matter at issue is whether the process that was involved in determining the rate of the contribution was legitimate and, secondly, whether the actual rate that was struck does accurately reflect the balance as between private and official. But, unless there is some further information-and the people around me are shaking their heads-I do not believe there is any question about that contribution, as thus assessed, having been actually paid. I believe it was.

speech.speaker: Hill Sen R.M.

talk.start.para: â€”I will find the reference to that. In the meantime, I ask the Minister: why did it take about a year after the Auditor-General drew attention to concerns about the way in which accounting was done for the personal telephone calls from Dublin for the Department or the Minister to take action to change the processes? I remind the Minister that the explanation that was given for the changes was that the Auditor-General had drawn matters to the attention of the Government.

speech.para: It seems an incredible coincidence that in the meantime there had been an application under the Freedom of Information Act for disclosure of certain information. On the face of it, action was taken in response to pressure that a public revelation would make rather than the Auditor-General's report. The question, therefore, is: why did the Department not act properly upon the Auditor-General's report to change a procedure in accordance with the normal practice that applies elsewhere rather than take so long to do so?

speech.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: â€”Again, I am not sure about the premise of the question. I will need correction if I get the detail of the question wrong, because the sequence of events is a little complicated. I refer to the original audit report to the Secretary of the Department. Presumably Senator Hill is talking about the document of 27 June 1990 in which it is said that payments by staff for personal telephone calls were based on a decision by the Ambassador that 10 per cent of the total cost of telephone calls would be attributable to personal use, and that it may not have been an appropriate basis for recovery of these costs. I wonder whether Senator Hill is referring to that report or whether he is going back to the audit observation of December 1989.
â€”Yes.

â€”If the latter, I shall just check whether the original audit observation was followed up quite soon. Just going through the sequence of events, I think that the place to start is the review of practice so far as contributions were concerned that was made by the Australian National Audit Office (ANAO) in December 1989. The ANAO did not recommend that the payment practice in question be stopped. It did say that the rationale for setting the personal contribution rate at 10 per cent should be on file and that in future this matter should be more specifically addressed in precise terms and conditions for ambassadors to reflect the actual payment formula involved. As to getting the rationale on file, I am told that that was attended to very shortly after the Audit Office recommendations were received some time in January, or whenever, 1990.

speech.para: Then there was this further communication on 27 June to which I referred earlier and which followed a request from the Department about details of an audit of private use of telephones that had been conducted in Dublin earlier this year. As I indicated a moment ago, the letter of the Australian National Audit Office of 27 June 1990 states that the audit disclosed that payments for personal calls were based on this 10 per cent formula and that this may not have been an appropriate basis for recovery. These audit recommendations were responded to by me as follows:
Having received this advice and on the recommendation of my Department, I then wrote to Mr Burke on 15 August 1990-
just a few weeks later-
to reaffirm that all private calls were to be identified and paid in full.

I believe that that particular letter has been tabled. At that stage I had regard only to the procedures involved. The matter did not go to quantum; it was just to ensure that Mr Burke was conscious of his obligations in this respect and did do things properly thereafter.

talk.start.para: â€”When was the letter written?

â€”That letter was written to Mr Burke on 15 August 1990 and it picked up the point that had been made. As Senator Hill said, this did follow a somewhat fortuitous freedom of information request having been put in around about that time, and it was a matter of merely dealing with--
â€”Spurred action.
â€”It is not a matter of a year later; it is a matter of literally a few weeks after the ANAO's letter of mid-1990 and that letter of mine of 15 August. The relevant paragraph of my letter states:

speech.para: I should, however, clarify the situation in relation to private telephone calls. Departmental instructions are that all private calls are to be identified and costs met in full. If necessary some form of record will need to be maintained to ensure that private calls are specifically identified and the necessary payments made. These instructions apply to all our posts, and I would be grateful if the arrangements you have in place in Dublin could be amended accordingly.

That was in August. Of course, it was not until very recently, immediately after the Estimates Committee hearings, that we discovered that these call logs were available, which clearly make much easier the administration of the contribution system involved.

talk.start.para: â€”I accept what the Minister says. In relation to the other matter, I may have misinterpreted one of his letters to Mr Burke, by confusing the private calls and those of the chancery. However, I understand the Minister to be saying to me that the personal calls, pursuant to Mr Burke's assessment in previous years, were not only assessed by also paid for. I think that is what the Minister said. I interpret that to be what he said. Now that he has had time to reflect on these matters, can he explain why, in fact--

speech.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: â€”Just before Senator Hill waxes metaphysical again, I can give him some further information about the Geneva visit which I have just had checked out. The reporting cable in question from Mr Burke arising out of his consultations in Geneva was repeated by us to relevant posts, namely Warsaw and Vienna- Warsaw because at that stage it was acting in relation to Czechoslovakia; Vienna because it was acting as the post in relation to Romania-I am sorry; Belgrade and Vienna-just Vienna because of the general brief in relation to eastern European matters generally. It was repeated to Warsaw, Belgrade and Vienna.

speech.para: The cable was not repeated to Moscow which does suggest that, despite the earlier expectation that representatives from the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics would be involved in the Geneva meeting, that did not, in fact, occur. There does not seem to be any further information that anyone can find as to why the Soviet representatives were not there, or as to the explanation for the submission having been put to me in the terms of Soviet representatives being expected to be there. They were not. In fact, it is quite possible that there was simply a misunderstanding about that because Mr Hancock's visit had been to Romania in relation to Czechoslovakia, not in relation to the Soviet Union, as such.

I take this opportunity to correct an answer to Senate question on notice No. 588 which was asked of me by Senator Campbell on 10 April. The reply has been tabled, but I am not quite sure when. In response to Senator Campbell, there is a reference by me to the Ambassador having been absent overseas from the Dublin Embassy on a variety of dates. The first date relates to this Geneva visit in September 1988. The reference there is to Mr Burke having met with Mr Lang Hancock and Soviet representatives. Having just checked that information with the officer in question, I am advised that that answer was compiled on the basis of the expectation rather than on the reality. That is another unfortunate misstatement of a minor kind, but I hope the record has now been appropriately corrected. I am sorry to have interrupted.

talk.start.para: â€”I thank the Minister for the additional information. I would have to say that he continues to be very generous to his former colleague Mr Burke. The minute quite clearly refers to the purpose of the visit as being to meet with Soviet representatives. On the face of it, that seems to be the basis on which the Minister was being induced to support Mr Burke travelling from Ireland to Geneva. I do not wish to pursue the matter further at the moment. Now that the Minister has had time to reflect on the enormous telephone bills from Dublin, I wonder whether he could give any further or better explanation of the extent of those calls than he was able to give to the Estimates Committee.

speech.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: â€”No, I cannot. The size of the accounts is large compared to elsewhere in Europe. As we have said on earlier occasions, that is partly explicable by the fact that there is a cross-accreditation to the Holy See. It is also partly explicable simply by variations in practice which occur quite naturally as between missions and the way in which they do business, particularly in terms of calls back to Australia and to the Department. The time zones are such that one would expect some categories of calls to be higher from these places than others; namely, calls of an official nature from the private residence.

speech.para: As to the actual quantum, I am not in a position to add anything further to what I said before the Estimates Committee. It may be that when we have Mr Burke's reply going to the break-up, with his memory aided by the call logs in question, I will be able to add something further. But I cannot do so at the moment.

talk.start.para: â€”The arrangement for charging for private telephone calls from the head of mission residence in Dublin was described to the Estimates Committee as having been `agreed with the then senior administrative officer'. The Auditor-General, in his documents tabled in the Senate, refers to the arrangement as being a decision by the Ambassador. Which of those two explanations is correct?

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: â€”I do not believe that they are inconsistent. A decision to do it in a particular way by the ambassador, with the details as worked out by the ambassador and his senior administrative officer, is an entirely likely and understandable way of responding to that particular issue. I do not see any prima facie inconsistency between those two statements.

speech.speaker: Hill Sen R.M.

talk.start.para: â€”It is obviously not the time to debate this, except for the fact that the implication to the Estimates Committee was clearly that this was not a decision-making process by Mr Burke but a shared process in which a fair burden should be placed upon the administrative officer, adding credence to the argument that this is normal practice. The Auditor-General did not see it in those terms at all and made it quite clear this was how Mr Burke determined he should assess private calls-a unique arrangement, it seems, applying only to Mr Burke.

speech.para: The Estimates Committee was told that the audit did not in fact require an end to the 10 per cent arrangement and `that had the effect of indicating that this method of calculating personal contributions was acceptable'. Does the Minister now concede, having again refreshed his memory this morning, that that is not in fact what the audit report said at all? It did not say that it was an acceptable practice. The audit report said it was:

. . . not strictly in accordance with the original contract of terms and conditions of employment. No supporting documentation for the determination of the formula used was available. It is considered the future contracts should be updated to reflect the actual . . .
That is, the actual situation. Therefore, what was the basis for the officer advising the Estimates Committee that the auditor had determined that the practice was acceptable?

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: â€”I have already responded to this. The audit observation and the appropriate management response are that there should be a rationale for the practice put on file; that is, some rationale indicating how the particular formula was struck and why that percentage formula-whatever it is-is to be regarded as likely to be an accurate reflection of the actual usage. That was all that the audit people required at that stage. That is what I have said and that is what appears from the papers that have been tabled.
â€”Senator Harradine, are you on a subject matter different to that which Senator Hill has been discussing?

speech.speaker: Harradine Sen B.

talk.start.para: â€”Senator Hill has been discussing several matters. I want to confine my questions, as did Senator Hill, to two or three matters about which I think this chamber requires more information. I refer to page B124 of the Hansard for Estimates Committee B. There I am shown as having asked a question about the proposed committee which the People's Republic of China has invited Australia to send to examine human rights violations in that country. Among other things, I asked:

speech.para: What areas in your mind should be pursued in respect of human rights violations?
Senator Gareth Evans responded by saying:
The obvious areas of major preoccupation are the right to political dissent; the right to religious freedom-not religious dissent, but religious freedom.

I am interested, and I am sure that the Committee would also be interested, in knowing what Senator Evans had in mind when he stated `the right to religious freedom-not religious dissent, but religious freedom'. I would be grateful if the Minister could explain this.

speech.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: â€”As I recall the context, and I would hope that Senator Harradine recalls it as well, it was a kind of linguistic correction. One talks about political dissent as the right to contest political issues against the approved line from the Government of the day but, in relation to religious expression the main context in which one talks about freedom of religion is not so much the right to dissent but the right to exercise religious freedom without intolerance.

speech.para: If there were an established church which laid down all sorts of rules about what was permissible so far as the practice of religion was concerned in that country and what was impermissible dissent from the approved established church, the appropriate expression probably would be `religious dissent'. But if the context is essentially the Chinese one-and, as I understand it, the argument is about the right to practise one's religion-the appropriate terminology is probably `religious freedom'.

If `religious dissent' is a more apt description in Senator Harradine's mind of what we are talking about here, then so be it. I am not intending to exclude any category of claim of right. It is simply a matter of a linguistic hiccup with my mentally correcting myself and thinking that in this context `religious freedom' is probably a more accurate expression as the appropriate religious counterpart to `political dissent'. If it is the case, as is perhaps it is in Tibet, for example, where essentially a political cry is being expressed through religious means, or in Burma, where so many Buddhist monks have been at the forefront of the campaign of resistance over the years to the military administration, that is not so much a matter of a claim of religious freedom or a right to exercise religious dissent; it is more a matter of political freedom or political dissent taking a religious institutional form. But, honestly, there was no significance to be attached to that distinction as I drew it in the course of that response.

speech.speaker: Harradine Sen B.

talk.start.para: â€”I thank the Minister. Clearly, the Minister means to envisage in his rights to religious freedom the rights of the catholics in China to adhere to their particular faith and to their Holy Father the Pope as being their spiritual leader and guide.
â€”Absolutely. Yes, that is my intention.

â€”I note also that the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has given some responses to the questions that I raised about the arrest and imprisonment of religious leaders, and I note curiously the words on page 182 of the additional information received where the Department states:

speech.para: The forthcoming visit to China of an Australian delegation to examine and discuss human rights in China will provide an opportunity to raise with the relevant Chinese authorities the cases of religious leaders allegedly held in detention and to discuss issues of religious freedom in China.

I would have thought that the word `allegedly' was not appropriate there, unless the Department is unclear as to the facts of the situation. Clearly, there are large numbers of religious leaders and, indeed, people who have attempted to express their religious freedom or their deeply held religious convictions within a spiritually based community who now find themselves in gaol, persecuted in one way or another. I would certainly like the Government to pursue these issues. I am sure what Senator Gareth Evans has said has now clarified the matter.

Besides the issue of people being held in detention, which is most disconcerting, there are other aspects: the receiving of religious literature, the printing of religious literature in China, the refusal of permission to open novitiates, the control of seminaries, and a number of other issues such as permission for ordinations and the return of confiscated property. All these things do go to fundamental rights. I will be very interested to hear the Minister's announcement later this week about the visit, and I look forward to seeing how it is proposed that these issues will be tested. I assume that the Committee will just not accept being handed a copy of the Constitution or a statement by the appropriate Minister and leave it at that.

speech.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: â€”That is an entirely reasonable assumption. The composition of the delegation has been determined and, as I said earlier in response to Senator Hill, I hope to be in a position later this week to announce at least that. Whether I am in a position to announce much more than that so far as the actual detailed program is concerned is a little uncertain at this stage. It depends on some further communications with the Chinese authorities, obviously. However, the delegation is proposing to meet in Canberra at the end of this week to have a first session in terms of discussing the shape, structure and priority of issues to be pursued. There is no doubt that the issues that have been raised by Senator Harradine will be very much in their minds, along with a great many other issues, of course, in working out how the mission is to be best structured and pursued.

speech.para: I assure Senator Harradine that a high degree of assiduousness will be demonstrated in following through these things. Once he sees the composition of the delegation, he will be confident that we have the expertise and credibility to follow through these things. I do not underestimate the delicacy and difficulty of getting something like this off the ground. I hope we do not have too many exaggerated expectations about what the mission will be able to achieve.

The object of the exercise, as I have said all along, essentially is to commence the process of dialogue, to make it clear that there is a very significant body of international opinion which feels very strongly that international principles and values are involved here. Perhaps it really is to be best regarded as the beginning of an ongoing process rather than something which will necessarily produce very spectacular results in itself. Having said all that, I hope that Senator Harradine will continue to be confident as further details come to light that this is a serious exercise which is being pursued with great seriousness and with a maximum possible effectiveness.

speech.speaker: Harradine Sen B.

talk.start.para: â€”I refer to the statement made in Estimates Committee B on page 6, headed `Changes to Explanatory Notes-AIDAB', which says:

speech.para: During questioning under program element 5.2.2 relating to a UNFPA aid project to strengthen the technical capacity of the Centre for Population Studies in the Ministry of Labour in Vietnam, the Committee was informed that the money defined in the Explanatory Notes as being for this particular project has subsequently been diverted to a different UNFPA project in Papua New Guinea and that AIDAB had been aware of this funding change since late February.

The Committee regards this situation as unsatisfactory and advises AIDAB that when significant variations to the Explanatory Notes occur, replacement pages indicating these variations should be provided to the Committee in advance of the public hearings.
The Committee notes in this regard that the Department of Defence provided in advance of the hearings some replacement pages which identified minor typographical and computational errors.
I do not want to make a big thing of this. Obviously, it is just a foul-up on that aspect. That is the bad news. I will just leave that as it is for the record. I am sure it will not occur again.

The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade did do the right thing by making a number of savings and, I suppose, theoretically, though not practically, in respect of some of these areas it did not have to present additional Estimates to the Parliament.

Obviously we would have found out about this post factum at the next Estimates committee and there would have been a hullabaloo if we had seen savings made in one area and the money sent to new projects here, there and everywhere. In the area of program budgeting, this is a problem: the question of the rights of parliament to exercise proper audit and control of taxpayers' expenditure on certain projects is not guaranteed.

I compliment the Department for having the principles of democracy and parliamentary accountability at heart and for presenting this material. The Department would recall a particular instance when a certain amount of money went from one country to another. The Minister in charge at the particular time did not know about it. But those days are gone. Leaving aside the criticism that Estimates Committee B quite properly made-that we had before us a piece of paper telling us where expenditure was going in Vietnam when it was not going there at all-I reiterate that the Department should be congratulated on and encouraged in its obvious respect for the spirit of democracy and parliamentary accountability in this country.

In the Estimates we were told of savings of around half a million dollars being transferred to particular areas. I ask the question: where should the priorities lie? If $500,000 of aid money is saved, what are the priority areas where that money should be placed? In this case the Department has placed it, in effect, largely in two areas of population control policy: one in Pakistan and one in Papua New Guinea. There are one or two other areas. I recall that last September I questioned the Minister at the Estimates Committee hearing on the savage cuts in funds to a food-for-work and reafforestation project in Ethiopia. At the time, the Minister stated:
In the circumstances of the pressure the aid budget was under, we very regrettably had no choice but to terminate it. It was a good project.
If I had some more money, that is one of the first things I would reinstate.

The Minister had $500,000-not a great deal, but $500,000-and it did not go to this project. It went to population control programs, which I will come to shortly. I believe that we should be given an explanation.

speech.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: â€”I am indebted to Senator Harradine for the generosity of his comments about the Department's responsiveness to the democratic demands upon us to keep the Committee and the Parliament informed as to what has happened when programs are changed, to the extent we possibly can. I say again for the record that the particular matter that the Committee drew attention to was the subject of apology and explanation at the hearing itself.

speech.para: The revised page recording the program change had been prepared in ample time within the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau (AIDAB) but, as a result of a communication breakdown, it had not been forwarded to honourable senators as a replacement page before the hearing. Copies were circulated during the hearing and AIDAB apologised for that. It might have been nice if the Committee had been as generous as Senator Harradine in acknowledging the apology in the language of the report.

Be that as it may, the more substantial question is the one that Senator Harradine raises about the reallocation of priorities. Let me put this into context by saying that, when one has an aid program involving the expenditure of something like $1.3 billion, as ours does, there are an enormous number of programs across an enormously wide spectrum, not all of which obviously fall out exactly within the time frames originally envisaged.

The truth of the matter is that, in the last couple of months of any given financial year, up to around $20m worth of aid expenditure is reallocated, usually within particular identified programs but sometimes from one program category to another. The accounting for that is, of course, conveyed to the Senate Estimates Committee if this happens before the Estimates Committee meets. Otherwise it has to go into the final wrap-up accounts for the year, which are then subject to scrutiny in later processes.

However, in this case it was not a matter of having $500,000 fortuitously available because of the non-expenditure on the Vietnam population studies program this year. It was a matter of that $500,000 being part of a larger sum of nearly $20m, which was also being moved around at that stage. When money is moved around in this way it is not a matter of scrambling at the last minute to find some appropriately worthy cause to devote the money to. It is really just a matter of bringing forward further programs in the same subject area that are in a particular pipeline.

The Papua New Guinea (PNG) program-I think this is true of the Pakistani one also-to which Senator Harradine referred, was very much intended to be the subject matter of expenditure in the next financial year. The money was able to be brought forward to fill the gap that was left by the Vietnam expenditure having to be, in effect, postponed. So this money was being spent within the policy commitment to doing useful things in the population area.

When I referred to my wish that money become available to be able to restore the Ethiopian reafforestation program, which certainly remains my wish, because it was a good program, I was referring to an overall net increase in the Budget rather than money becoming fortuitously available as a result of programming problems of a familiar kind. That is, I hope, a full explanation of why things are as they are. I hope that Senator Harradine will appreciate the context in which this decision was accordingly made.

In terms of the intrinsic merits of the population program as it applies to PNG, we have become increasingly concerned about the very high rate of population growth in PNG, which is throwing out a number of earlier calculations that were made not only by ourselves but also by the PNG Government about the future economic development of the country and restraint on resources, as well as employment, youth welfare and everything else. It is becoming a matter of quite important policy concern which does need addressing. We were pleased in that respect to be able to accelerate the priority with which this money was spent in population activities in PNG. I appreciate, as always, the sensitivity of this subject as far as Senator Harradine is concerned, but I hope he will understand the good faith in which this program has been implemented.

talk.start.para: â€”Leaving aside that last comment which I will come back to when I question the Minister about the PNG program, a couple of things in his response did worry me a little. I hope my appraisal of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has not been too effusive. The Minister said that there was shuffling around of perhaps $20m between programs. Does that mean between programs which have already been the subject of scrutiny by the Estimates Committee and the Parliament?

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: â€”As I said, to the extent possible. What I was talking about was, essentially, what happens in the May-June period each year. Sometimes it becomes apparent earlier than May-June-as was the case with the Vietnam program-that a particular program is not likely to be expended in that year for whatever reason. It is very often the case that it is not until towards the end of the year that it becomes obvious that there will be shortfalls of expenditure in some areas. We communicate as best as we possibly can to the Estimates Committee totally up-to-date information as to how the money is being expended between programs. If it happens after the Estimates Committee hearings then that accounting, as I said, really has to go into the next financial year's Estimates and does, of course, show up in the Forward Estimates documentation which honourable senators receive and debate in September-October or later.

â€”One could understand the transfer of moneys to projects for which there is overwhelming general approval by the Parliament including famine relief, disaster relief and that sort of thing. At the present moment there are considerable demands for moneys in those particular areas, and I refer to the amounts required in Eritrea just to give an example. It is the Government's responsibility when money is shuffled around to make sure that, if there are savings from one project, it goes to another project that has the authorisation of, and has been subject to the scrutiny of, the Parliament. This particular matter had not been and that was the reason why, quite properly, the Department brought it to the Estimates Committee. I ask the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade whether the bulk of the $500,000 was saved from an agro-climatology program. Was that not the case?

speech.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: â€”It was a United Nations Fund for Population Activities aid project to strengthen the technical capacity of the Centre for Population Studies in the Ministry of Labour in Vietnam. What the Centre for Population Studies would be doing about agro-climatology I do not know. I will need to get a slightly more detailed account of this, but it was within the general environmental rubric originally. I have now been told that there was an agro-climatology project, the money was not able to be expended on that and was diverted to the Vietnam Centre for Population Studies. It was not able to be spent on that, for whatever reason, and it was sent to Papua New Guinea.

speech.para: The population issue is regarded as broadly within the spectrum of issues covered by the environment program for reasons that have to do with the conceptual approach to environmental protection, with population increase being one obviously important factor impacting upon that. We can debate the theology or the metaphysics of this conceptualisation perhaps at considerable length, but that is how it happened. I will need to trace the course of that particular allocation.

I simply want to say that it has been my intention, which I have frankly articulated to Senator Harradine, the Estimates Committee and this Parliament, to devote as many resources as we can within the broad aid budget and the other demands upon us, to properly supervised and constrained population activities. I do not make any apology for finding the opportunity to do so as occasion arises. All of these things are fully reported to the Parliament and are subject to full scrutiny, not always before the event but certainly after the event. The opportunity to do that is, of course, in the detailed Estimates Committee hearings themselves. That is an opportunity that Senator Harradine has amply taken advantage of in the past and no doubt will again.

speech.speaker: Harradine Sen B.

talk.start.para: â€”This is not the place, as the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade said-although he seemed to take advantage of it-to argue about whether his view of the situation is the correct one or not; that is to say, whether the priority that he gives to population control is consistent with proper considerations of development assistance, economics or human rights, for that matter. That is a debate for some other time. What I am simply asking is, because the saving has been made from the agro-climatology aspect of the environmental aid budget, would it not have been more appropriate to give it to the Ethiopian project which was a food for work and reafforestation project? I simply leave that with the Minister to think about and to chew on because, in my view, that might have been one of the particular areas calling out for immediate aid including the ones that I have previously mentioned.

speech.para: Turning to the areas where the money went, the responses have not included detailed information on the Pakistan program. I do not ask the Minister now, but I would like the Department to take on notice to provide me with the details of that program at the earliest opportunity.

speech.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: â€”I am able to tell Senator Harradine that the amounts in question which went to Pakistan, at least under broad headings, are as follows: reading materials for female literacy, $0.08m; traditional birth attendance, immunisation, family planning and training for rural women, $26,000; and women's development through increased skills, $104,000. That is the way in which that Pakistan money was broken up. If Senator Harradine wants any further information I guess we can supply it, but that information is about as precise as we can presently provide.

speech.para: I will certainly chew on the Ethiopian matter, but there is a question whether we can just put small, bite-sized amounts of this kind in and out of programs of that kind or whether we stay committed to funding in a major and ongoing way. I am advised that, at the time of the agro-climatology initiative funds becoming available, there were no non-population projects suitable for funding in what was left of that particular financial year that had been identified and were readily able to be expended upon, whereas the other things were available in the way that I have indicated.

It is also the case that there had been something of a shortfall in terms of the amount of money allocated to population activities in the Budget, that is, $1.4m as compared with the amount that I had originally sought in the Budget process. This was an effort to top that up a little consistently with the general picture that I have described, which is that population activities are seen as an important element in the whole question of sustainable development.

speech.speaker: Harradine Sen B.

talk.start.para: â€”Senator Gareth Evans is nearly inviting me to debate that. At some stage we must debate it in a clear and reasoned fashion rather than have the Minister making an assertion which, frankly, I have not seen rationally supported by him nor in the literature that I have read.

speech.para: I am aware of the fact that the money this Government is giving to the International Planned Parenthood Federation (IPPF), for example, is being used for institutional strengthening to support that particular view and that view only. There is a great deal of censorship going on in this whole area in academic circles. It is a tragedy that there is this sort of censorship, this institutional strengthening, where people get on this band wagon and keep on going. As the Minister knows, the United Nations Fund for Population Activities (UNFPA) and IPPF have a vested interest in keeping the money flowing.

I raise only two other matters. On the proposed Vietnam project, the answers that I have received are on page 180. This is now no longer a project, but I simply raise this because the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau did say that it would examine factors indicating the success in the first stage. Yet the paper that we received from AIDAB said that the Vietnam project was a `successful project'. In response to my question as to what were the tests of success, AIDAB has indicated that it would examine what factors indicated success in the first stage.

That to me is not adequate. I am aware of the difficulties of getting information from Vietnam, but it is not impossible to deduce what is going on in Vietnam. There are reports from time to time. In respect of this issue of human rights and population control in Vietnam, for example, there was a report by Reuters as far back as 22 November 1988. It goes as far back as November 1988. The report said:

People will be offered free contraceptives and abortions, while a ``commendation and award system'' will encourage vasectomy and sterilisation, the Communist Party newspaper Nhan Dan reported a government decree as saying.
For those who have too many children ``the organs of direct management will mete out appropriate punitive measures according to the law currently in force,'' said the paper's October 27 issue . . .

I wonder whether the Department has this material on file. Does it say that the project that it has been funding is successful? Has it tested that against human rights violations in that program or has it just accepted the view of UNFPA? Frankly, UNFPA does not impress me one bit.

Despite the Minister's letter-and I am pleased that he wrote the letter-Nafis Sadik has, to my knowledge, never come out and criticised the coercive elements of the Chinese population control program. She has taken the material that has been given to her by the PRC Minister. Indeed, not only that but, on 8 April 1991, after the Chinese Communist Party General-Secretary had made statements clearly indicating the nature of the PRC population control program which makes it coercive, Nafis Sadik said that China `should feel proud of its achievements in effectively controlling the growth of its population'. That was said on the very same day.

Incidentally, the day after that, Chinese Premier Li Peng said that, from the historical perspective, the measures adopted by the Chinese Government to quench the riots on 4 June 1989 had been proved correct. Does the Department take the word of UNFPA on this issue? Has it examined the consequent question of vio- lations of human rights in the Vietnam program, and what tests have been done as to the validity of what AIDAB calls a `successful program' in Vietnam?

speech.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: â€”I am not sure that I am able to add much by way of specific reply to Senator Harradine's concerns. All I can say in general terms is that, as I have made clear in previous Estimates hearings, I share his distaste for anything in the nature of coercion associated with these population programs in China, Vietnam or anywhere else. We have expressed that view very strongly to the UNFPA. I have no basis for believing that Madam Sadik and anyone else in the UNFPA are other than genuine in the way in which they respond to my expressions and, indeed, Senator Harradine's expressions in this respect. All I can say is that we will continue to monitor very carefully, as best we possibly can, the way in which these programs are implemented.

speech.para: As any new information comes to hand, we will do our best to test that information and to seek specific responses on it. I understand that we have been doing so in relation to Vietnam and we have, of course, been doing so in relation to China. We will further pursue some of those issues in relation to China in the course of the human rights delegation. This will have to be the subject of ongoing and careful scrutiny.

I understand and appreciate Senator Harradine's interest in this. If he keeps drawing to my attention things that may have escaped me and the Department, I give the assurance that I will do my best, as will the Minister for Trade and Overseas Negotiations, Dr Blewett, to follow these things up and ensure that the principles that we both agree with are, in fact, applied in practice.

speech.speaker: Harradine Sen B.

talk.start.para: â€”I am referring to the transfer of part of this money saved to a program proposed for Papua New Guinea and that program will rely heavily on the drug depo-provera. I point out to the Committee that the details given to us by the Department show clearly that the UNFPA has set targets for contraceptive acceptance of oral contraceptives, condoms and depo-provera from an estimated 6 per cent in 1989 to 35 per cent by 1995.

speech.para: Depo-provera accounts for 63.3 per cent of the total funds to be spent on contraceptive purchases for women by the UNFPA for the PNG projects. This indicates that the UNFPA has decided that approximately six out of every 10 targeted women will use depo-provera. The use of depo-provera for contraception is not an approved indication in Australia and such use is investigational since there are unresolved questions relating to its safety for this indication.

Here we have a drug which is not an approved indication for contraception purposes in Australia but which will be the key element in a program that we are supporting in Papua New Guinea. That to me is shameful. It opens the way for quite serious accusations against the Australian Government-accusations of cultural colonialism and racism. If the drug is not so approved in Australia, why do we support a UNFPA program for its use in Papua New Guinea? Depo-provera will be the major element of this program.

The Department said that the project was well justified in terms of helping meet significant needs for better and more widely available maternal care. AIDAB said that it is estimated that 1,000 women die annually as a direct result of pregnancy and that the majority of these deaths could be avoided by the provision of adequate ante-natal and post-natal care. Can the Minister respond as to why-if the apparent focus of the project is on improving maternal health care-AIDAB has classified the project as an environmental program? I think Senator Knowles wants to intervene, and I am happy to accede to her.

speech.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: â€”I have some responses to what Senator Harradine has just been saying. I will get rid of those first of all because I do not want to leave the matter on the record with the misunderstanding that is apparently there. For a start, the Australian contribution to the Papua New Guinea (PNG) project of the UNFPA is at the moment going only towards salaries for people, in effect, to develop the program; it is not actually being used for the purchase of contraceptives. I think it is a $3m program. We have not been asked to fund it as such; it is just this particular bridging dimension of it. But, that having been said, clearly the program does need justification. It is focused on maternal health and it will provide contraceptives, including depo-provera. It is important to understand two things about the depo-provera aspect of the program. Firstly, it is not true to say, as Senator Harradine does, that six out of every 10 women in PNG targeted for contraceptive use will be supplied with depo-provera. There is a wide range of contraceptive options, including natural family planning methods. Couples are free to choose the most appropriate methods. Project inputs will be adjusted accordingly. The reason that depo-provera represents 60 per cent of the budget earmarked for contraceptive supplies is simply that it is so expensive. Injectable contraceptives are more expensive than other kinds.
â€”I have the costings.

â€”Well, it is $348,000 out of $595,000, which is 20 per cent of $3m, which has been identified for contraceptive supplies. One cannot extrapolate from that that six out of every 10 women supplied with contraceptives will be using depo-provera. That simply does not follow from that particular arithmetic calculation. Depo-provera costs more per person.

speech.para: The second thing to say about depo-provera is that it should not be assumed that there is something inherently bad or wrong or inappropriate about it. Not only is it a family planning method presently offered by the PNG Department of Health, but also its use is approved by the World Health Organisation (WHO) as a contraceptive option. The PNG Department of Health is following WHO guidelines which are internationally accepted in its own proposed application of the drug.

Depo-provera is approved for use in over 80 industrial and developing countries, including Australia, where it is available under certain circumstances for defined indications. The Family Planning Federation of Australia and the Royal Australian College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists believe that it is perfectly responsible and appropriate for medical practitioners to prescribe depo-provera in Australia in defined circumstances.

talk.start.para: â€”But not for contraception.
â€”Be that as it may, I have responded as best I can to what Senator Harradine has said.

â€”I have a few short questions which I was hoping I would have been able to ask immediately following Senator Hill's questions about the former Ambassador to Ireland, Mr Burke. I bring Senator Evans back to the question of Mr Burke's telephone bills. Given that they were so high in comparison with other posts around the world, particularly comparable posts in Europe, why was the figure of 10 per cent set for the personal level, considering that it is obviously so low? Did the Minister not have some suspicion when he saw the telephone bills coming through that they were excessively high and that that component may well have been made up of an excessively high number of personal phone calls, and that therefore the situation should have been reviewed?

speech.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: â€”I have said already in the Estimates Committee hearings and I think in the Senate that the questions of quantum-the actual dollars involved-were not put in front of me when I wrote to Mr Burke in August 1990. The question in issue was one of process rather than amount. I do not think anyone actually had regard to the actual dollar amounts-in particular, the relative size of the bills here as compared with other posts-until this matter became the subject of more detailed scrutiny earlier this year.
