speech.para: The point essentially is that, under the devolved management strategies that we have been introducing-with a great deal of enthusiastic support from the honourable senator's side of politics-in the Public Service generally and within my Department in particular, questions of detailed administration and the allocation of budgets as between particular areas have been devolved to posts. The only time that the Department gets to second guess what posts are doing in this respect is when some claim is made for supplementation-when some claim is made that the particular administrative allocation that a post has been given is insufficient.

That then sets in train a process of detailed scrutiny of just how the post has been spending the money and whether in fact the claim is legitimate, sensible or reasonable, given prevailing patterns of expenditure elsewhere. It is not a subject of minute scrutiny as long as no extra claim is being made against the original amounts that were allocated which, I might say, have been in increasingly short supply in recent years. It is getting tougher and tougher for posts to manage with their budgets.

I am advised that there had been no cry of pain from the Dublin mission about its budget being inadequate for it to cope. So it simply had not been the subject of attention at this stage last year. Now that it is the subject of attention and it is apparent that those telephone costs for Dublin are very high, obviously I am seeking explanations; and that has been the point of my correspondence with Mr Burke and it is the point of the current exchange. It is why I am awaiting with almost as much interest as the honourable senator-perhaps not quite as much-Mr Burke's reply to see how it shapes up and to see whether the 10 per cent was in fact, for the benefit of the detail available in these logs, an appropriate rough rule of thumb calculation or whether it was astray. If it was astray, the honourable senator will have her explanation.

talk.start.para: â€”I can understand why the Minister personally would not necessarily be involved in the day to day running of the post but, surely, his Department would be aware in a budgetary process from year to year of the posts trying to appropriate that type of money and that, therefore, the amount for telephone calls from Dublin was far in excess of that in comparable posts. Therefore, it might be brought to the Minister's attention and might make it seem a bit odd to the Minister that the amount was so much higher than everywhere else.

speech.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: â€”We have 89 or 90 posts around the world. An absolute army of people to second guess every item of expenditure that is incurred by those posts and to make comparative judgments about it simply does not exist. It is the case that the posts operate within a framework of detailed guidelines and regulations which are laid out in practice. It is the case that there is an internal audit program, quite apart from the Australian National Audit Office program, which operates in relation to those posts. If there are any irregularities in the procedures involved they will show up. I guess it tends to be inherent in the nature of audit proceedings that the focus is on process rather than quantum. As long as the process is accurate, audit people do not tend to make comparative judgments about amounts.

speech.para: Practice does vary enormously between posts as to the way in which they operate and between individuals as to the way in which they operate. It is not, prima facie, wholly implausible that different posts with different managerial styles might have differently shaped accounts. I repeat: the posts are operating within tight budgetary constraints and if they internally organise themselves consistent with proper procedures and practice so far as the auditors are concerned that is not something which you could reasonably expect to leap out at the financial administrators in Canberra unless and until some specific focus is placed upon it.

talk.start.para: â€”Is Senator Evans assuring himself, or has he assured himself, from the evidence of the telephone log-I understand from what he said this morning that, quite rightly, for privacy reasons he will not necessarily be looking at the log himself-that Mr Burke was not involved in party politics while serving as an ambassador, given the fact that on previous occasions the Minister has said that it would be inappropriate for an ambassador to do that? Has the Minister sought to ensure, through some other mechanism, that that was not happening while Mr Burke was being paid as an ambassador by the Federal Government?

speech.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: â€”I think this issue has been covered pretty exhaustively in earlier debates surrounding the circumstances of Mr Burke's resignation. When it became apparent that Mr Burke was involved in party politics, at least in the sense of doing something by way of administering a party leader's account, that was one of the issues that contributed to the course of events that lead very directly to Mr Burke's resignation.
â€”But you did not sack him.

â€”The honourable senator should remember-and I do not want to again track over everything that has been said-the two separate sides to it. The first is the question of illegality or impropriety. I make no judgments now, nor have I in the past, about that illegality or impropriety except to say that, if there was activity that involved active ongoing participation in political party affairs, it would be quite inappropriate for an ambassador to engage in that. Whether it is inappropriate to the point of requiring dismissal is another question and one that I have answered previously in this place. But it is manifestly inappropriate.

speech.para: The other side of the coin is the extent to which the issues bore upon Mr Burke's capacity to actually handle the job, in terms of both the physical time he could devote to it and his capacity to operate in a climate that was not coloured by this issue, in terms of the local press and so on. It is already well known-and I have said it in this place-that when it did become apparent that a series of issues about party political activity that needed to be further tested and discussed were now in the public domain this would require a lot of Mr Burke's time to be spent in Australia before the Royal Commission into Commercial Activities of Government and Other Matters in order to resolve the issue and would generate a degree of controversy which would be unhelpful in Ireland. Under those circumstances, the resignation option was entirely appropriate. We have been through all of that before and I really do not think I can add anything very useful to what I have said in this respect.

talk.start.para: â€”Will the Minister still go ahead with rewriting the new standards for ambassadors?

â€”I have asked the Department to advise me of the desirability, practicability and utility of preparing some kind of handbook for ambassadors in this respect, addressing their responsibilities specifically in a way that is not covered by documents which are applicable to the Public Service as a whole. I am still awaiting that advice. I do not know what will be proposed to me in this respect. I am not assuming that some handbook or guidelines document will actually be proposed; I am waiting to get advice on the desirability and utility of it.

speech.para: I, myself, think there would be some utility in laying down these things in a more precise way, particularly because it is the case that a number of Public Service guidelines are not formally applicable to ambassadors. At the moment they are regarded as being in a separate category. It is probably appropriate, as a practical matter, that they should be applied to ambassadors, and to that extent it would be helpful to lay this out clearly. That is where I start from, but where I will finish will depend, among other things, upon the guidance and advice I receive from my Department, which is no doubt working away assiduously at it at the moment-if not quite this very second.

talk.start.para: â€”I am obviously still very concerned that the inference is that, because one ambassador has played up, a reference is being placed on all ambassadors that perhaps they should not be involved in investments, running accounts--
â€”Or that they do not know how to behave.

â€”Or, as my colleague says, that they do not know how to behave. Given that that has happened in the past with Mr Burke in particular-that is not hearsay evidence, it is his own evidence that he avoided paying tax on the accounts that he was running-has the Minister, as Mr Burke's former boss, sought the assistance of Senator McMullan and Senator Beahan as to what they knew about the leader's account. Has he asked why the tax was not being paid on that account when they were very much involved with it-from Senator McMullan's point of view as National Secretary of the Australian Labor Party, or whatever he was, and from Senator Beahan's point of view as State Secretary-to assure himself as to why no tax was paid on those accounts?

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: â€”No, I have not because the issue, as far as my responsibilities are concerned, was resolved by Mr Burke's resignation. As far as other more general matters of public interest are concerned, they will be dealt with by the Royal Commission. As far as the interests of the taxpayers of the nation are concerned, they will be dealt with by the Australian Commissioner of Taxation.

â€”I want to clarify that, even though evidence was given by Mr Burke before he resigned-or before the Minister sacked him, whichever case it was-the Minister at no stage sought to clarify whether the law had been broken with regard to tax.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: â€”I have answered a question in this place about that issue, as did the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). Questions of tax liability are matters for the Commissioner of Taxation-not for me to make assumptions or to conduct investigations about.

speech.speaker: Harradine Sen B.

talk.start.para: â€”I have found figures that can prove that Senator Evans's information is misleading. First of all, I will go through what Senator Evans said. What he is saying is this, `We are just supplying a project coordinator and this is an amount for bridging finance'. The whole program has been assessed and approved by the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau. It did not adequately assess the issue of depo-provera and its implications.

speech.para: The Minister knows as well as a number of others in this chamber that I am very careful in what I say, particularly when it comes to figures. It is from the information that his Department gave us-that is, Estimate Committee B and the chamber-that I arrived at my figure. In other words, the figures that his Department gave us indicate that UNFPA has decided that approximately six out of every 10 targeted women will use depo-provera. The Minister has come back with the answer that, no, that is not right because there will be a number of other contraceptives involved-condoms and oral contraceptives-as well as depo-provera. Let us agree to exclude condoms when we are talking about women and deal with the other two. The information I have from the UNFPA procurement office clearly does not support what the Minister has implied-I think he has even said it-which is that because depo-provera is substantially more expensive the basis of my calculations is wrong. According to the procurement office of the UNFPA, that is not correct.

talk.start.para: â€”Why? What are you saying?

â€”The figures from the UNFPA procurement office show that, on the basis of dosage times unit cost, depo-provera costs around $US2.80 per year and that oral contraceptives cost around $US2.10 per year. Other estimates that were given to me have a lower figure for bulk purchase of depo-provera. I assert, based on information obtained by me, that the Government is to support a massive program in Papua New Guinea whose key, so far as the women are concerned, is a drug-depo-provera-which is not an approved indication for contraception in Australia.

speech.para: Another thing that Senator Evans mentioned is that there will also be the natural family planning method. From the information that has been given to me, I cannot see it stated anywhere that that method is to be part of the UNFPA program. It rarely is. The reason is that UNFPA is tied in with the drug companies. The Billings ovulation method has been proven as a culturally accepted and effective method of family planning in a number of trials, including recent successful Indian Council of Medical Research trials in India and Family Health International trials in Indonesia. Both of those organisations have views on population control which would not accord with mine. Yet trials have been done and the Billings ovulation method has been found to be culturally accepted and effective. So why are we supporting this particular program of UNFPA with its heavy reliance on depo-provera?

speech.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: â€”Quickly, I will give the figures again. The total project is costing $3m. The only component of it that Australia has been asked to contribute to is a bridging phase for consultation and development, which is at a cost of $265,000. We are not directly providing the contraceptives themselves, which are only 20 per cent of the total program, nor will we in the future. As I understand, this is as far as our contribution will go. But we support the program itself, and therefore it is a legitimate series of questions that Senator Harradine has asked.

speech.para: As to the relative cost of depo-provera and the question about the number of women that are being targeted, the point I was simply making is that, of the total of $595,000 that has been earmarked at PNG's request for contraceptive supplies, $348,000 has been earmarked for injectable contraceptives- that is, depo-provera-which is roughly six-tenths of the total cost of the contraceptives involved. I am making the point that Senator Harradine cannot simply extrapolate from that financial calculation to make the assumption that six out of every 10 women are being targeted.

talk.start.para: â€”I wasn't. I didn't.

â€”My understanding was that was the only basis on which Senator Harradine could have drawn the conclusion that six out of 10 women were being targeted in that way, simply by virtue of the costs involved. One can argue about the relative costs of it. I am told that while it is the case that the cost of depo-provera might be of the order of magnitude Senator Harradine has suggested over a year, the cost of condoms is obviously significantly less than that, depending, of course, on the degree of usage Senator Harradine--
â€”We are talking about targeted women.
â€”All right. Well, I am not going to get into--
â€”We are talking about targeted women. Are you going to say that they are going to somehow use condoms?

â€”No, it can be supplied with them. It is not unusual in these programs for the women to be the targets of the program. That is an available method delivered through the women just as much as through the men. It depends on the particular cultures involved which is the most likely to be productive-or unproductive. For all the virtue of the Billings ovulation method, and while it may be culturally acceptable, to make it work with all the rigour, apparatus and conscientiousness that are involved in the back blocks of Enga or Mount Hagen is something that has to be taken into account by those administering these projects.

speech.para: One of the virtues, of course, of depo-provera is that it works for three months at a time. In an environment where there is an alarming series of developments so far as infant and maternal mortality rates are concerned-and that, let us come back to it, is the nub of the problem-the whole question of maternal health, including family planning, is a crucially important one to address. It is a matter for the judgment of the people concerned as to what the best way of doing it is in the environment in question. For all the anxiety that Senator Harradine may have about depo-provera as a contraceptive method, I can only repeat what I said earlier: it is one that is approved as a contraceptive option by the World Health Organisation. WHO has set guidelines and it is within those guidelines that PNG is operating.

speech.speaker: Harradine Sen B.

talk.start.para: â€”The Minister has challenged the statement I made. I am now more than convinced that the statement is correct: this program-which he now admits that the Government supports-the UNFPA project for Papua New Guinea, relies heavily on depo-provera.

speech.para: I come back to the point that it was not on the simple mathematical calculation of the cost of the drug as provided to me by the Department. I went further and obtained from the UNFPA bulk procurement office the actual costs. That is what we are talking about; this group is running the program in Papua New Guinea. On the basis of those costs, compared with oral contraceptives, condoms do not come into it. It is a fact that approximately six out of 10 women will be targeted to use the drug depo-provera.

Senator Evans might talk about what the World Health Organisation, which designed the PNG project, says. My concern has been expressed previously about the WHO's unethical approach to these questions of population control drugs and other measures. The WHO has a human reproduction program that is developing RU486, the abortion drug, and assisting in the development of an anti-HCG vaccine. That is the sort of ethics that Senator Evans is talking about so far as the WHO is concerned in these particular areas. Of course, in a large number of other areas the WHO is doing a marvellous job, but in this particular area its ethics are very questionable indeed.

I remind the Senate that the former Director-General of the WHO, Halfdan Mahler-who, incidentally, now has gone over as head of IPPF, the International Planned Parenthood Federation-said as far back as 1983 that WHO's perceived neutrality made it `a most appropriate instrument to deal with an area as sensitive as that of family planning research'.

What does that mean? What I am saying to the Minister is that we have no right to support a project which is heavily reliant on a drug which is not an approved indication for contraceptive purposes in Australia, and that is a very important issue.

One comes finally to the last point, the nub of the question-maternal deaths. If the Minister's Department has advised him that the UNFPA project in PNG should be supported for that reason, it is on the wrong track. The great crying need, so far as maternal deaths in Papua New Guinea are concerned, is to have a widespread network of trained birth attendants and other persons who are trained to support women during pregnancy, at time of birth and after to ensure the good health of them and their children. In its documentation AIDAB says that 22 per cent of the estimated 1,000 maternal deaths at birth were from puerperal sepsis. That is a condition which is far more common in women having their first baby. Unless there is a hidden coercive agenda, the UNFPA project will not overcome maternal deaths among women with four or more children who are the targets for depo-provera, let alone those women having their first child.

AIDAB has not done its homework on this issue. It has not looked at the situation and seen that there are crying needs in Papua New Guinea. I was the only backbencher of this Parliament to be invited to the opening of the new Papua New Guinea Parliament. I know a little about Papua New Guinea. I love the people there. But to have pushed on them a program, which is supported by our money, involving a drug that is not culturally accepted by them is wrong. I talked to women there in the health area; and it is not culturally acceptable. Half of them do not know what is happening and their husbands are concerned about the effect that it is having on their relationships and its ill effects on their wives.

I ask the Minister and his department to reconsider this issue and to have a good look at it, because I fear that, in the end, it will blow up in their faces. But worse than that, I fear that it will have adverse consequences so far as Papua New Guinean people are concerned. I also urge the Minister and AIDAB to have a look at the really important things that need to be done in respect of maternal health care in Papua New Guinea. If we are talking about maternal deaths and if that is the nub of the question, I ask the Minister to have a good look at it and rethink it.

speech.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: â€”There is no question about Senator Harradine's good faith in this respect and I understand and respect the spirit in which he asks these questions. I assure him that we will take very seriously what he said and follow it further.

speech.para: There has been a long course of discussion, I am advised, with the Papua New Guinea health department about all these issues. But I think rather than trying to track over the detail of this, in this environment at this stage and in this atmosphere, it is better for me to simply respond by saying that we understand the points he is making, and we will take them aboard in our continuing close evaluation of this program.

talk.start.para: â€”Can the Department give me further information about the Commonwealth Foundation? It was going to do so at some particular stage.

speech.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: â€”Certainly; I will ensure that that happens.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.
REPORT OF ESTIMATES COMMITTEE C
Motion (by Senator Richardson) proposed:
That the report of Estimates Committee C be adopted.

talk.start.para: â€”The Committee will consider the expenditure examined by Estimates Committee C. The first department to be considered is the Department of Social Security.
â€”Could the Minister explain, in the privacy area, what the situation is concerning other departments or States wanting information regarding social security beneficiaries?
â€”It has to be permissible under section 19.
â€”Would you explain that?
â€”There are rules set out in section 19 and if it complies with that-if you would like me to read that section out, I will do so.
â€”If you could just paraphrase your view.

â€”Basically it says that no officer can divulge any information on our clients to anyone. The only exception would be if the disclosure is considered to be in the national interest. If that was the case, I think I make a determination and then the Secretary has to issue a certificate, which would permit it. I think that that is a fairly strict arrangement, and it seems to work. Obviously, in recent times that has come under some pressure, but we have been holding the line because we regard privacy as being very important.

â€”Do I understand it correctly that if a State department wanted access to the names of social security beneficiaries, the Minister would have to give permission for that department to acquire those names and addresses?

â€”The previous Minister, Mr Howe, made some determinations about the disclosure of information, and I think we are mainly talking about access for State departments as to whether people were eligible for fringe benefits. That was the main purpose.
â€”Social security benefits-just generally.

â€”I am trying to explain where this mostly applies. To give an example, local councils seek access so as to know whether pensioners are entitled to Commonwealth fringe benefits, which is very often a determining factor as to whether they are entitled to the benefits that the local council might provide. My understanding is that the previous Minister gave a determination on that question, and I have never sought to alter it. Some State departments and some councils get access on that basis. To make it clear: that does not give them access to the personal details on the file, such as what beneficiaries are paid, where they live and how many people they live with; it confirms that they are eligible for benefits.
â€”Does that apply only to fringe benefits of age pensioners?

â€”I am trying to make absolutely sure; I do not wish to mislead the Committee on that point. In so far as I am aware-it has just been confirmed to me-the pensioner confirmation service operates only on the basis that I have just explained: that is, the person's eligibility for those benefits would be confirmed to the inquiring agency. I think that point most recently came up in the Brisbane City Council over deeming when that became an issue. That is the only way that we would confirm anyone's eligibility.

â€”If that is the only one, as Minister, have you recently given permission to the Tasmanian Department of Roads and Transport to obtain information on names and addresses of social security beneficiaries?

â€”I certainly have not and officers here are shaking their heads indicating to me that they do not know anything about it either. I could check for you as to whether any previous Minister has ever done it. I certainly have not signed anything about this.
â€”It occurred in your time in your portfolio. Are you making sure?
â€”I am trying to make sure.
â€”I am sure you would remember.

â€”We would have to check to see whether they are part of the client confirmation service program now. I do not recall adding them, but I will have to check to see whether that has been done. The thing to remember about the client confirmation service is that it involves the consent of the pensioner as well.

speech.speaker: Walters Sen M.S.

talk.start.para: â€”The Minister will perhaps understand my concern when I read what I have before me. It is from the Tasmanian Department of Roads and Transport. It is an application for a school bus transport pass. It is addressed to the recipient, including the name and address. It reads:

speech.para: The State Government is extending free school bus transport to your children. As you are a recipient of a Commonwealth Social Security benefit . . . your children are eligible to receive free transport if they are attending school by bus . . .

How was the Tasmanian Department of Roads and Transport able to ascertain the names of all social security beneficiaries and post out to them individually an application for a school bus pass for their children? The beneficiaries were not aware that a State department had access to such information and I was not aware that a State department was entitled to have access to such private information. I was sure that the Minister for Social Security would not give permission for that information to have been handed over to any State department.

talk.start.para: â€”I would not, but occasionally the Department of Social Security sends mail-outs for State departments. Where they wish to make it known to eligible people that a particular benefit, such as a free pass on buses or trains, is available it is quite possible that we would agree to send out a mail-out for them. I do not actually give permission for that to be done, because it does not involve the disclosure of any information, but I will certainly check up on it. The State departments concerned do not get the information. They supply the letter and we send out copies of it for them; they do not actually see the names and addresses.
â€”Would such a letter be sent out on the letterhead of the Department of Social Security (DSS) or the letterhead of the State Department of Roads and Transport?
â€”It could be sent out on either. It is usually sent out on the State department letterhead, but it could be sent out on the DSS letterhead.

speech.speaker: Walters Sen M.S.

talk.start.para: â€”As the Department of Social Security sent out this letter with no indication that it was sent out by that Commonwealth Department or that the Department had any input into it-the only information it gives is that all queries regarding bus fares are to be directed to the State Department of Roads and Transport and gives its telephone number-the concern of the recipients of this information can be easily imagined. I am really appalled. I do not care whether the Department of Social Security sent it out or whether the Department of Roads and Transport sent it out; the point is that the recipients believe the Department of Roads and Transport sent it out because there is no indication in the letter that the information had not been supplied to the State Department of Roads and Transport.

speech.para: The Minister has obviously sent someone to find out whether his Department did send out this information. Nevertheless, I again ask why this letter does not clearly indicate to social security beneficiaries that very private information about them has not been handed over to another State department, that the State department did not actually receive that information.

speech.speaker: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

talk.start.para: â€”I do not quite agree. As Senator Walters has just acknowledged, I have sent someone to find out the details of this and as soon as I receive them I will let her know. If we took part in a mail-out, it would be normal, indeed natural, to explain to a class of people that they were eligible for a State benefit and that inquiries on the extent of that State benefit and how to go about getting it should obviously go to the State department. We would not seek to administer it, so I do not find that a problem.

speech.para: However, what Senator Walters raised in respect of there being no indication on the letter as to how the person's name had been included in the mail-out could potentially be a problem. As I understand the system, it would be normal for there to be some explanation on the letter of how it came to be sent to that person.

interject.speaker: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

talk.start.para: â€”Order! It being 12.45 p.m., I put the question:

interject.para: That the Temporary Chairman do now leave the chair and report to the Senate.
The Temporary Chairman having reported accordingly-

talk.start.para: â€”My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to the report that Australia has been `dragooned' by other Western countries into writing off almost $200m owed by Egypt for wheat sales. I ask the Minister whether he would explain what has in fact occurred in this regard. Will he, therefore, explain the circumstances of this write-off and how it is in Australia's national interests that such a write-off should occur in the light of our current economic circumstances? If this is the case, presumably Australian wheat farmers are to be in some way compensated for this loss. Would he explain to the Senate how this is going to occur?

answer.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talk.start.para: â€”It is the case that on 25 May creditor countries participating in the Paris Club, including Australia, agreed to reschedule a part of Egypt's debts in view of the difficulties faced by Egypt, particularly the effects of the Gulf crisis on the Egyptian economy. The Paris Club agreed to implement an extraordinary debt reduction equal to at least 50 per cent of the net present value of that part of Egypt's debts which were previously rescheduled in 1987.

answer.para: As a consequence, the Australian Government is obliged to reschedule eligible debts amounting to $280m over a 25-year period at a concessional interest rate that will result in an effective 50 per cent debt reduction. These debts were incurred by the Australian Government as a result of having underwritten credit sales of wheat by the Australian Wheat Board. The Australian Trade Commission and the Australian Wheat Board also have outstanding debts which will be affected by the Paris Club agreement.

The assistance given to Egypt is conditional upon Egypt attaining economic adjustment targets agreed with the International Monetary Fund. Such adjustments by Egypt will enhance its ability to meet its substantial other debts to the Australian Wheat Board which were not, of course, affected by this rescheduling.

We have participated in the Paris Club process because it does allow us to register our views. Were we to stand aside from the process, Egypt would not be able to give Australia more favourable terms than it gives to other creditor countries as this was a condition of their agreeing to provide debt relief.

Basically, in short, we were locked into a process and we have to bear the consequences of it in the way that I have described. My note says, as I have already indicated, that this is in effect an underwriting by the Australian Government. My present assumption is certainly that it is the Government and the Budget that will be bearing the pain, not the wheat farmers.

talk.start.para: â€”Mr President, I ask for clarification. The Minister talks about rescheduling and that it would amount to a 50 per cent write-off. What does that mean in current dollar terms? Is the $200m write-off in current dollar terms?

â€”The budgetary implications of the Egypt rescheduling are not completely clear at this stage as the detailed parameters of the Paris Club agreement with Egypt are still being calculated by the secretariat. But our own figuring prior to the Paris Club meeting suggested that there may be around $15m per annum payable from the Budget for the next three years-I presume that is in current dollar terms. We now expect that this may be a little bit lower than that. Thereafter, Budget payments could increase to $20m to $30m per annum and then decline progressively over the rescheduling period. My working assumption is that all of that is in current dollars. If there is any change to that, I will clarify the record later.

â€”I direct my question to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. I refer to recent media reports about improvements in shipping services being offered by the Australian National Line (ANL) in the Bass Strait trade. I ask the Minister how these relate to the Government's micro-economic reform program.

answer.speaker: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

talk.start.para: â€”Mr President, in fact, they will make a significant contribution to it. The Australian National Line has been a pacesetter in introducing innovative reforms to Australian shipping services. I was in the fortunate position of being at a welcome home ceremony, I guess it could be called, just recently in Melbourne for the latest addition to the ANL fleet, its flagship the Australian Endeavour, the largest container vessel in the Australian fleet that conducts trade directly between Australia and Asia.

answer.para: ANL was the first shipping company to introduce roll-on roll-off general cargo vessels to the Bass Strait trade in 1961. The line is still seeking further to improve services between the Australian mainland and Tasmania. ANL has done this by introducing two new high technology vessels to the trade, and I do thank Senator Sherry for raising this question because he has pursued the matter with me privately. These vessels are purpose designed and built specifically to meet the future requirements of Australian National Line's Bass Strait customers.

The Searoad Mersey is already in operation and is demonstrating the advantages of a revolutionary cargo handling system for the trade. This is based on the special use of steel pellets, or cassettes as they are called, which have the capacity to hold four 20-foot shipping containers or up to 69 tonnes of bulk commodities. The cassettes can be preloaded and positioned before the vessel arrives and then driven aboard using special hydraulic trucks.

The new system enables customers to present a range of non-homogenous cargo in a manner to suit the customer's needs while enabling ANL to deal with a diverse cargo mix without losing any of its handling efficiencies. The reduction in port time possible under the new system allows extended port coverage and will encourage further innovation in product handling.

Next month a second vessel, the Searoad Tamar, will join the Bass Strait service. These vessels are part of ANL's investment in new ships and equipment to optimise the benefits flowing from the Government's shipping and waterfront reform programs. Both vessels are being manned with the new low crew levels achievable under the shipping reform program. The Searoad Mersey has a crew level of 14. The Searoad Tamar, which is a larger vessel, is expected to have a similarly low complement. It will replace the Bass Trader, which has a crew of 25.

ANL is to be complimented for its investment in the future of Australian shipping. With these new ships, using the latest in technology and design and the low crew levels flowing from the shipping reform program, the line is delivering efficient, competitive services to customers in the Bass Strait trade.

question.speaker: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

talk.start.para: â€”My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson, who was the responsible Minister at the relevant time. I ask him whether he can yet provide an answer to my question of 16 May regarding why $968,841 was paid to Timbertech when it should have been paid to Plywood and Plastic Pty Ltd. Mr President, I seek leave to table the business name registration for Timbertech and correspondence between my colleague Senator O'Chee and the liquidator of National Associated Plywood Pty Ltd which shows that $968,841 was banked to the account of that company on 10 January 1990.

question.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: â€”I ask: will Senator Richardson now admit that not only did he pay the cheque to the wrong company but also that it never arrived in the account of Plywood and Plastic?

answer.speaker: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

talk.start.para: â€”I do not think it is a matter of my being forced to admit anything about a cheque which Senator Boswell said that I paid. Quite clearly, as I have explained before, I do not pay any cheques. The departments and not I pay the cheques. A cheque was paid to Timbertech to the amount of $968,000-odd. I have no doubt, on the basis of some documents supplied to me, that the statement that Senator Boswell was given that the cheque was banked on 10 January last year in that account, is correct. I do not find any discomfort in making those admissions.

answer.para: I did refer Senator Boswell's question to the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. I had one meeting with the Department last week to discuss it and I am awaiting a final answer from it on the detail of why and how a cheque was paid to Timbertech and what effect that actually has. By the way, I do not think it affects the Commonwealth's legal position in any way.

talk.start.para: â€”Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister has had 13 days to get an answer to that question. It is the very serious matter of an amount of $968,841 going to the wrong company. Not only is it the wrong company but also many people in Ravenshoe have missed payments because the cheque went to the wrong company. Can the Minister tell me why it was paid to the wrong company?
â€”I have nothing further to add to what I said before.

â€”My question is addressed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I refer to the proposed multifunction polis (MFP) in Adelaide. I ask the Minister: will the Federal Government accede to any requests by the Premier of South Australia, Mr John Bannon, for the Federal Government to contribute to the cost of the MFP development in Adelaide?

answer.speaker: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

talk.start.para: â€”I am not aware that the Premier, Mr Bannon, has asked for funding to contribute to MFP Adelaide apart from the funds which we have already made available as a national government. That was done on a dollar for dollar basis to fund feasibility studies under the auspices of the MFP management board. We have now received the management board's report and the Government is studying the details of it to determine future involvement of the Commonwealth Government.

answer.para: Currently the community consultation panel chaired by Mr Lansdown is undertaking its final stages of consultation with the community in Adelaide and other parts of Australia. This process will take a little longer to complete, concluding in a report to the Federal and South Australian governments in a couple of months time. One of the nine principles agreed to in the Commonwealth's agreement with all State governments about the MFP in 1987 was that it would not be financed through the provision of location-specific Commonwealth and State subsidies. Another was that the proposal would proceed to fruition only if it could attract private sector investment. These principles continue to govern the Federal Government's approach.

The report of the management board, which has just been given to the Government, does not call for direct financial support or subsidies. However, it does recommend consideration of support through the application of existing policies and programs, such as the research and development incentive and other infrastructure support. The Government will be considering its support over the next few months in the light of the board's recommendations. Any decision on Commonwealth involvement will, of course, be taking into consideration the outcome of the community consultation process. I must say that a preliminary reading of the management board report, together with discussion of it in the press and elsewhere, enhances the importance of this project as one which has to be considered very seriously by governments at State and Federal levels.

talk.start.para: â€”I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health to last year's unanimous recommendation of the working party set up by the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) on the role and requirements of acupuncture education, that acupuncture registration be expedited. Firstly, what action will the Minister be taking concerning the NHMRC health care committee's refusal to endorse the working party's recommendation and both the committee's and the full Council's continuing lack of concern for public safety in this area? Secondly, will the Government lend support to the recommendation of the working party that the registration of acupuncturists be expedited in the interests of public safety? If not, why not?

answer.speaker: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

talk.start.para: â€”In answer to Senator Powell, it might be helpful to the Senate if I record some of the stages in this process. It is true that a working party was established by the National Health and Medical Research Council, I think back in August last year, to consider issues relating to the requirements for acupuncture education in Australia.

answer.para: In November last year the Council agreed to a recommendation which supported the provision of acupuncture courses within the tertiary sector, but it decided that other recommendations, particularly a recommendation for registration of acupuncture practitioners, should be further considered by the health care committee at its next meeting. That committee did meet in late February this year and it is understood that it will recommend to the June session of the National Health and Medical Research Council that acupuncture practitioners should not be registered at this time. I understand that, in reaching this position, the health care committee was concerned that registration would not necessarily achieve improved safety and may imply recognition of the efficacy of acupuncture in treating a range of diseases not yet established by the evidence.

The National Health and Medical Research Council has not yet adopted a position on the registration of acupuncture practitioners, and I do not believe that it would be appropriate for the Government to give a direction to the Council on this matter. In any case, the issue of registration would need to be considered by each State and Territory, as the registration of health professionals is a State responsibility.

talk.start.para: â€”My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to an article in yesterday's Australian Financial Review claiming that the Government had bowed to business and legal pressure to blunt the thrust of its proposed sanctions against insider trading in financial markets? The article draws attention in particular to the decision to abandon the proposal contained in the exposure draft to reverse the onus of proof, thus forcing defendants to establish their innocence. Will the Minister inform the Senate of the reasons for the changes? Could he also assure the Senate that the changes contained in the amending Bill will be effective in prosecuting those involved in the invidious practice of insider trading?

answer.speaker: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

talk.start.para: â€”The Government certainly has not softened its approach to the problem of insider trading. In his question, Senator Beahan referred to it as `the insidious practice'. It certainly is one of those practices which disfigured and degraded the scene in companies and securities areas in Australia in the late 1980s and into 1990. I believe that the regime of penalties, for example, which will be attached to the newly-defined offence of insider trading, to be seen in the Bill to be introduced by the Attorney-General in the other place today or tomorrow, will very clearly indicate that this Government is most concerned that the Parliament, on behalf of the Australian people, should indicate that insider trading is an offence which should attract the harshest penalties to those individuals or corporations found to be involved in it.

answer.para: It is true that there was a House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs report into insider trading, and the Government indicated that it would adopt most of its recommendations. The main policy issue that arose through public exposure of the recommendations of that Committee was how far the insider trading provisions should be amended to facilitate the prosecution of persons accused of having contravened those insider trading provisions. As you would know, Mr President, this chamber has always taken a particular interest in the question of the burden of proof; reversals of onus of proof. I see Senator Austin Lewis opposite nodding sagely as a previous Chairman of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances with a particular interest in this matter.

Contrary to the recommendations of the Committee, the exposure draft provisions had reversed the onus of proof in respect of a person's knowledge that information was inside information, as it was considered that this was a matter peculiarly within the knowledge of the defendant. However, the point was made in a number of submissions on the exposure draft that the provisions went too far in lessening the basic protection given to the accused under the criminal law. Further, given the increased resources provided to law enforcement and the reported improvements in market surveillance by the Australian Stock Exchange, it was considered that a more cautious approach should be adopted at this time. Thus the exposure draft provisions have been modified to restore the onus of proof in respect of this element of the offence to the prosecution and now accords with the recommendations of the Committee in this regard. I believe that they were the unanimous recommendations of the House of Representatives Committee which, of course, included members of the Opposition. So the onus of proof will be borne by the prosecution in relation to these insider trading offences.

However, the insider trading provisions will continue to be monitored to see whether they are effective in preventing insider trading and in restoring investor confidence in the securities markets, which must remain the objective so that the securities markets can attract the investment which is required to ensure that commercial and trading life-business activity-in Australia is of such a kind that we can create the necessary wealth in the Australian community.

talk.start.para: â€”My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. I refer Senator Richardson to the cheque for $968,841 meant for the Ravenshoe sawmill, which was paid to the wrong company. I also remind Senator Richardson that on 16 May he admitted to authorising this cheque. Given that the payment was recommended in December 1989, but audited accounts for the 1988-89 year were still outstanding the following January, what financial statements did the Minister see before he approved the payment? On what basis did Senator Richardson believe the payment would benefit the Ravenshoe people when National Associated Plywood, which received the cheque, owned a mill in Kyogle? Will Senator Richardson admit that with this one payment he cost the people of Ravenshoe almost a million dollars?

â€”No, I will not admit that because that would be nonsense. When any Minister receives a recommendation from a department to make a payment, a brief is presented to the Minister as to why. On that occasion the company had requested that an advance payment be made. The Department examined that request; it had some advisers examine the request as well and decided that it ought to go ahead. That being the case, I was given a brief on it. I concurred on the basis of the information supplied to me that a payment should be made. I did not at any time agree to a payment being made to Timbertech. I agreed to the payment being made. I told Senator Boswell in answer to the last question that I talked to my former Department about this last week. I had a meeting with it on this very issue. I asked it to provide me with an answer and that answer will be here soon-I should imagine in the next few days. When it is here, I will present it to Senator O'Chee.

â€”Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In light of Senator Richardson's answer, will he now table all documents relating to the request for and approval of the payment in question? If Senator Richardson did not authorise the payment of $968,000, as he told the Senate on 16 May, is he now man enough to accept ministerial responsibility for the negligence and incompetence that have caused the suffering at Ravenshoe?
â€”Are you a man or a boy?

â€”I am going to resist all temptation. As a matter of fact, I will make no such silly admissions. I just explained to Senator O'Chee that I authorised the payment to be made. I did not authorise it to be made to Timbertech in particular. I authorised the payment to be made-Timbertech being a trading name for the company in general.
â€”Why won't you table the relevant documents?

â€”Senator Hill is not renowned for his patience but he has shown some at times. As to the tabling of documents, not just on this but on a whole lot of other requests for tabling of documents that Senator O'Chee has made, I will check with the Attorney-General's Department as to whether disclosure is a good idea-the problem being that I will not do anything to undermine the Commonwealth's legal position. To do so would be a betrayal of my duties and I just will not do it. In this saga I have sought the Attorney-General's advice on what I can and cannot table, as any Minister would do on any payment, and I shall continue to do that. I shall certainly ask the Attorney-General whether I am permitted to table any of these documents. I suspect, given the likely actions to take place over the next few months, that the answer will be no.

â€”My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. How much credence can be given to the Prime Minister's claim that he will not press for an expansion of the uranium industry at the Australian Labor Party (ALP) centenary conference in light of counter-claims reported in the Australian Financial Review on Monday, 28 May 1991 by the convenor of the Centre Left, Senator Beahan, that the issue is not dead yet? Has the Prime Minister seen the merit in the detailed arguments put by Friends of the Earth, Greenpeace and other environment and safe energy community groups, or is his changed stance merely a tactical move designed to take the heat out of this divisive issue? If the Government considers the present uranium policy illogical, when can we expect to see a new and clearer policy which will distinguish the Government's policy from that of the Opposition, which will go beyond the Opposition's policy of digging it up anyhow and the Centre Left's preferred position of digging it up carefully?

answer.speaker: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

talk.start.para: â€”I do not understand the Australian Financial Review to have a delegate at the ALP national conference. Any views expressed in the Australian Financial Review may be taken into account at the national conference, but I do not think they would be very persuasive.

answer.para: Mr President, I suppose I could ask you to rule this question out of order because it really has nothing to do with my ministerial responsibilities or the Prime Minister's responsibilities. As is well known, the ALP has a national committee of inquiry into its uranium policy. There are a number of alternative suggestions in the conclusions of that committee. They will be considered at the national conference of the Labor Party and when that conference is over, the Government will be taking into account whether any change in Government policy is necessary or not.

talk.start.para: â€”I ask a supplementary question. Can we assume from the Minister's answer that the Prime Minister's statements, whether made publicly or privately to members of Labor Caucus at certain meetings, are inconsequential?
â€”Nothing which is said by a Prime Minister is inconsequential. The real question is the weight it will have at the national conference of the ALP which will determine these matters.

â€”My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services. Has the Minister discussed or sought advice about whether the Commonwealth could further suppress free speech by banning political advertisements in the print media?
â€”I have not.

â€”I ask a supplementary question. The Minister has stated that the reason for his outrageous proposal to ban freedom of speech on radio and television is to reduce the costs of political campaigns and, thus, potential corruption. If the cost of political campaigns is not reduced-which is probable-is it not logical that the same argument would be used in the future to muzzle the print media through the corporations power?

answer.speaker: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

talk.start.para: â€”I must say, it is great to be back. I have missed the inane questions from the other side. Let me tackle the preposition that Senator Parer bases his question on.
â€”Preposition! It is `proposition'.
â€”I will also alert him as to whether I have received or sought further advice. The Government's proposals in this area, as we have stated from the start, are clear.
â€”Were you brought up in South Australia, Nick?

â€”I am sure Senator Walters had a great time yesterday without me. She should just keep quiet for a while. The Government's intentions are pretty clear. We recognise that there is a need to tackle the question of campaign costs and the relationship between political parties and the need for finance. We have done this with a two-legged approach. One, of course, is to provide for full disclosure of donations and other income and expenditure of political parties and third party organisations.

answer.para: Secondly, we recognise, as has been recognised by a number of people in our community-even Mr Howard from the other side-that disclosure in itself is not enough. He alluded to the American situation, and that is good experience that disclosure and the implementation of disclosure legislation are not sufficient to stop the sorts of problems that we, on this side, are concerned about. We have already made it very clear that an important way to do that is to regulate, to the extent of banning, paid political advertising on electronic media. In coming to that conclusion as a response available to the Government appropriate in these circumstances, the Government has taken into consideration quite a number of factors.

The other thing that astounds me from the other side of the chamber is this new found respect or concern for human rights. It has been the other side, consistently for the best part of a decade, that has opposed in this place, in the House of Representatives and out in the community time after time Government proposals to protect human rights in this country. We have tried to do that by introducing legislation. We have tried to do that by amending the Constitution. It is the Opposition that, despite its latter-day, opportunistic conversion to the Human Rights Commission, still has a policy of abolishing that very same Commission that it is invoking to support some claim to being supporters of human rights.

It does not understand the area. It has never understood the area. It has always opposed legitimate and appropriate mechanisms and responses to protect human rights even though those mechanisms and responses have sometimes come from bipartisan committees which included former Victorian Liberal premiers. Those sorts of responses have been opposed by the other side because it has absolutely no respect for human rights. If it knew about human rights, if it knew about the covenants that it is talking about and if it knew about freedom of speech, it would understand the Government's position full well.

talk.start.para: â€”My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Is it a fact that the principal reason given by Mr Greiner for holding the New South Wales election early was his Government's determination to seek a mandate to press for his proposed industrial relations legislation? Can the Minister advise what the effect of the New South Wales electorate's refusal to grant this mandate is likely to be on Federal-State industrial relations arrangements and on the prospects of the system in general?

answer.speaker: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

talk.start.para: â€”I thank Senator Childs for his question.
â€”Tell us about the Entrance result.
â€”We are going to win it. I just got a report. Do you want to put some money on it?
â€”Order! I think we have all read the New South Wales election result. I call Senator Cook.

â€”I was just waiting while the bets were put as to the outcome. This question asked me whether the above mentioned is a fact. I can say that it is true that last year major parts of the New South Wales Government's industrial relations Bill were rebuffed by the Legislative Council and that, earlier this year, the then Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Fahey, announced that he would break this Bill up into several bite size chunks and try to feed it through the upper House again.

answer.para: It is also true that late last year the New South Wales Government commenced a royal commission into the building industry, about which it was said by many commentators that it was created for the sole purpose of trying to dramatise anti-union sentiment in New South Wales and creating a climate of some crisis in the building industry.

It is also true, as a matter of fact, as anyone looking at the records of industrial disputation in Australia can see, that, on the table showing days lost through industrial disputes per 1,000 employees, New South Wales is the worst performing State in the Commonwealth and, in fact, drags the national average down because of that poor performance. Indeed, if it had performed like Labor States in the Commonwealth, the 60 per cent improvement of the Hawke period over the Fraser period would be even greater.

It is true as well, as this question implies, that Mr Greiner said before the election that he would regard this as a referendum on industrial relations and, on that basis, that he would re-present his legislation to the Legislative Council. In the event of the election, Bob Carr did not fall for it. The big election issue was not industrial relations but was, in fact, a State consumption tax. There is no doubt about what the electors of New South Wales thought about the possibility of a consumption tax. I am interested to see that, among others, Senator Knowles is now back-pedalling within the Liberal Party caucus on a consumption tax. While it is true that there was an attempt to beat up industrial relations as a political issue in New South Wales, to dramatise a period--

talk.start.para: â€”You are just a born liar.
â€”I ask for that remark to be withdrawn. It is unparliamentary.
â€”Order! I ask that the interjection be withdrawn.
â€”Mr President, I have not back-pedalled on a consumption tax. If the truth offends, I will withdraw.
â€”Do you withdraw unconditionally?
â€”I withdraw.

â€”What is true is that there was, as it turned out, a pathetic effort in New South Wales to try to turn industrial relations into an election issue and acquire a mandate for an independent Liberal government on that subject. That sits uneasily and in strange counterpoint to the fact that Mr Greiner has been a leading advocate in Australia among the State Premiers of handing over industrial relations powers to the Commonwealth. Perhaps that is because deep down he recognises our better performance in this area.

answer.para: The Commonwealth welcomes any effort by the States to clothe us with greater powers on industrial relations. The New South Wales electors are entitled to reject, as they apparently have, any cynical attempts to manipulate industrial relations. It is about time conservative parties in this country learnt that the community rejects efforts to divide them on matters of industrial relations and supports efforts as epitomised by this Government to try to bring some coherence and rationality into the field of industrial relations.

talk.start.para: â€”My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services. Is the Minister aware that presently Australia is ranked as one of only 28 countries in the world with the greatest civil liberties and political rights, as shown in the `Freedom in the World' survey 1989-90? Is he also aware that Australia is ranked among the countries with the highest freedom from control of the media? Does the Minister realise that the Government's legislation that bans all political advertising on the electronic media would downgrade Australia's standing in the world survey on government control of the media to join such countries as Argentina, Botswana, Brazil, Mexico, Paraguay, Bangladesh, China and Chile, to name but a few?

answer.speaker: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

talk.start.para: â€”In answering this question, I am reminded of a debate that was held in this place a few years ago. The then Liberal spokesman in this area made some points about international recognition of human rights. At that stage, we were discussing this Government's proposal once again to entrench in our legal structure, our political structure, the protection of human rights. That spokesman was not on his own. At the time, Senator Durack-from Senator Walters's side of the Parliament-said, `We will not join in any international covenant to bring human rights to everybody'. That is the position that those opposite have held. They have held it for such a long time. Senator Gareth Evans met that resistance when he tried to bring in constitutional changes to amend the Constitution to protect human rights.

answer.para: If we stand so high on the international level in terms of the protection of human rights, it is not because of the actions of those on Senator Walters's side of the Parliament; it is because of the consistently good work done on this side. Senator Evans, Mr Bowen and others in the legal area have strived consistently to protect those human rights, and every time it has been argued against by the Opposition. We have argued for changes to the Constitution to entrench such basic principles as the right to trial by jury or the right to vote which those opposite went out and opposed. They cannot come in here now as born-again believers in human rights and run this line on me.

I do not believe that what the Government is doing will in any way downgrade any position we have internationally. What will downgrade it is the policy of those opposite to abolish the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and their policy against human rights legislation. There is a great difference between the view on our side of Parliament and that on the other side. We have had years of introducing legislation to protect human rights. We have a respect for the mechanisms of human rights and for those who run them.

In this situation those opposite would not have had a Human Rights Commission; they would not even have talked to the Human Rights Commissioner. We have consulted with him. We are getting advice and that advice indicates that there is an obvious difference of opinion between our legal advisers and the Commission. No-one shies away from that. But, at the end of the day, the Government has made it very clear that we are acting within the advice and the advice is that we are acting within our international obligations. Senator Walters should not come in here, with her track record of filibustering to stop human rights legislation getting through this place, with a holier-than-thou attitude in this area.

talk.start.para: â€”Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. As the Minister has been so supportive of the Human Rights Commissioner, will he take his advice on this issue?

â€”I have already answered that question, as did the Prime Minister yesterday. We have consulted with the Commissioner. We believe the advice he has given to us is not accurate, is not right, and we have reached that conclusion very much on the advice of our legal advisers. I do not know how those opposite can come in here and say that they would take the advice of a particular functionary of government when they are the ones who want to abolish that person's role and abolish the Commission. They should get their lines right.

â€”Is the Minister for Industrial Relations aware of studies that strongly suggest that work practices which include a high degree of consultation between management and the work force have a positive influence on production levels? Can the Minister point to practical examples of where this is occurring in Australia at present?

answer.speaker: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

talk.start.para: â€”Last week I had the opportunity to visit Newcastle and the factory of Anderson Rea Pty Ltd, which is a heavy engineering manufacturer in this country of underground mining equipment, and launch a case study of workplace reform which the Department of Industrial Relations is conducting with this company. I must say that it is an impressive operation. It has developed a teamwork approach in the workplace and has eradicated the old `them and us' attitude. The management has committed itself to working through a workplace consultative committee which comprises representatives of the employees. That is a very effective mechanism. It has been the key to changing the workplace culture and fashioning a new culture of cooperation which is now emerging. That is freely attributed to by the management of the company.

answer.para: In 1986, this company employed 114 Australians; it now employs 170. They all produce much more now than they did then and the dramatic improvement, as I have said, is ascribed by management to the involvement of the work force in the company's operations through the consultative committee. That has meant greater job security for the workers and it has meant that they have achieved a great deal more job satisfaction.

People in this company actually look forward to going to work every day. The tradesmen in this company are able to follow a project from the drawing board through to completion. Their job satisfaction is much more elevated. They also have access to a sophisticated in-house training scheme which enables them to be promoted along career paths. The accident levels in this company have fallen to their lowest ever. A number of new processes and innovations have been introduced into production, which have arisen from the consultative approach that management has taken with its work force. There are now no more demarcation disputes and work practice problems have also been removed.

That is a quite stunning achievement, but it is best illustrated by the commercial performance of this company. In 1986, Anderson Rea had 33 per cent of the market in Australia for the manufacture of long wall mining equipment-that is, underground equipment used basically in the coalmining industry. Mitsui in Japan and Eickhoss in Germany each had 33 per cent. By 1990, through this workplace change program, Anderson Rea had secured 50 per cent of the market, the Germans 27 per cent, and the Japanese 23 per cent. The expectation of outside observers and the company itself is that by the end of this year its market share will have gone up to 56 per cent, the German's market share will have gone down to 20 per cent and the Japanese down to 24 per cent.

This is an example of a company becoming more productive, producing a better quality item, introducing more innovation into its range of products, becoming more productive per employee and being a model for workplace change-in fact, a snapshot of the sort of cultural change this Government wants to introduce across industry in Australia. I commend the company, the managers and the workers. I trust that other companies will examine their experience more closely to see what can be achieved through the accord-type structure that we have been promoting in Australia.

talk.start.para: â€”My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. In view of the recent media reports that the Prime Minister accepts the overwhelming view within the Australian Labor Party that there should be no change to the Party's three-mine uranium policy, is the Minister aware of the conclusion of the recent report by the uranium policy review committee of the Labor Party that the current uranium policy is an unsatisfactory compromise? How does he explain the apparent contradiction?

â€”I am aware of the views of the committee of inquiry. I have seen some alleged comments by the Prime Minister in the press about this issue. As far as the Government is concerned, these issues will be discussed and resolved at the national conference of the Labor Party and, if there is any change, the Government will announce that change at an appropriate time.
â€”Order! That was the second question that did not contain a great deal of ministerial responsibility.

â€”Can the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade confirm that the draft comprehensive settlement agreement for Cambodia does not exclude senior Khmer Rouge officials responsible for genocidal acts during the Pol Pot era from being elected to political office in the proposed Cambodian elections? Will the Government propose amendments to the draft agreement to ensure that those officials are identified by an international tribunal and are barred from holding political office before elections are held?

answer.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talk.start.para: â€”It is true that the Permanent Five negotiating text in its present draft form does not specifically address that issue, although as a practical issue it has been understood that Pol Pot and his most notorious associates are not proposing to stand for election. Nonetheless, it is an issue which the Australian Government believes needs to be more specifically addressed in some way in the settlement process.

answer.para: The suggestion for an international tribunal to identify Khmer Rouge leaders who should be barred from holding political office has some attractions in the abstract, but all the available evidence is that it is not an approach which is especially likely to prove practicable. It would be difficult to obtain the international agreement necessary to establish a tribunal and to have its findings accepted. It may be more practical to proceed by way of agreement, perhaps explicit in the text of the final settlement or by way of a less formal agreement on the basis that a more formal disqualification provision may not be achievable.

This is one of the issues that will be the subject of discussion between the Cambodian parties and the Paris conference co-chairmen in Jakarta next week. I am in no doubt that it is an issue that will also need to be tackled in the final round of negotiations when the Paris conference is reconvened. We are conscious of its significance. Nobody wants to contemplate a situation where any of the more notorious associates of Pol Pot were to re-emerge on the public stage. Indeed, it is reasonable to work on the assumption that the United Nations and the governments-including Australia's-that are most immediately involved in this would find it extremely difficult, to the point of impossibility, to cooperate with a process which was belittled by the presence of candidates of such notoriety.

talk.start.para: â€”My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Recently the Economic Planning Advisory Council (EPAC) released a paper entitled Competitiveness: The Policy Environment which notes the deterioration of Australia's competitiveness in recent years. It also notes the development of trading blocs and bilateral trading arrangements around the world. The Minister may recall that his Department made a contribution in that area. At the EPAC meeting at which that paper was discussed, Dr Blewett conceded that, if the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade Round failed, there would be a very real danger of growth and entrenchment of trading blocs around the world, and clearly to our detriment. Are not all our eggs in the one basket-that is, the success of the Uruguay Round? Why are we not looking at alternatives? Is there not a real chance that Australia will end up in the cold with our only trading partner being New Zealand? Should we not be commencing bilateral discussions with our neighbours-in particular, Indonesia with a population of about 180 million-so that we are not left naked if or when it finally becomes transparent that the Uruguay Round has failed?

answer.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talk.start.para: â€”I am sure at the outset I can say that we are all well aware of the urgent need to make Australia more competitive and every policy that we have been honing and putting in place in recent years has been directed at doing that in terms of domestic economic policy. The 12 March statement has made the most substantial possible contribution to that. So, too, of course, has the achievement of record low inflation figures which, in themselves, do more than any other conceivable outcome to lift our competitive game so far as domestic policy is concerned.

answer.para: The nub of Senator Lewis's question is, of course, about international trade policy. It remains our overwhelming objective to ensure multilateral international trade liberalisation. That remains overwhelmingly the desire of all the other major trading countries, including those within our own region. It is not to be assumed, accordingly, that even should the Uruguay Round-God forbid-fall in a hole again this year, there will necessarily be a headlong tumble into the creation of trading blocs, involving either the inclusion or the exclusion of Australia. There are many forces of sanity around the world that are going to be working very hard to resist that although it is, of course, going to be that much more difficult in the event that the Uruguay Round does fail and some of the instincts towards protectionism and managed trade do get a head of steam up as a result.

What we are trying to do is not only focus our attention on bringing the Uruguay Round to a successful conclusion but also to have in place a variety of other strategies both to supplement that and also to cope with a situation of potential failure. One is, of course, within our own region. The Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) process should not be regarded as the prelude to some kind of trade bloc in the future but rather as a trade group which is strongly competitive and directed to freeing up the total international system.

One of the things that we are actively looking at within the APEC process at the moment is non-discriminatory regional trade liberalisation as a strategy separate and distinct from the Uruguay Round, which is focused in the first instance on the region, which includes both sides of the Pacific and which is designed to focus on particular areas where there are many trade restrictions within this area at the moment which desirably ought to be reduced and which sensibly could be reduced on a non-discriminatory basis but in such a way that the benefits would flow in the first instance to the region. This is a sophisticated strategy which is in the early stages of development. It is very actively being pursued within the APEC group at the moment and will be the subject of more detailed attention at the full ministerial level meeting in October.

The suggestion that we are somehow neglecting bilateral trade relations while all this other multilateral activity is going on is completely ill-founded. We are extremely conscious of not only the market opportunities in the more traditional European and North American environments but, of course, the market opportunities that are dramatically opening up in our own region and conspicuously so in Indonesia. I have lost count of the number of times that I have spoken to business audiences in Australia about the potential that Indonesia in particular represents with 180 million people and already a middle class of some 10 million people but, more importantly than that, an emerging economic environment which is not only effective so far as macro-management is concerned but is increasingly becoming very much more attractive so far as micro-regulation is concerned-the removal of licensing and other restrictions which have traditionally been a major inhibitor to investment and other activity by Australian business.

That is overwhelmingly obviously the area in which we ought to be focusing our attention.
