Austrade, in its new post-McKinsey strategy, is much more alertly focused on that in terms of bilateral intergovernmental negotiations to further smooth the way for entrepreneurial activity in this respect. We are being very active indeed.

talk.start.para: â€”I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to recent speculation concerning possible foreign policy changes that may be occurring in the Democratic People's Republic of Korea (DPRK). I ask: what is Australia's attitude to the announcement from Pyongyang that the DPRK is to seek membership of the United Nations (UN)? What criteria are employed by Australia in forming a view on such an application for the DPRK to join the international community in a formal way?

answer.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talk.start.para: â€”The news of the past 24 hours that North Korea, the DPRK, is now going to seek membership of the United Nations is very positive, very important, and very welcome news. Australia strongly supports universal state membership of the United Nations. We strongly support, as a result, this move by the DPRK to end its long period of relative international isolation and to join the United Nations.

answer.para: This is not to be seen necessarily as barring ultimate reunification of the two Koreas. It remains an objective that they both in their different ways share, and it may take a long time to achieve. In the meantime, they are operating effectively and, of course, have been for many years, as two separate nations. It is entirely appropriate that universal membership including them both be achieved.

The other dimension of this news that is important and welcome is that it should help acceptance of the formal application of South Korea, the Republic of Korea (ROK), to join the United Nations, which formal application is expected later this year. Membership of the United Nations of both the DPRK and the ROK should also contribute in its own way to easing security concerns on the Korean peninsula. This would be very welcome not only to Australia but to the whole region.

It is worth making the point finally, and just reinforcing the one I made earlier about assisting the application of the ROK, that applications from countries seeking to join the UN do require the support of nine members of the Security Council, with no veto by any of the Permanent Five, and the support also being required of two-thirds of the members of the General Assembly. There has been some fear that China would have vetoed, although it was manifestly reconsidering its position in recent months, an application by the ROK. Now that the DPRK-North Korea-has joined in, it does seem effectively beyond doubt that the applications of both of those countries will now go through. That is a very salutary result indeed.

question.speaker: Vanstone Sen A.E.

talk.start.para: â€”My question is addressed to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs both in that capacity and as Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. I refer him to a report in the Australian of 8 April 1991 headed `Statistics hide extent of child sex abuse by women' which contains, among other things, the allegation:

question.para: . . . certain women's refuges had become known as centres of child abuse but little had ever been done about them.

Given the funding through the Department of Community Services and Health for women's shelters and the Government's attitude to abuse of women and children, and given that these shelters should be where women and children can get what they seek, namely, refuge from such abuse, will the Minister tell the Senate what action his Government has taken to ascertain the veracity of this allegation? Will the Minister also indicate what level of concern his Government has about the number of allegations of sexual abuse against children that are made, not when the parents are living together but rather when custody or access of children in a separation is contested by the father?

answer.speaker: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

talk.start.para: â€”There is no doubt that abuse of children, whether it be physical violence or sexual abuse, or a combination of both, which would be particularly horrific, is a matter of great concern in our Australian community. I think it is fair to say that there is more awareness of the terrible deeds that are done by adults and perhaps those of teenage years against younger children in our community in this regard, although I am unable to say whether the practice has increased. There is certainly an awareness in the community that was not prevalent some years ago.

answer.para: Indeed, it is a fact, as Senator Vanstone has indicated, that violence against children is one of the underlying causes of violence throughout the community and as expressed by those children as they move into their adult years. This was a finding of the National Committee on Violence in its report entitled Violence: Directions for Australia which indicated that the household, the home, which should be a refuge and haven from violence, was a place where children experience violence-`became a training ground for aggression' was the expression used in that report. Of course, that has implications for their development as human beings, and their non-violent relationships, which they should enter into with other human beings, become impaired, and resort to violence is something that they see as part of the normal upbringing and way of relating of human beings.

As far as sexual abuse is concerned, that is a particularly degrading form of abuse of children. It quite often impairs the ability of those children themselves to enter into reasonable and happy sexual relationships as they move into adult life. It is therefore something with which the whole community ought be greatly concerned-not only the Federal Government but also State governments within whose criminal jurisdictions such activity naturally falls and which also, I would imagine, would have an interest in the registration and the setting up of the refuges which Senator Vanstone referred to, which indeed should be refuges and not places where this abuse does occur.

I am unable at the moment to say whether any particular action has been taken to follow up that newspaper report in relation to these terrible allegations. I will seek information from the Minister as to whether the Department is aware, as a result of its funding contribution, of the failure to adopt the highest practices in relation to the protection of children in these refuges and will provide Senator Vanstone with an answer as soon as possible.

talk.start.para: â€”Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for that answer, which is obviously adequate in relation to the first question. As I understand what the Minister said, he is not sure whether anything has been done to ascertain the veracity of that report but will make inquiries and report back to this chamber. Can the Minister answer the second part of the question, which asks about the level of concern that his Government has about the number of allegations of sexual abuse against children that are made not when the parents are together but rather when custody or access of children in a separation is contested by the father? Is the Government concerned that there may be an unusually high proportion of allegations being made in those situations rather than across the board? Is that indicative of those sorts of allegations being misused?

â€”I am not myself aware of the extent of such allegations or whether they have been recorded in a way which would be helpful to understand the phenomenon throughout the Australian community. No doubt some assistance could be gained from the Family Court of Australia and its counsellors and the records of that court in relation to applications that are made, for example, to vary custody and access arrangements on the basis of an allegation of abuse having been suffered by the children who are enjoying the access-or having the access, I should say, because they are certainly not enjoying it if they are being abused. Perhaps the best thing I can do, Mr President, is to ask the Department to see whether the Family Court of Australia or any other agency has some information which would bear on the question that Senator Vanstone has asked.
â€”Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

â€”In the answers that I gave to Senators Boswell and O'Chee today, I outlined to them the normal processes that would be involved in a Minister authorising a payment. I did so because I am always prepared to accept responsibility when it is due. However, the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories confirmed in my office during Question Time that I was not informed of that payment to the company or that the payment was being made at all before it was made. The payments were made simply as a result of the agreement which I had signed originally. It is just as well that I did not accede to Senator O'Chee's blandishments and make all sorts of admissions that would have been completely untrue.
â€”I thought you said the other day you--
â€”I just read the answer I gave the other day. Senator Hill ought to have a good look at it.

answer.speaker: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

talk.start.para: â€”Senator Coulter yesterday asked me a question as the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories concerning a recent Army exercise at Jervis Bay. I answered the question in part and undertook to seek further information from the Minister. I am now able to provide that additional information. Following my response yesterday, the honourable senator has claimed that I misled the Senate. He alleges that I claimed that the Army exercise at Jervis Bay was confined to Murrays Beach on the south side of the Bay. The Hansard shows that I did not make such a claim. I gave Senator Coulter the information I had and undertook to get further information.

answer.para: Yesterday I dealt specifically with that part of the Army exercise which was conducted at Murrays Beach in the Jervis Bay Territory, where the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories has responsibility and in respect of which he gave approval. The Army exercise was also conducted on Beecroft Peninsula on the northern side of the bay, but outside the Jervis Bay Territory. This is Commonwealth-owned land which is managed and controlled by the Department of Defence.

I am advised that Defence did do some temporary environmental damage on Beecroft Peninsula. I am also advised that no trees were cut down and no new tracks were bulldozed. The extent of the damage or whether the exercise on Beecroft Peninsular was called off as a result are matters which should be directed to the Minister for Defence.

It was up to the Defence Department, in the case of Beecroft, to trigger the Environment Assessment (Impact of Propo- sals) Act and to refer information to the Australian Heritage Commission so that it can give consideration under section 30 of its Act. The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories cannot trigger the Act.

The Defence Department is not obliged to trigger the Act or refer the matter to the Heritage Commission if it considers that the action proposed will have no significant effect on the National Estate. In the case of Beecroft, the Act was not triggered nor the matter referred to the Heritage Commission. Therefore, the environment Minister was not formally involved in the defence activities on Beecroft Peninsula.

I am advised that the Minister for the environment has now asked the Australian Heritage Commission to develop a memorandum of understanding with the Department of Defence to determine the types of activities which should be referred to the Commission. I am also advised that the Department of Defence has now agreed to this process.

I inform the honourable senator that the draft management strategy plan of the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, to which he referred, concerns only the Jervis Bay Territory and does not embrace Beecroft Peninsula. The draft plan includes among its important objectives the conservation of the environmental values of the Territory which will be set out in the draft management plan for the Jervis Bay Territory nature reserve, to be released for public comment later in 1991.

In answer to the honourable senator's question about the Government's commitment to the protection of the environment at Jervis Bay, I am advised that the declaration of a marine park is a high priority. The Commonwealth has approached New South Wales in an endeavour to achieve a joint Commonwealth-State declaration of a Jervis Bay marine park.

question.block.title: FUNDING OF HOSPITALS IN WESTERN AUSTRALIA

answer.speaker: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

talk.start.para: â€”Yesterday Senator Knowles asked me in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health a question concerning Federal funding of Western Australian hospitals. I have received an answer from the Minister and have provided that answer to Senator Knowles. I seek leave to have the answer incorporated in Hansard.

answer.para: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-

The current public hospital funding arrangements, including the formula for distribution to the States and Territories, were discussed by Health Ministers and accepted at the 1988 Premiers' Conference. The arrangements apply to the period 1988-89 to 1992-93.

It is incorrect to say that Commonwealth funding has declined. In 1988-89, the first year of the current arrangements, the Commonwealth hospital funding grant amounted to $273.7 million, in 1990-91 it will be in the vicinity of $325.2 million and estimated to be $373.4 million in 1992-93, the last year of the arrangements.

Commonwealth funds for hospitals are distributed annually to the States and Territories on a per capita basis, weighted according to age and sex population profiles, to take account of the greater than average need of hospital services by aged persons and women. This method of distribution was developed by the Commonwealth as a means of ensuring equity in funding between the States and Territories.
Therefore it is inappropriate to make comparisons on a straight per capita basis of levels of hospital funding between States and Territories.

I should also point out that the hospital funding grants are included in the general distribution of Commonwealth monies to States through the Financial Assistance Grants. This latter process is undertaken annually at the Premiers' Conference and reflects the fiscal equalisation principles proposed by the Grants Commission and adopted by Premiers at the 1988 Conference.

answer.speaker: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

talk.start.para: â€”Yesterday in Question Time Senator Panizza asked me a question in relation to the accident involving a Mitsubishi MU2 aircraft at Meekatharra. I provided Senator Panizza with my recollections of that incident. The Bureau of Air Safety Investigation has now provided me with a detailed response to Senator Panizza's question which, because of its length, I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard.

answer.para: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-

First, I would like to correct a comment I made yesterday, regarding the restriction of the MU-2 aircraft to the carriage of freight. I have been subsequently advised that although the bulk of MU-2 operations involves the carriage of freight, there is not a restriction on the carriage of passengers.
In relation to the coroner's report, I am advised that the coroner was unable to come to any firm conclusion as to the cause of the accident, but did identify three contributory factors, namely:
- inadequate training and the captain's inexperience on the MU-2
- ice accretion on the aircraft
- lack of adequate warning devices on the MU-2.
The coroner was critical of the time taken by the CAA to impose additional training and experience for MU-2 pilots.

Following an MU-2 accident in December 1988, the CAA sought information from overseas authorities and the MU-2 operators in an attempt to identify any special training or operational requirements. This approach culminated in a conference, delayed by the pilots' dispute, involving CAA, BASI and industry representatives on 28 November 1989 and an article reporting the conference was published in civil aviation news in January 1990.
Although agreement on training requirements was not reached at the conference, a number of detailed requirements on pilots were imposed in January 1990 immediately following the Meekatharra accident.

The coroner was concerned that BASI and the CAA having an `interest' in the matter, were not truly independent advisers to the coroner. There is no doubting that BASI and CAA do have a vested interest in the outcome of any accident in determining the truth and that all coroners can expect support from both organisations and receive unbiased, factual evidence. It is clearly not unusual for the CAA to brief legal counsel.
The coroner's suggestion that ice-detection devices be installed is being reviewed by the CAA in consultation with the original certificating authority.

A final comment made by the coroner was that the interview techniques of two CAA staff were somewhat ``inexpert'' and the CAA has accepted this and is addressing the problem through its training processes.

The CAA has noted that while the captain was not subject to the additional training now required on the aircraft, that he was more aware than most of the characteristics of the aircraft having been deeply involved as the superintendent of the BASI Perth Field Office, in the investigation of a MU-2 accident in December 1988.
The CAA agrees that ice accretion was probably a contributing factor.

On the third factor, the CAA has advised that the aircraft does not have ice warning devices, but is certificated for flight in icing conditions, and does have anti-icing equipment. This is an issue to which the CAA is giving further consideration.
The coroner also made some other comments in relation to his findings including that covered in Senator Panizza's question yesterday.

The coroner suggests that this particular MU-2 (VH-MUA) got through the safety net as it had inadequate repairs of previous damage sustained overseas. The CAA has advised that the repair was assessed when this aircraft was brought into Australia and it was determined that the repair was adequate and the aircraft airworthy. A more detailed inspection would have required the repair to be dismantled and there were no indications to warrant such action.

The coroner was also critical of one element of the industry for recording completed inspections which had not been done, leading to a recommendation that the CAA should scrutinise more closely the work practices of such organisations. Since the time of the accident the CAA has introduced the national surveillance system which improves the CAA's surveillance of the industry.

LIBERALS CALL FOR TAX DETAILS
By MICHELLE GRATTAN
Canberra
The Opposition Leader, Dr Hewson, came under backbench pressure yesterday to release early the coalition's detailed policy on consumption tax.

talk.start.para: â€”Of the major problems posed by the Government's regulations, the most complex is the issue of retro- spectivity. It rises because of the uncertainty surrounding the law relevant to the offence of possessing a prohibited import of the type prescribed by the regulations. It has been argued, for example, by the New South Wales Minister for Police and Emergency Services, Mr Pickering, that the regulations could apply to firearms which were legally imported prior to the commencement of the regulations, although the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) has argued that the regulations will not have any retrospective operation.

speech.para: The shadow Attorney-General, Mr Peacock, has had some correspondence with the Minister for Justice on the question of the retrospective operation of the amended regulations. It appears that the advice of the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) is that the regulations will not have any retrospective effect. Initially, this advice relied heavily on the provisions of section 48(2) of the Acts Interpretation Act which reflect the well-established presumption that legislation is not intended to have a retrospective operation.

After a query from Mr Peacock about this advice, the Government obtained further counsel advice from the Federal Chief General Counsel. Differing opinions have been provided by the Crown Solicitor for New South Wales and the Federal Chief General Counsel. I am referring to that advice of the Chief General Counsel as the Minister's office has foreshadowed that it may be tabled, and he has provided a copy of it to Mr Peacock.

The State Crown Solicitor's Office of the New South Wales Government has advised that the regulations may have retrospective effect. As I said, the Federal Chief General Counsel has offered conflicting advice. The issue is whether possession of goods which fall within the description of prohibited imports given by the amended regulations constitute an offence for the purpose of the Act, notwithstanding the fact that, at the time such goods were imported prior to the commencement of the amended regulations, they were permissible imports.

The relevant legislation is the Customs Act 1901. Section 51 of that Act provides that goods, the importation of which is prohibited under section 50, are prohibited imports. Paragraph 233 (1) (d) provides that a person shall not unlawfully convey or have in his possession any prohibited imports and, under subsection 233 (2) it is unlawful for any person to convey or have in his possession without reasonable excuse, proof whereof shall lie upon him, any smuggled goods or prohibited imports.

It is arguable that the combination of these sections effectively prohibits the possession of goods of any kind whose importation is prohibited under section 50 whether or not they have actually been imported. The Crown Solicitor for New South Wales concludes that section 233 (1) (d) and section 233 (2) of the Act can apply to prohibit possession of goods which are prohibited imports, irrespective of the place where the person in possession is found, the time of such possession in relation to the importation and the method of purchase of the goods. Whether it is an offence to possess a prohibited import where, at the time of importation, such goods were permissible imports will depend upon whether the provisions of paragraph 233 (1) (d) and subsection 233 (2) can be construed as excluding the general presumption against retrospectivity.

The courts have not being called upon to decide the meaning of prohibited imports within the context of the possession offences in paragraph 233 (1) (d) and subsection 233 (2). However, relevant comments have been made in related contexts. In the case of R v. Bull, 1971, 131 CLR at page 203, the High Court considered the expression `prohibited imports'. It was held that goods, the importation of which is prohibited by the Act, are prohibited imports regardless of their location and whether or not at the time they were so designated they have been wrongfully introduced into Australia. Mr Justice Stephen said:

Goods the importation of which is so prohibited, by virtue of section 51, are prohibited imports and will, in my view, be so regardless of their location and whether or not they have already wrongfully been introduced into Australia.

The phrase `prohibited imports' was again considered by the High Court in Milicevik v. Campbell, 1975, 132 CLR at page 307. It was held by the majority of the High Court that prohibited imports within the meaning of the relevant section are goods, the importation of which has been prohibited whether or not they have been imported.

The courts have not yet had to consider a factual situation involving the possession of goods which were imported at a time when it was lawful to do so but, subsequent to importation, such goods have been prescribed as prohibited imports. Accordingly, the passages to which I have referred are admittedly by way of obiter.

The Chief General Counsel dismisses these arrangements on the grounds that the courts would read down the provisions to restrict their application, firstly, to goods which have actually been imported and, secondly, to goods which, at the time of importation, have actually been designated as prohibited imports. However, I point out that this makes the assumption that the courts will so read down the provisions. Even if the assumption is correct, this still shows that the state of the law is somewhat uncertain. It would seem that the law relating to the possession of prohibited imports is therefore very uncertain. Although the position is by no means clear, the following propositions can be extracted from the case law.

Firstly, textual considerations of the drafting of the Act suggest that importation may not be a necessary element for an offence of possessing prohibited imports. Such a conclusion is also supported by the policy rationale behind the offences, namely, to remove such goods from the Australian community in the event that they pass the importation barrier.

Secondly, for these particular provisions in the Act to be constitutionally valid, as the Chief General Counsel intimates, it may be that they should be interpreted as applying to goods of overseas origin which have been imported. This interpretation, however, is at odds with the plain meaning that can be accorded to the provisions.

Thirdly, even if importation is a requisite element of the offence of possession of prohibited imports, it may not be necessary that at the time of the importation they be designated as prohibited imports. Textual and policy considerations tend to suggest that the presumption against retrospectivity has been rebutted. Whether it has in fact been rebutted will depend on the facts of any individual case, after balancing the injustice done to the individual concerned against the presumed intention of the legislature, as reflected in the policy rationale behind the provisions.

The Opposition believes that this uncertainty should be resolved and the matter put beyond doubt by the inclusion of an express statement making it clear that the regulations will not have any retrospective effect. The issue has been the subject of a great deal of debate and correspondence, yet the Minister refuses to concede that there may be a problem. It is ironic that all this debate and discussion is in a sense needless, as the matter is very simply resolved by the inclusion of a short paragraph in the regulations to make it clear that they are not intended to have retrospective effect. The Opposition has proposed, in the alternative regulations which I have had incorporated, a simple amendment to clause 1.2 which removes this ambiguity.

The second major issue is of vital importance to sporting shooters in Australia. At a meeting in November 1990, the Police Ministers Council, with the exception of New South Wales, approved a statement about the importation of firearms. The statement provided that it would be lawful to import rifles and shotguns for competitive use in shooting competitions endorsed by certain recognised organisations such as the Sporting Shooters Association of Australia Inc. The regulations, in contrast to the police Ministers' statement, do not make provision for allowing the importation of firearms for competitive use. The regulations do, however, provide that competitors from other countries may bring in such firearms. This may disadvantage Australian sporting shooters and may well have a detrimental impact on the viability of Australia hosting international sporting competitions. In turn, this may impede the development of the shooting as a legitimate and internationally recognised competitive sport.

The National Rifle Association of Australia points out that a great percentage of its members use military-style rifles for the purpose of competition shooting and have done since the inception of the rifle clubs over 100 years ago. It is inevitable that confusion will arise. In fact, it has already arisen. For example, in September last year, the Sporting Shooters Association of Australia sought the advice of the Minister for Small Business and Customs, Mr Beddall, as to whether an import permit was required for the importation of an AR15 semi-automatic rifle. Mr Beddall consulted the Australian Federal Police, on whom the Australian Customs Service depends for expert advice on firearms. They confirmed that the AR15 is a semi-automatic sporting rifle and that therefore an import permit is not required.

Earlier this month the Sporting Shooters Association sought the clarification of the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs about the import of three specified firearms: the Colt Delta H-Bar target rifle, the Colt Sporter Match H-Bar heavy barrel target rifle, and the Springfield Armoury MIA National and Super Match rifles. The Association was advised that all three firearms are prohibited imports because they substantially duplicate military firearms in design, function or appearance.

The irony is that the first two rifles mentioned-the Colt Delta H-bar target rifle and the Colt Sporter Match H-bar heavy barrel target rifle-are target versions of the AR15 which the Australian Federal Police and the Minister for Small Business and Customs say is a sporting rifle. Yet this confusion need not arise; it can easily be avoided by the inclusion of provisions such as those contained in the alternative regulations that we have produced and had incorporated. They make it clear that firearms which are to be imported for the sole purpose of use in lawful competition may be imported, notwithstanding the fact that they bear similarities to military firearms.

The Australian Democrats have raised the concern that the proposed exemption may be unworkable in the sense that, once imported, a firearm imported for competition could then be sold to a third party, who may then use it for other purposes. However, the problem may be overcome by the general law relating to the possession of prohibited imports. Under the exemption the firearm can be imported only on the condition that it is used in lawful sporting competition. If that condition is subsequently breached by a third party purchaser, the firearm would then assume prohibited import status.

The Opposition is also concerned that the regulations may have an unwarranted adverse effect on legitimate collectors of firearms as military paraphernalia. Once again, this point is addressed in the Opposition's alternative regulations which provide for the importation of firearms where the sole purpose of the importation is arms and military collection.

Finally, in our discussions with shooting organisations it became clear that, despite protestations to the contrary, the Government has not undertaken adequate consultations to ensure that the views of shooters were properly taken into account in the formulation of these regulations. In contrast, the Opposition has consulted and corresponded widely with a wide range of organisations about our alternative regulations. These organisations include: the National Rifle Association of Australia, the Arms and Militaria Collectors Association of New South Wales, the BHP Rifle Club Inc., the Firearms Safety Foundation Ltd, the Shooting Sports Council of Victoria, the Sporting Shooters Association of Australia, the Armoury, the Australian Shooting Association Inc., the New South Wales Rifle Association and Movie Ordnance Queensland Pty Ltd.

I wish to emphasise that the Opposition's proposed amendments are not intended to be inclusive. Other matters which merit further consideration have not been addressed completely in view of the time available and the restricted resources. For example, some issues would not become apparent in the absence of consultation with certain organisations. The Arms Collectors Guild of Queensland has brought to our attention its belief that the regulations are causing great difficulties to the film industry which is unable to import weapons props. This organisation works regularly with the overseas film industry and it reports that several proposed television series and films have not been proceeded with in Australia because of the problems with firearms importation. The organisation feels that the amended regulations will further hamper future film plans.

Another company, Movie Ordnance Queensland, is the largest and longest established movie and film firearms hire business in Queensland. It is the supplier for the new Movieworld theme park on the Gold Coast. For several years it has been making representations to various Ministers regarding the prohibition upon the importation of restricted firearms for its blank fire conversions and application in movies and films. Under the existing regulations, it cannot import any pistol group firearms and any machine-gun, submachine-gun or the like or any military self-loading rifle. As it points out, considering the improving viability of the film industry here, the inability to obtain certain types of firearms, required by production works, works against the industry in Australia. The importation of parts and accessories for many of the firearms already held in stock would also be prohibited, which means that they cannot be serviced or repaired. All this reinforces the point that the full ramifications of the Government's regulations have not been thought through.

The Opposition has given most serious consideration to the many matters raised by these regulations. Having consulted widely with the groups that will be needlessly adversely affected by the passage into law of these regulations, we have reluctantly come to the view that the only course of action open to us is to move for their disallowance. We could not move for amendment because of the fact that they are regulations. We are limited to disallowance and putting an alternative and better set of regulations to the Government, which is the course of action that we have adopted.

We hope that the alternative regulations laid on the table and now incorporated will serve to show the Government that it is possible to produce legislation which not only serves the desired purpose of restricting the importation of firearms but also does so in a way which takes into account the individual rights of all those who will be affected. We hope that the Australian Democrats, who will ultimately decide on this issue, as I understand that the Government is not prepared to consider it further, will be convinced by what I would respectfully submit to them are very persuasive arguments.

speech.speaker: Bourne Sen V.

talk.start.para: â€”The Australian Democrats agree that these regulations are not problem-free. I am sure the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) will also agree with that in a moment. We have discussed the regulations with those affected and with all those concerned in this chamber. We understand that the Minister will foreshadow amendments that the Government will be making to the regulations.

speech.para: I am pleased that in a number of important areas the Minister's office has agreed that the regulations were faulty and that amendments would need to be made. As the Senate is aware, these regulations have their origins in last year's Police Ministers Council meeting where the Commonwealth and all States agreed to adopt new restrictions on the importation of firearms into Australia. Understandably, there was some general agreement that new regulations were necessary to tighten up the area of firearm importation into this country. In many ways this reflects increasing community concern over the spread of firearms and of firearm use in Australia.

The Democrats share those concerns and endorse attempts at the government level to improve regulatory control over firearm importation, which these regulations attempt to carry out. However, the Democrats also accept that the Government has a responsibility to introduce regulations that are fair and which do not have an unnecessarily adverse impact on any one sector of the community. With this in mind, we were initially concerned about several aspects of these regulations. I know that the Minister intends to address these concerns in the debate today.

For instance, the Opposition has already claimed that the regulations carry an element of retrospectivity. However, it is my understanding that the Chief General Counsel of the Attorney-General's Department, in considering this precise matter, has provided an opinion that the regulations carry no retrospectivity whatsoever. I thank the Minister's office for providing me with a copy of that advice in which the Chief General Counsel quite clearly states that there is no retrospective element contained within the regulations. I understand that the Minister will be tabling that advice in the Senate today.

The second matter that most concerned the Democrats was the possible adverse impact which these regulations may have had on genuine sporting level competition in this country. A number of sporting shooters associations have approached my office in recent months to argue that these regulations would unfairly restrict a range of firearms currently used in sporting level competition. Certainly it would be unjust for these regulations to ban the importation of Olympic-style firearms, especially those firearms which are used at top level sporting competitions in the country. The Democrats were concerned to find that the regulations made no provision for allowing the importation of firearms for competitive use in sporting level competitions.

Australia is a top level nation in this sport and the regulations may well have had an adverse impact on the sport by preventing the importation of these firearms. The Democrats have made it clear that we would not accept the regulations if they did not contain exemptions for those firearms used at this level of competition. I am pleased to say that the Minister has given us an assurance that these regulations will be amended to contain such exemptions. I understand that these changes will be presented to the Parliament within the next few weeks.

I look forward to these amendments as I am sure do a number of sporting shooters associations. I commend the Government for the good sense that it has shown in agreeing to amend the regulations when they contained such an obvious flaw. I ask the Minister to table the documents that he said he will. I ask him to stand by the assurances that he has also given to me in private. Under those circumstances, the Democrats will not be supporting the Opposition's disallowance motion.

speech.speaker: Vallentine Sen J.

talk.start.para: â€”I will not be supporting the Opposition's disallowance motion. I would certainly support stronger and stricter guidelines being imposed on such imports as firearms. As a principle, I, too, am opposed in general to any element of retrospectivity. I am pleased to hear that the advice of the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) deals with that issue.

speech.para: I suspect that the Opposition's disallowance motion is largely fuelled by the gun lobby in Australia and Senator Hill quoted various shooting organisations, which bears that out. I do not believe that shooting is an activity that we want to promote. I certainly do not want to promote it at any level in any way in the Australian community. As we know, guns get into the wrong hands. They can lead to violence in the community. There are many examples-and I do not need to document them here-of people amassing a whole arsenal of weapons and then using them in a very detrimental fashion as far as the community is concerned. So I think the tighter the regulations are, the better.

Shooting is hardly a sporting activity when we consider the real meaning of the word. Killing of any sort should not be seen as enjoyable. I cannot agree with the notion that we should encourage young people to get involved in this sport as though it is something laudable and enjoyable.

I would not even want to encourage the collecting of military paraphernalia either-and this is another issue that Senator Hill addressed. Such an activity legitimises the notion that violence is acceptable, that war is acceptable, that war games and war paraphernalia can be fun. That is not the climate in which I want to raise my children. Of course, it is a different matter to say that we should ban these things altogether. That is not what the regulations are doing. But I think a tightening up of the regulations could certainly be in order.

The Sporting Shooters Association of Australia, which is one of the bodies that Senator Hill quoted, indicated at its 1988 gun lobby conference some very worrying trends. At a training workshop it was concerned about how to get training into schools. A whole section was devoted to that. It was concerned about how to get young people in Australia to deal with and to learn about weapons. It was concerned with ways in which to get young people excited about firearms. In its 1988 training workshop manual, the Association said:
Pupils should be reached as early as possible-both primary and post-primary education should be considered . . .
Some work has been done on a primary school program in South Australia and the SSAA has a program in preparation.
It is very obvious that this is what the Association is trying to do.
In the Sporting Shooter of July 1989, Ray Galea wrote:

Personally, I recommend to start children at the earliest age by letting them handle toy guns. A responsible parent must take the time to show the child shooting stances, aiming and trigger techniques . . .

If a child starts with a toy gun, safe-handling becomes a natural instinct. Mind you, these toys are difficult to find in children's gift stores these days because of a conspiracy to discourage young people from participating in gun sports.
Well, hear, hear, I say to that. He continued:

We must not allow national anti-gun schemers achieve their objectives, otherwise future generations of Australians will never lay their hands on sporting firearms. Our sole responsibility is to teach our youth about guns and related subjects.
Really, if that is the aim of that organisation, I do not want to have anything to do with promoting that kind of activity. Further on in the same article, he stated:
Shooters Paradise, an indoor riffle range at Penrith, NSW, have developed programs to enhance shooting skills of young people aged between 10 and 18.

What kinds of attitudes is that activity engendering in our young people? We are being told that violence is okay, it is acceptable and it is fun. Well, it is not acceptable to a large percentage of the Australian community. He went on to say:
The future of the sport depends on our youth!
The tone is positively evangelical. Religious zeal seems to be employed.

The whole emphasis in an article in the August 1990 edition of the same magazine, written by Gerard McKie and entitled `Teach 'Em Young', was to get children at a young age to handle and become familiar and friendly with firearms. The President of the Sporting Shooters Association, Keith Tidswell, launched the most aggressive membership drive known to the organisation after a trip that he had made to the United States of America where he learnt, no doubt, lots of tricks of the trade from the powerful gun lobby in that country. He would have learned there something that will be very damaging to community attitudes in terms of what the various police Ministers around Australia are trying to do in respect of regulating and reducing the number of firearms in Australian homes and communities.

The adherence by citizens of the United States to their constitutional right to bear arms results in gross homicide figures mainly involving the use of guns in domestic situations. I do not believe that we want to follow the United States example. Yet, here we have the national President of the Sporting Shooters Association of Australia learning lots of tricks of the trade from the extremely powerful gun lobby in the United States. The Association is obviously trying to replicate that situation in this country. I do not think it should get any support whatsoever. The Association should be very carefully watched.
The Firearms Safety Foundation Ltd is another organisation that has sprung up to do exactly the same sort of thing. I would like to quote from one of the Foundation's promotional pamphlets:

The Firearms Safety Foundation Limited was established in 1988 to act as a funding body to various groups which were being organised around Australia because of the actions of anti-gun lobbyists. The original Foundation members, made up of several major importers and dealers-
of course, this is where the other sinister part comes in: the main objective of people is to make money out of this very negative so-called sport and entertainment industry-
quietly funded many fighting councils during their various struggles as law makers and politicians enacted changes in gun legislation.

One of the Foundation's major activities `will include education of children through the Education Departments'. I think Ministers of education in every State need to take a personal responsibility to ensure that this promotion of gun shooting and gun toting does not get a foothold in our schools. It is not the kind of activity that we want to engender.

In 1990, after the outrageous displays of community violence in the streets of Melbourne-the Hoddle Street massacre, the Russell Street shooting and so on are examples of the misuse to which firearms can be put if they are not very strictly regulated; and even if they are, this could still happen-the Minister for Police and Emergency Services, Mal Sandon, said that we should be:
Looking to the training of future shooters, there are more than 250 schools which have shooting as part of their sports program . . . .
I urge you to join a shooting club where you can improve your knowledge, understanding and enjoyment of firearms.

This is what was written by the Minister for Police and Emergency Services. I challenge the whole ethos of promoting the use of firearms in our schools as being something enjoyable. It is just totally unacceptable on that ground alone.

Let us also look at the unacceptability of firearms on environmental grounds. The Sporting Shooters Association claims in some of its material that it is protecting the wildlife of Australia. This is a totally absurd situation. I would agree that it would be a sensible proposition if we are really concerned about the need to eliminate feral animals on environmental grounds. But this is a job that should be carried out under strict control by the departments of conservation and land management. It should not be left to so-called sporting shooters gun toting in the wild. If such people were allowed to shoot feral animals, they would also be responsible for environmental damage and they probably would take out a lot of native habitat species as well.

I want to quote figures provided by Wildlife Rescue in Victoria for just one episode of the duck hunting season in 1990. Animal welfare groups collected a total of 373 protected birds that were killed by duck shooters during the duck season-this would have been a minuscule part of the damage that was done-and the Department of Conservation, Forests and Lands collected a total of 69 protected birds.

A couple of issues arise from that. One is that duck shooters do not shoot only ducks. They shoot whatever moves. They are not very careful in their aiming. Maybe that is deliberate, maybe it is accidental. I do not know. Whether it is accidental or deliberate, the fact remains that many protected birds are killed during this barbarous duck shooting episode that still happens in some States of Australia. This is the kind of sport that we are meant to agree with, promote and to think is good fun.

It also means, considering that the animal welfare groups collected 373 dead protected birds and the Government department collected 69, that the animal welfare groups were much more vigilant in their efforts. This would have been voluntary labour, people who are determined to eradicate this barbarous practice of opening fire on innocent birds in the duck shooting season. That is one aspect.

I want to mention also the former rifle range in Williamstown which is severely contaminated by lead shot. Not only is the wildlife at risk from so called sporting shooters, but also the land and the waterways are at risk. The Urban Land Authority bought a 111-hectare site from the Department of Defence. Before the housing project can be commenced on this former test rifle range, the Authority has to have a massive clean up of the lead shot which is situated in the mounds. For a long time this was used as a target area for the military, but it is the same sort of situation that occurs when sporting shooters at rifle ranges and so on perpetually pump lead into the soil. In relation to this site, an article in the Age newspaper of 16 August 1990 stated:

. . . rainwater soaking into the butts was steadily leaching lead into the bay, groundwater and a proposed flora and fauna reserve . . . plans to develop the land would have to be altered to treat the contaminated butts-
lead being a highly contaminating substance which we do not want to see getting into our soil or into our water.

There was also a 1989 report from South Australia on lead contamination associated with the South Australian Field and Game Club facilities at Cromer within the Mount Lofty Ranges watershed. The background to this inquiry was that a letter was received from Mr V.K. Mueller of Birdwood in late August 1987 expressing concern that sections 118 and 120 of Talunga were being polluted by lead shot.

The toxicity of lead ought to be taken very seriously. It is persistent in the aquatic environment and is biologically accumulated. It is both acutely and chronically toxic to aquatic life and impacts upon animals and humans. The impacts on agriculture, which were discovered in this study, were that there was contamination of soil and pasture by high concentrations of lead, constituting a serious risk to grazing through the accidental ingestion of soil by the animals, and the oxidisation and transportation of lead into compounds which may be taken up by plants or mobilised with soil solution.

There was also impact on the ground water. The soils in the area are generally acidic, with low salinity ground water occurring at about 1.5 millimetres. In addition, the land in question is a potential recharge area. In acid sandy soils the lead compounds are soluble and may be mobile in the soil and, therefore, it is likely that lead levels in the ground water will increase in the future. This is in the catchment area, the watershed area, in the Mount Lofty Ranges so it does have quite a lot of relevance for the water situation in South Australia.

From the analysis of soil and water sample it can be concluded that there is extensive contamination of pasture and local dams; that the local sheep are absorbing lead, which may give rise to unacceptable lead levels in meat; and that environmental contamination, which is not extensive at this stage, is likely to get worse if this rifle range is allowed to continue operations. Water from two of the dams in the region must not be used for human consumption.

On environmental grounds, I would say that it is very important that we look very closely at what the gun lobby in Australia is trying to do. I do not believe that we should be supporting so-called sports which have such a negative side effect, such as private arsenals, community violence, destruction of native habitat, soil and water contamination, no matter how careful the gun shooters are. In their literature, they certainly advocate responsible use of firearms. The point is that not all people are responsible, no matter how careful they are. I do not believe that we should be giving support to these kinds of so-called sporting activities.

I am indebted to the Gun Control Association of Australia for some of this material. It recently organised a successful seminar concerning the accelerating development of the gun lobby in Australia and 20 organisations which were concerned with environmental matters, social justice issues, crime issues, peace issues and non-violence were represented at that seminar. I think that it is very important that these issues are put on the national agenda. On social, moral and environmental grounds, I will not be supporting the Opposition's disallowance motion.

speech.speaker: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

talker.name: Senator TATE
talker.role: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

talk.start.para: â€”The Government, of course, wishes to see the Senate support the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations to do with the import of certain firearms to Australia. I believe that there have been indications from around the chamber that that support will be forthcoming and that the motion of disallowance moved by Senator Hill will be defeated.

speech.para: I want to commend Senator Robert Hill for bringing on this motion. I do so quite sincerely because the temptation would have been for the Opposition to bring on this disallowance motion during the New South Wales election campaign. I believe that Senator Hill and other responsible members of the Opposition have taken the view that they did not want to be caught up with the grandstanding and the highly emotive campaigning undertaken by the Minister for Police in New South Wales, Mr Ted Pickering, concerning this particular issue. I do want to say, before I rebut the arguments put forward by Senator Hill, that I believe that he has acted very responsibly in that respect.

Mr Pickering was going around the countryside creating fear and a real fur- ore, or at least he was attempting to whip up a frenzy amongst the gun owners of New South Wales by indicating to them that they could face prosecution for the possession of firearms which are prohibited by this regulation from being imported into Australia but which were in their lawful possession before 21 December 1990 when this regulation came into effect. He issued various press releases over the past several months to that effect and he has been campaigning around New South Wales during the election campaign trying to, as I say, whip up a frenzy equivalent to that which accompanied the previous State election campaign. It is now a matter of record, as one looks at the various election results, that that campaign by Mr Pickering was an abysmal failure. Yet it is true to say that, amongst some gun owners and their associations in New South Wales and elsewhere in Australia, there have been misgivings about these regulations, which it has been somewhat difficult to abate.

As to the question of retrospectivity, I think it is absolutely beyond doubt that the police Ministers in Australia, who have the cooperation of the customs Ministers in making these particular regulations, attempted to prevent the importation into Australia of a limited range of firearms, and I will name them. The regulations were framed on the basis of the police Ministers, excluding the one in New South Wales, advising the Minister for Small Business and Customs (Mr Beddall) that the regulations should be drawn up so as to exclude the importation of a rifle or shotgun that is fitted with a readily detachable or folding stock, whether by design or modification, and most importantly, or a self-loading centre fire rifle or carbine that has been issued or used by a military authority or militia, or which substantially duplicates those weapons by design, function and/or appearance.

What was happening was that firearms were being imported which had been designed for the sole purpose of killing other human beings, for use by the military or militia in other nations, or which were very closely based on those designs, substantially duplicating the appearance and design. It was thought by the police Ministers that, at the very least, Australian society should say that we do not need to import those sorts of weapons. Certainly, we do not need them to deal with the particular problems of feral animals, for example, when farmers and those involved in the eradication campaigns which are quite properly undertaken need to use quite powerful firearms to carry out the culling and the killing of animals regarded as nuisance or vermin in regard to the farming and agricultural pursuits undertaken in Australia.

One of the most interesting aspects of this whole attempt to prevent the importing of this restricted category of weapons has been the very firm support of the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, Mr Marshall Perron. I guess there are more hunters and recreational shooters dealing with wild animals in the Northern Territory than, for example, in urban Sydney, Melbourne or even Tasmania, yet Mr Perron was very strongly in support of this particular ban. But neither he nor any other police Minister would be in support of any attempt to make this ban apply somehow retrospectively so as to permit Customs officers to seize weapons being held in farms or houses around Australia that had already been lawfully imported. There is no intention and no possible effect in the wording of this regulation to allow for the banging down of doors of farmhouses or other dwellings around Australia to seize weapons which were lawfully in the possession of people under State or Territory law prior to the coming into being of this regulation.

It is true that certain opinions were sought, apparently by Mr Pickering, from the New South Wales Assistant State Crown Solicitor. Certainly the copy provided to us of that advice does not take the position that the legislation operates retrospectively. It answers completely different questions from those which are said to have been put to him before his answer. Of course, it is an offence to possess a prohibited import if the weapon was imported after 21 December 1990. That is the question which he answered affirmatively. What he was not asked was: does the regulation make the possession of a firearm imported before 21 December illegal? The answer to that must be no.

Anyway, the Chief General Counsel has provided an opinion. Senator Vicki Bourne of the Australian Democrats has asked whether I will table that particular opinion, and I certainly do so. The questions asked of counsel were:
(a) Does s.233 (1) (d) of the Customs Act 1901 apply to the possession in Australia of goods that have never been imported?
(b) Does s.233 (1) (d) apply to the possession in Australia of imported goods that are `prohibited imports' at the time of the possession but were not `prohibited imports' at the time of importation?
He says:
The answer to each of these questions is clearly `No'.

The reasons for that are outlined. I table that opinion. There is no doubt that, in the opinion of the Chief General Counsel of the Attorney-General's Department, there is no retrospective operation of these particular amending regulations.

Indeed, it would be plain to honourable senators that there is no need to include an express statement that the regulations are not retrospective. To do so would bring into question other legislation and effectively erode what is currently a clear presumption against retrospectivity. I think Senator Hill would recognise that there is a danger in, as he says, simply clarifying the matter or making explicit what is claimed by us, because it could throw into question the presumption which we say applies to all other instances where import regulations are amended and where a new list of goods is prohibited.

We want to make it abundantly clear that, in all those cases, in the absence of some very express wording, there is no retrospective application of the regulation. There is a clear presumption against retrospectivity which applies in this case. Indeed, it is of interest that the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances itself put in a holding notice of a motion to disallow this regulation. Amongst other grounds mentioned by Senator Patricia Giles, the Chairperson of that Committee, was the problem of retrospectivity. That Committee received a response from the Minister for Small Business and Customs, Mr Beddall, which attached the Chief General Counsel's opinion and affirmed that there was no retrospective application of these regulations. That must have satisfied that Committee, because it withdrew its notice of motion for disallowance. Naturally, that Committee has members of the Liberal and National Opposition coalition on it, and they were obviously satisfied by that explanation, or at least the Committee-that is as much as I can say-was satisfied by that explanation.

talk.start.para: â€”Can you give an assurance that there will be no prosecutions?

â€”What I am saying is that, if a weapon or firearm the importation of which is prohibited by these regulations is in the possession of a person in Australia who acquired possession of that firearm in Australia before 21 December 1990, there can be no effect on the lawfulness of that possession by the operation of this regulation. It is not retrospective in any way, shape or form. I want to give that absolute assurance that Senator Reid has so rightly sought.

speech.para: It would be wrong for anybody who has any good in his or her possession, quite lawfully under State law, suddenly to find that it could be seized by Customs officers, or in some other way made unlawful, simply because from a particular date the importation of those goods is made unlawful. For those reasons, I ask the Senate to accept-as obviously did its own Regulations and Ordinances Committee-that there is no retrospectivity involved in these regulations. To emphasise that or simply to state it for clarification, as Senator Hill suggests, would have a very damaging effect on the general presumption against retrospectivity which must apply to all legislation, as reinforced by the Acts Interpretation Act, but particularly in regard to Customs regulations.

As far as the competitive use of firearms is concerned, I emphasise that the regulations as drafted certainly reflect the intention of the Australian Police Ministers Council that the various responsible shooting organisations around Australia ought to have a very prominent and decisive role in indicating which firearms might be properly imported for competitive use but also for hunting and recreational use. But we will not permit the importation of military or military style semi-automatics for competitive use. They are completely out of bounds. That has to be made absolutely clear. We are not going to allow in the military style firearms, which are designed to kill other human beings for use by various militias such as the Red Army, or the Chinese military look-alikes which have been imported in great numbers into New South Wales prior to the passage of this particular regulation. We are not going to make any concessions there.

If one reads the regulation, one finds that such bodies as the Sporting Shooters Association of Australia Inc., the Amateur Pistol Shooting Union of Australia, the International Practical Shooting Confederation, the International Handguns Metallic Silhouette Association, the Australian Shooting Association, the Australian Clay Target Association Inc., the National Rifle Association of Australia, the Field and Game Federation of Australia, the Australian Small Bore and Air Rifle Association and so on are given an enhanced role such that, if those organisations endorse a particular firearm as acceptable for competitive use in their various disciplines and events, that hand gun, rifle or shotgun will be permitted to be imported into Australia. So it can be seen that there has been an incredible deference to those organisations and the role which they should play.

talk.start.para: â€”Is the difficulty not that some of those weapons seem to have been developed for a dual role and there is a version that is particularly tailored for target shooting? That is why the three types I specified--
â€”Senator Hill, I wonder whether you could address your matter more formally to the full Senate.
â€”I understand Senator Hill to be making the point that--
â€”I am glad that you do, Minister, but the rest of us may not. Indeed, Hansard may not, and neither may the ABC.
â€”Or the 33 listeners out there in Australia may not have quite grasped what he was saying.
â€”Due process, Minister. I just wanted it on the record.

â€”Senator Hill was making the point that some of these firearms that are sought to be imported for competitive use are modelled on military style semi-automatics and that, simply because they duplicate that military style weapon, that should be enough to exclude their being imported. In trying to change the way in which the Australian society deals with weapons, and in part in response to the report of the National Committee on Violence, the Australian Police Ministers have set down as clearly as they can that those weapons based on those military style weapons ought to be excluded from our community but that all other firearms with competitive and target type uses ought to be recognised and endorsed and the particular weapons permitted to be imported, although they are then subject to State or Territory law regulating the possession or use of the particular firearm.

speech.para: There was a very high level of consultation. I will not accept the constant refrain that the Federal Government did not indulge in a sufficient round of consultation with these particular organisations. I met several times with personnel from these organisations, including a very long afternoon in Adelaide when we met with several of the leading personnel from a range of three or four different organisations in what might be loosely termed the gun lobby. As a result of listening to them, several amendments were made to the proposal taken to the Australian Police Ministers Council meeting in Alice Springs later in the year. So we were not only listening but also responding in a very positive way to their representations in order to try to come to as much common ground as possible in restricting the importation of firearms.

In drawing up the regulation, I believe that the Australian Shooting Association, of which Mr Tamblyn is the National Executive Director, has pointed to a particular matter where the regulation does need some changing and some remedying. That is that the regulations as presently drafted provide overseas competitors with an exemption from safety testing requirements when they bring into Australia a firearm for the purpose of a competition. The Government recognises that weapons used in competition are too delicate to be exposed to standard testing procedures-for example, the drop test-and that the testing would have limited utility for this class of firearm, bearing in mind the skills of the competitors and the purpose for which they are imported.

Exemption does not apply to similar firearms which have been taken out of Australia or purchased overseas by Australian competitors. That is certainly an anomaly and steps are being taken urgently to amend the regulations so as to reinstate the position of the testing of competitive firearms which existed prior to 21 December 1990. I wrote yesterday to Mr Tamblyn to acquaint him of that particular fact. It is a very legitimate matter and I am sorry that, in the drafting of the regulation, that was not attended to as accurately as it ought to have been.

talk.start.para: â€”But the overseas competitor will be able to bring in a weapon that an Australian competitor would not be able to import.

â€”No. With regard to both overseas competitors and Australian resident competitors trying to bring in a firearm from overseas, in each case the import of the military style weapon will be prohibited. At the moment, the disparity between the status of both overseas and resident competitors is that the one has to face a certain testing of an imported weapon and the other does not, and we want to remedy that anomaly.
â€”You are going to tighten that?

â€”No, not tighten that. In fact, by the amendment that I have indicated to Mr Tamblyn, we will permit the easier importing of certain firearms for competitive use. At the moment, when they are brought in, they must be subjected to a certain test which, given the delicacy of the particular weapons, is totally unsuitable and ought not to be undertaken. I recognise that and am trying to help the competitive and sporting shooters in that regard.

speech.para: That probably deals with the major matters brought to the attention of the Senate by Senator Hill. I have indicated that an amendment will be forthcoming shortly as a result of the letter received from Mr Tamblyn but, apart from that, I believe that the regulation does what the Australian Police Ministers Council thought ought to be done and which I believe has very widespread public support.

That was evidenced by the New South Wales election where in this particular matter responsible shooters, whether competitive, sporting, recreational or hunting, were not beguiled or seduced by Mr Pickering in his attempt to relive the campaign of three years ago when there was a frenzied attempt to generate a tremendous amount of hysteria from the gun owners of New South Wales in particular, but Australia-wide, about the attempt by government to regulate the possession and use of firearms in our community. All this regulation does is prevent the import of a very restricted class of firearm which would prevent the accumulation within the Australian community of firearms designed basically to kill other human beings.

I believe that that is a very simple proposition which commands the support of the great majority of Australians. In my conversations and to my knowledge, most of those who possess firearms in our community see no reason for these particular firearms to be in our community. Indeed, as I say, my strongest supporter on the Australian Police Ministers Council in this regard has been Mr Marshall Perron, Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, who is of a completely different political colouring and responsible for a community where one might think there would be an attitude that almost any weapon would be satisfactory, suitable and proper to hold, given the particular indigenous and imported wild animals and beasts which a person in that Territory might face.

As in the case of all other Police Ministers, apart from Mr Pickering in New South Wales, the Chief Minister has recognised that we have to try to assist Australian society to change some of its attitudes with regard to the ownership, possession and use of firearms in our community. This change is part of a wider attempt-and there are many facets to it-to create a less violent Australia, an Australia where terrible massacres and deaths cannot occur, either in group situations or where someone is the individual victim of a person with one of these terrible weapons. We are trying to modify, ameliorate and change the culture which allows these firearms to be used in these terrible ways. It is only a small step, but one which I believe has the support of the Australian community. I hope that the regulation has the support of the chamber and that the motion for disallowance is rejected.

speech.speaker: Reid Sen M.E.

talk.start.para: â€”Much of what the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) said this afternoon would lead anyone listening to believe that he ought to withdraw the regulations presently before the Senate and come back when they have been redrafted to include those things which ought to be included and which the Minister and the Australian Democrats have admitted ought to be included. The Australian Democrats referred to the regulations as being not problem-free. We are dealing with a regulation that the Opposition has moved to disallow-that is, the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1990 No. 460, made under the Customs Act 1901. It arises from the statement made by the Minister on 22 November 1990 that there would be a restriction on the importation of firearms. It was referred to by the Minister as `a positive generic statement on permitted imports'.

speech.para: When I read the regulations, it looked to me as though they had been drafted by the Government to appear as though it was doing something about violence without adequately looking at the situation to ensure that it was achieving it. As a consequence of the Minister's announcement on 22 November 1990, the regulations were made on 19 December 1990, less than four weeks later, which indicates the extent to which they were rushed through. Every honourable senator knows how long it usually takes to get legislation into the Parliament from the time it is decided upon. Look at the number of Bills that have been on the Notice Paper for weeks and weeks. There is still no sign of the legislation. It was announced in a statement by the Minister on 22 November, and on 19 December 1990 regulations were made to prohibit the importation of all firearms other than specified exempt firearms.

I do not believe the Minister has rebutted the arguments that Senator Hill put when he spoke initially in support of the disallowance motion. The Minister did deal with the question of retrospectivity. He denied that there was any question of retrospectivity. I do not accept that the argument has been laid to rest, as he seeks; I think it is debatable. However, I was pleased to have the Minister's assurance that there would be no prosecution of anybody who presently has one of the firearms which in future will be outlawed and that the firearm cannot be seized.

Undoubtedly some firearms should be banned; we are not arguing against that. There is no question about the need to control violence in our society. But just bringing in regulations such as these does not go to the heart of the matter. Is it really so long since the Minister practised law that he has forgotten how difficult it is to advise clients and how much more expensive it is for clients when a Minister brings in regulations and has to admit that he has to make changes to them? Any legislation that is changed time after time becomes more complex and is likely to be misinterpreted. It is certainly more expensive for clients being advised on its implications. Knowing there is an inquiry by this Parliament into the cost of justice, the Minister should withdraw these regulations for as many weeks as it takes to bring them back in a way which sets it beyond doubt what he is trying to do. For that reason alone the Minister should defer bringing them in today.

We have heard about the implications of the regulations on sporting shooters. There are many eminent shooters in this country who have done extremely well with their shooting and it is most unfortunate that aspersions have been cast at them. We are talking about allowing legitimate sporting competitions to continue and not be outlawed. For example, the Palma match would no longer be able to be held in Australia. Australia would be not be able to host International Practical Shooting Confederation rifle matches. Has the Minister contemplated the fact that that is what he will achieve?

The question of collectors has been referred to. Collectors are willing to make compromises in their interests and community safety by, for example, deactivating dangerous types of arms such as machine-guns; but these regulations absolutely prohibit the importation of such arms. It has already been said that the legislation is difficult to meld with State requirements. It is arbitrary; it is impractical.

Does the Minister realise there are only four types of rifle produced that have a detachable magazine limit of only five rounds or less? These cost between $850 and $1,450 each. They are unsuited to competition, are of little interest to collectors and are very expensive for use by primary producers for vermin eradication. Primary producers are denied access to economical arms for feral pest destruction. Has the Minister looked at that aspect? It is arbitrary to change the regulations so that only semi-automatic rifles with more than five rounds are to be prohibited absolutely. Also, it seems that there is no intention to prohibit the importation of parts that can be used to make a firearm capable of the functions that are prohibited in fully imported weapons. Has the Minister looked at that aspect? Is that going to require another change to the regulations later?

The Sporting Shooters Association of Australia has put forward alternative proposals. I shall look closely at whether the Minister has met the suggestions put forward by the Association. I dealt with the question of retrospectivity previously. The Minister ought to look again at regulation 4.4.1, which allows no discretion or avenue of appeal. This is particularly important, given that the Minister has given State and Federal police the final say on listing which firearms can be imported. There is no avenue of appeal from that at all. Has the Minister had the time to analyse these regulations in the way that they should be? It is surely a denial of justice for the Minister to give to the police the final say on listing which firearms can be imported and not allow any appeal. I cannot believe that that is what the Minister is doing.

This legislation contributes nothing towards public safety, which is what most people in the community would hope the Minister would be doing. The answer to reducing violence in the community lies in part in prohibiting certain weapons. It lies more with education of the community, not with discriminatory legislation of this kind. It is estimated that there are 3 1/2 million firearms in Australia. The Minister may succeed in prohibiting the importation of a few. It is a fact that about 700 Australians die each year from gunshot wounds. That includes homicide, accidental death and suicide. That is an horrifically large number. However, it needs to be looked at, together with the 2,500 deaths from motor vehicle accidents this year.

There are other factors that can be taken into account in this debate-for example, the high rate of gun ownership but the low rate of homicide in Switzerland. There are reports dealing with these matters which indicate that the subculture of professional criminals will be minimally affected by such regulations and licensing that the Minister seeks to bring in. In my view, one death or assault using firearms is one too many. It would be better if the Minister did something in the community to see that that form of violence did not occur rather than bringing in these regulations and sleeping easily, believing that he has done something about it.

There is a need for sensible gun control measures, but they should not dealt with in these regulations.
