I realise that the Minister wants to appear to be doing something but without a regard for the real issues and the technical knowledge of what he is doing I do not believe he has succeeded. Other senators on this side of the chamber also would have liked to participate in this debate. The debate has gone on for much longer than was intended, but things had to be said in the light of the debate, the admission that the regulations are faulty and the fact that the Minister is rushing on with them without getting them right. Senator Michael Baume has been involved with many of the organisations. He too would have liked to speak. At this stage it is clear that the Democrats are determined to support the Government with the regulations. I am very disappointed that the Democrats were not prepared to use their influence with the Government to say, `Fair go. We understand what you are trying to do but do it properly and do not just get it half right'.

When will the changes come in? We will be flat out between now and 21 June and hardly able to cope with the volume of legislation which is before us. Then there will be the recession until the Budget session. I really wonder what, in fact, the Government is doing and why it is that it will not do so properly.
Question resolved in the negative.

speech.speaker: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

talk.start.para: â€”I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the document.

In speaking to this final annual report of the Australian bicentennial road development (ABRD) program I want to emphasise how much I appreciate any program which seeks to improve our roads. This is the seventh and final report on progress made in carrying out the ABRD program. Originally an initiative of the Fraser Government, it was supported enthusiastically by the then Minister, the Hon. Ralph Hunt. The program finally came into effect on 20 December 1982 for the purpose of providing a major impetus to the development of Australia's road system by the end of the nation's bicentennial year in 1988. It ended on 31 December of that year.

It was to be financed by a special surcharge on diesel fuel and motor spirit. As the report notes on page 11, the rates of surcharge were established at 1c a litre for the period 17 August 1982 to 30 June 1983, and 2c a litre for the period 1 July 1983 to 31 December 1988. It also notes that although these collections were supposedly for sole use on the roads, they were paid into consolidated revenue. In 1988-89 rebates, remissions and refunds under the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund Act exceeded gross surcharge collections under the 1c levy by $671,000. Net collections under the 2c levy were $223.7m.

It is about the progress over those years and the expenditure of that surcharge that I want to make a few points this evening. As I said, the ABRD program was to be financed by a special surcharge on petrol. What has happened is that while more than half the money spent by motorists on petrol goes to the Federal Government, for every litre of petrol or diesel purchased the Government takes about 26c in tax, returning only about 5c to 5.5c to the motorist in the form of road funding-the reason that it was imposed in the first place. Consequently, it has placed greater financial strain on local and State authorities already struggling to cope with rising costs.

I commend the fact that a major part of the program was to upgrade the national highways. However, in the process the arterial and rural roads were forgotten. The situation has now developed where local authorities have not been given enough for their own areas even to maintain those arterial roads. What has resulted is a major discrepancy between the two wonderful national highways. However, when we drive off the highways all we get are pot-holed surfaces and, many times, roads that have been returned to dirt and gravel instead of bitumen because councils cannot afford the upkeep.

Local authorities are, naturally, very concerned about the Government's refusal to acknowledge that insufficient funding has become a gigantic problem. Cuts have been particularly bad and have had a major impact in country areas. It has become impossible to keep up with the demand for new and improved roads to cater for the needs of the transport industry and the individual motorist. As fewer roadworks are commenced, fewer jobs become available in road construction and maintenance. This has had a particularly detrimental effect on employment opportunities in many provincial and rural centres. I have noticed this particularly in our South Burnett area where one reads in the local papers from time to time about many council employees who have lost their jobs.

A safe, reliable road network is of fundamental importance to our nation's economy. Poor roads serve only to isolate communities, increase fuel consumption, damage vehicles and increase the costs of goods and services. As most honourable senators will be aware, the ABRD and the Australian land transport programs were replaced by the current Australian centennial roads development program.

These are very important matters that I wanted to bring before the Senate this evening. One sees the number of articles about the state of the roads in rural Queensland, including statements like, `Lack of road funding is an insult to every travelling motorist. It is an insult to our intelligence to get so little back from our fuel tax for our roads. It is unfair that people in the most productive areas of Australia have to put up with deteriorating roads while money for roads is lavished on Sydney, Melbourne and Canberra', as we see around us.

speech.speaker: Calvert Sen P.H.

talk.start.para: â€”I wish to speak on the final report of the Australian bicentennial road development program. Like my colleague Senator Bjelke-Petersen, I too would draw attention to the broad objectives that were set out in this report and just refer to a couple of them. One states:

speech.para: * In accordance with national priorities, upgrade the road network in Australia to facilitate the reliable and efficient carriage of road traffic;
* enhance the safety of Australian roads;
Further on the report comments on the benefits as follows:
* Savings in private and commercial travelling times . . .
* reductions in the incidence of deaths and injuries from traffic crashes and their associated economic and social cost to the community;

They are fine objectives and I am not decrying this particular program but, as Senator Bjelke-Petersen said, when the levy was first imposed for the funding of this national road system, I do not think anybody believed that the Government was going to use it as just another means of filling up the coffers of the consolidated revenue.

I refer to a statement made by the Minister for Land Transport, Mr Bob Brown, about the fact that spending on country roads is disproportionate to spending on urban roads. It certainly is. He ignores the fact that rural roads are the vital link in this country's export capacity.

I took note of the consumer price index fuel indexation that people have been talking about for quite some time. Back in 1970 when it first started we were looking at 3.365c per litre of fuel. Then, when the Hawke Government came to power in 1982, it was 6.1c to 7.1c. By 1987 it had jumped to 15.766c, in 1990 it was 24.12 and as, Senator Bjelke-Petersen pointed out, it is now quite considerably more than that.

While the Government has been collecting all this extra revenue-billions and billions of dollars, not only from this particular area but also from the tax on crude oil; and we must remember that in the Budget last year the Government budgeted on the price of oil being about $23 a barrel when, in fact, it went a lot higher so the Government had a windfall gain there-the amount of money that is being spent on roads has been reduced by about 27 per cent.

The Government has just not played the game fairly. What has happened is that the Government has been squeezing motorists for more and more money and giving less and less for road funding. I think this point was raised in the last election campaign by quite a lot of community groups but, in particular, by the automobile associations. We can all remember the campaign that they ran and the sorts of priorities that were shown by the people of Australia.

talk.start.para: â€”Bolkus is going to stop them doing that.

â€”Of course he is going to stop them. In the future, under this proposed legislation of the Government, the Automobile Association will not be able to tell the people of Australia that 88 per cent of motorists believe that the Federal Government should allocate more funds to roads. It will not be allowed to do that.

speech.para: Another thing has not worked out as well as expected, as honourable senators may remember. During the election campaign, the Labor Government promised $100m a year extra for a provincial cities and rural highways program. This was to be funded by the tax on luxury cars. We all know what happened to that. That went out the back door very quickly because it put half the car dealers in Australia in a terrible financial situation. What has happened to that $100m a year that was promised at the 1990 election? I can guarantee that that money will not be spent on a rural highways program or on provincial cities.

The motorists of Australia have been conned by this Government. They have been ripped off. The petrol bowser has become just another source of income for the Government. One only has to travel around the rural areas of Australia to see just how much our road system has been run down because there has been very little help from this Government.

speech.speaker: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

talk.start.para: â€”I also wish to speak on the annual report on the Australian bicentennial road development program, which formally ended on 31 December 1988. The program was established in 1982 by the last coalition Government. It was funded through a surcharge on motor spirit and diesel fuel excise. Moneys from this source were paid into a trust fund.

speech.para: The last coalition Budget allocated $1,058m for road transport expenditure. It also set the level of expenditure for the following year at $1,265m. However, since the Labor Government came to power and set the level of road expenditure, funding for roads has stagnated in nominal terms and fallen in real terms by about 40 per cent. However, at the same time, hypothecated fuel excise as a proportion of total fuel taxes has fallen from well over 50 per cent to under 25 per cent. Petrol excise has risen from about 6c per litre to nearly 25c per litre.

The Government's record in the area of road funding has been nothing short of a disgrace. The Government has continually failed to provide the funds necessary for Australians to have the roads they need and deserve. A better road transport funding policy would enable Australia to reap significant benefits.

Probably the most important issue is that of road safety. It has been estimated that bad roads contribute to about 30 per cent of all crashes. Better roads are safer roads. Widening traffic lanes by one metre can reduce head-on crashes and run off road crashes by 29 per cent. Passing lanes can cut crashes by 50 per cent. Replacing an undivided road with a freeway can cut crashes by 90 per cent.

Road transport costs alone are typically in the order of 5 per cent of the total product costs within the more trade exposed parts of the manufacturing sector. An Industries Assistance Commission and Business Council of Australia study has suggested that increasing efficiency in the road transport area could lead to a $1.7 billion increase in national output, something Australia needs at this time in its economic history. Rough surfaces increase fuel consumption by 20 per cent and vehicle repair costs by nearly 40 per cent, again adding undue costs especially to our farm and manufactured goods. It costs $1 per minute every time a heavy transport is held up in traffic, not to mention the environmental consequences.

But, in reality, what do we have? Nationwide sealed roads are being torn up and returned to gravel because local governments cannot afford to maintain them. In my electorate in Victoria, I have been taken around the shire of Werribee and shown the appalling state of the roads. The shire councillors have taken me around Sherbrooke Shire, one of the developing areas which has had a high increase in population, and I have been shown the appalling and deteriorating state of the roads there.

Over half our major roads have surfaces that are 20 years old. It has been disturbing that some of the men who constructed those roads for a company that was associated with road construction have come to my office and told me that many roads are actually reaching the end of their lives. This Government has never committed itself to an adequate level of road funding, and it seems destined to continue along the same path. I find it very interesting that only colleagues on this side of the Senate have expressed any concern for or interest in this annual report.

speech.speaker: Panizza Sen J.H.

talk.start.para: â€”I rise to speak briefly on the annual report on the Australian bicentennial road development (ABRD) program. I have pleasure in doing so because this report winds up a very good program, which was probably one of the last pro- jects of lasting importance commenced under Malcolm Fraser's last Budget. It is not that the other measures he put into place, including this Parliament House, were not of lasting importance, but the ABRD program certainly was because that is where the concept of road funding and better road construction in Australia started. It introduced a predictable level of funding, which had not existed before.

speech.para: Senator Patterson has already pointed out that increased road funding started with the introduction of a fuel excise of, I think, 2c per litre. That excise was to go into this trust fund which was meant to distribute money to four categories of roads, if I remember correctly: national roads, which involved national interstate highways; urban arterial roads; State arterial roads; and local roads. The money was passed out to the State governments to be distributed to their main roads departments. Of course, money went through local government as well. The road system of Australia improved no end as a result of that.

One of the most significant features of the change in road funding was that for the first time main roads departments had to tender for their own jobs. In other words, they had to tender alongside private enterprise for the big projects. Some main roads departments won the contracts and some did not, but it put a lot more responsibility into road making. We saw the benefits of that. Unfortunately, those benefits are starting to run down now because of the lack of funding for roads provided by this Government since it came into power in 1983. The amount spent on roads is ever decreasing in real terms. Tendering certainly made tend- erers a lot keener, and the roads that were built were a lot better.

Senator Patterson pointed out that there are roads in Victoria that have not had any money spent on them for the last 20 years. Normally, when a commercial main road is built, it can be expected that not too much will have to be spent on it for 15 years. Those roads are normally made with a life expectancy of 35 years but, at the 15-year level, some money has to be spent on maintenance. Senator Patterson referred to the state of some roads in Victoria five years ago, and what she said applies also to New South Wales and my State of Western Australia. The Government has failed these areas in road funding.

As Senator Patterson said, a lot of those roads are being ripped up and are being put back to gravel because of the lack of funding. Those good, solid bitumen roads will last 35 years as long as we maintain them. A lot of people have the idea that, once a bitumen road is down, it is down for life and nothing else is done on it. But that is not right. It is a lot cheaper to maintain a bitumen road than a gravel road early in its life but, as bitumen roads reach the age of 15, 20 and 35 years, the level of spending becomes far greater than for gravel roads. Gravel roads require continuous maintenance.

I believe that our former Prime Minister, Mr Malcolm Fraser, through his last Budget of 1982, did a great service to Australia by getting the ABRD system going. It was changed to a Commonwealth road development system about two years ago and last year was changed totally through the land transport Bill. Now there are far too many ministerial powers governing where road funding is allocated. Unfortunately, what road funding is available tends to go into the areas that are more receptive to ballot boxes than into the areas where good roads are needed. In conclusion, I believe that this has been a very worthwhile program since 1982 and I hope that in some way or other it can continue. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

debate.title: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS, DEFENCE AND TRADE

speech.speaker: Maguire Sen G.R.

talk.start.para: â€”I present the report of the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on Australia and United Nations peacekeeping, together with the transcript of evidence.

speech.para: Ordered that the report be printed.

talk.start.para: â€”by leave-I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the report.

When I moved on 20 September 1990 for the terms of reference for the inquiry which led to this report, peacekeeping was emerging as a high priority on the international agenda. United Nations peacekeeping missions in the Western Sahara and Cambodia were already under active consideration. In the short time since then a new peacekeeping mission has been established on the Iraq-Kuwait border in the aftermath of the Gulf war.

Participation in United Nations peacekeeping operations is now, more than ever before, one of the high-probability tasks of the Australian Defence Force. Opportunities for civilian contributions are also likely to increase.
Scope of the Report

The Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade is confident that its report will make a positive contribution to the evaluation of Australia's role in United Nations peacekeeping. As the terms of reference suggest, there are several important issues that need to be addressed.

The report gives a brief outline of the evolution of peacekeeping and the way it is managed and administered by the United Nations and in Australia. The report does not examine Australia's role in the Gulf war, as the Committee took the view that this was outside the scope of the terms of reference for the inquiry laid down by the Senate. The report looks at Australia's past participation in United Nations peacekeeping and the demands that may be placed upon Australia in the future. It examines critically the costs and benefits to Australia of that participation. The report explores the role and possible contribution that non-military organisations can make to peacekeeping. It addresses the critical issue of public support of peacekeeping in Australia. The report examines the perspectives that have dominated Australia's past approach to providing resources for United Nations peacekeeping, and looks to a clearer and increased commitment to peacekeeping in the future. The Committee endorses the importance given to United Nations peacekeeping activities by successive Australian governments.
Australian Objectives

The evidence before the Committee suggested that the underlying objectives for Australian involvement in United Nations peacekeeping need to be more effectively drawn together and publicly enunciated. The report emphasises the importance of assessing peacekeeping activities as part of wider Australian security concerns and foreign policy interests. The Committee was struck by a certain amount of confusion in the material before it between the objectives that Australia should seek to achieve through participation in peacekeeping, and benefits that might flow from such participation. For the purposes of assessing whether or not Australia should participate in a particular peacekeeping exercise, it is important to maintain a clear distinction between the two.

Historically, Australia has rightly attached importance to the contribution of multilateral institutions such as the United Nations to a favourable international order. It has given concrete expression to this commitment by contributing to a substantial number of the United Nations peacekeeping operations that have been conducted. However, a much stronger linkage to Australia's overall foreign policy objectives must be established if decisions to become involved in specific peacekeeping operations are to be soundly based. The relative importance to be attached and resources devoted to fulfilling obligations under the United Nations charter, as opposed to using other foreign policy instruments, need to be carefully considered.

A theme common to a number of the submissions before the Committee was the increased scope, with the ending of the Cold War, for the United Nations to play a more constructive and influential role on the world stage. It is essential that policy advisers critically examine this proposition. An assessment of the validity of this proposition should be a vital component in any decisions on the relative effort Australia should put into activities like peacekeeping.
Regional Cooperation

The balance of effort that should go into potential regional peacekeeping commitments such as Cambodia, as opposed to more distant ones such as the Western Sahara, is another key issue that must be addressed more fully than it has been in the past. A pro-active approach to encouraging greater cooperation with regional countries in relation to United Nations peacekeeping is an area where Australia has the capacity to creatively influence the regional defence and security agenda.

The Committee's report recommends that the Australian Government take the initiative to explore with countries of the region the idea of greater regional cooperation, at various levels, in developing a capacity to respond to United Nations peacekeeping requests speedily and efficiently. The emphasis should be on giving a new focus to the links which already exist under ongoing defence and foreign policy programs. The Committee sees this as a potentially valuable component in the network of linkages that Australia is seeking to establish with the countries of the region. Adequate resources to achieve this objective will have to be provided. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said in his address to the Asia-Australia Institute last Friday that:
. . . we no longer seek, through our alliances, to build up walls of defence against the region, but to build bridges of cooperation with the region.

The Committee sees its proposal that the Government initiate discussion with countries of the region aimed at developing a regional capacity to contribute to peacekeeping as an important positive element in the building of these bridges of cooperation.
Australian Defence Force Objectives

Evidence presented to the Committee indicated that peacekeeping was seen by the Department of Defence as a positive and worthwhile but somewhat peripheral activity. The Committee believes that the ambiguity implicit in this approach can be effectively reconciled only by including an upgraded commitment to peacekeeping in the explicit objectives of the Australian Defence Force. The Committee's report therefore recommends that the Australian contributions to international peacekeeping be explicitly included in the objectives of the Australian Defence Force, and in particular be recognised as one positive element in regional security cooperation.

The contribution of Australian peacekeeping contingents to a particular operation should first be assessed on a case by case basis; secondly, utilise existing capabilities; and, thirdly, play no role in determining the structure of the Australian Defence Force. I seek leave to have the remainder of my remarks incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The remainder of the speech read as follows-
Reserves
The role of the Reserves in peacekeeping operations was explored with several witnesses, and the participation of reservists in past operations was reviewed.

The Committee has recommended that the role of the Reserves in peacekeeping tasks be comprehensively addressed by current force structure reviews, including ways and means (such as legislation guaranteeing employment) of eliminating obstacles to greater use of Reserves for such tasks.
Policy-making and Administration

The Committee heard criticism during its hearings of the United Nations policy-making and administrative machinery for peacekeeping operations. Witnesses proposed suggestions for improvements and for achieving greater Australian influence at UN Headquarters, and in the operational command of missions.
The Committee has stressed that the Australian Government should give a high priority in its foreign policy objectives to seeking improvement of the UN machinery for peacekeeping.
In particular, the permanent appointment of an Australian officer to the UN Secretary General's Military Planning Staff should be actively and vigorously pursued.

With the prospect of peacekeeping requirements emerging closer to Australia's own region and immediate interests, it may become critically important for Australia to be successful in obtaining command appointments. The evidence given to the Committee suggested that it is now recognised that in operations such as the one in prospect in Cambodia, the appointment of an Australian to command the operation in the event of an Australian contribution would be most desirable.

The Committee has recommended that if Australia was to commit forces to a peacekeeping operation in Cambodia, steps should be taken at the most senior levels, and every avenue pursued, to put to the United Nations Secretariat Australia's case for command of the operation. Success in this endeavour will require persistence and a high level of diplomatic skill.
Peacekeeping Secretariat
The Committee examined the adequacy of current organisational arrangements within the bureaucracy in Australia for handling peacekeeping issues.

It became obvious that information on the basic question of financial costs to Australia was fragmented within the bureaucracy, difficult to access and inadequate. The Committee has recommended that a more comprehensive picture of the total financial cost of any Australian contributions be readily available to Government, to the Parliament and to the Australian people.

More generally, there appears to be inadequate capability for critical evaluation of peacekeeping operations. The Committee was struck by the apparently haphazard nature of the evaluation of past peacekeeping operations and Australia's role in them. Individual Australian contingent commanders have reported to the Government on their assignments. What is less clear is the extent to which these reports have informed subsequent decision-makers and participants.

The disparate nature of the various peacekeeping operations, their geographic spread, and the different locations within the Defence Department that have had management responsibility for particular operations, all suggest that the lessons of the past may not have been fully absorbed and as well integrated into future policy advice as they might.

The problem is compounded by the absence of an in-built evaluation system within the UN. Although efforts have apparently been made by Australian officials to remedy this, they have so far met with very limited success.
The Committee came to the view that there was a need for a fresh look at existing organisational arrangements in Australia for coordinating policy advice on peacekeeping.

The Committee has recommended that a permanent Australian Government secretariat or task force be established as a matter of priority to oversight and coordinate the many and varied aspects of peacekeeping in the evolving international order. Representatives from the various relevant departments and agencies should be seconded to the unit as required.

The basic role of the unit should be pro-active, not reactive. Its starting point should be a clear identification of Australia's interests in peacekeeping, both generally, and as specific cases arise.

The Committee has drawn up a suggested reference list of factors that should be taken into account by the proposed peacekeeping secretariat in formulating policy advice on participation by Australia in future operations.

In the event of a mixed Australian military/civilian contribution to future peacekeeping operations, particularly in situations such as Cambodia, careful attention will need to be given to establishing appropriate mechanisms to maximise effective coordination.
These mechanisms should extend to civilian non-governmental organisations, whose activities are complementary to but not part of the peacekeeping operation.

The responsibility for ensuring that adequate mechanisms for effective coordination are in place for any particular peacekeeping operation should lie with the small permanent peacekeeping secretariat the Committee has proposed.
Public Support
The Committee took the view that the support of the Australian public for participation in peacekeeping missions was of vital importance.

We observed, however, that by and large, the community was sometimes poorly informed and appeared unaware of the specific extent and range of Australia's involvement with peacekeeping activities. Knowledge of some of the smaller contingents, such as the observers on the Iran-Iraq border, seemed particularly poor.
Public support for Australian participation in peacekeeping operations cannot be taken for granted. Three essential issues need to be addressed if public support is to be maintained.
Level of Risk

First, it is essential to make as accurate an assessment of likely risk as possible. This has not always proved easy or straightforward in the past. With the benefits of hindsight, it appears the level of risk in the case of the observers sent to the Iran-Iraq border was seriously underestimated, while the conditions in Namibia proved to be less hazardous than had been feared initially. Information available from the United Nations apparently proved inadequate.

One of the lessons to be drawn is the value of sending an advance scout to assess the situation on the ground. It is particularly important to do so when there is good reason to expect a high level of risk, as would undoubtedly be the case in Cambodia.

The Committee has therefore recommended that on-the-ground assessment of the security situation by Australian personnel in the country of a proposed United Nations peacekeeping operation be instituted as standard procedure before the commitment of forces.
Second, steps must be taken to minimise the risks as far as possible.

An essential requirement for this is that the political settlement on which the peacekeeping operation is to be based should be a durable one. In other words, all parties to the conflict would have to be committed to a comprehensive settlement and to the relevant Security Council resolutions and to the agreed operational plans. The Committee has recommended that this kind of commitment be a precondition for the commitment of any Australian contribution to a UN peacekeeping force.

Third, every effort needs to be made to adequately inform and prepare the Australian public. A basic requirement is public understanding of the reasons for a particular peacekeeping operation, why it matters and why Australia should play a part in it.
Public Information

The Committee has recommended that a statement of the factors being taken into account by the Government in deciding on participation in a proposed specific peacekeeping operation be publicised widely in the Australian community before a final decision on participation in that operation is reached.
I emphasise that broad public acceptance that the effort is worthwhile is essential.
Recognition

Another way of achieving a higher profile for Australia's involvement in peacekeeping would be to ensure that peacekeepers returning from their mission are given due public recognition for the services they have performed.
The Committee was pleased to see the public welcome given to the Army engineers returning from Namibia.

It is obviously more difficult to achieve the same impact when a small group of observers are involved on a rotation basis over an extended period of time, as they were in UNIIMOG on the Iran-Iraq border. Nevertheless the Defence Forces Public Relations unit should endeavour to attract favourable publicity for each rotation and for some individual cases.
The Committee has recommended that Australia's role in peacekeeping, both military and civilian, be given greater acknowledgment by Government, and be more actively publicised.
Medal

The award of the Australian Service Medal is an occasion that could be used in this way. Not only is this useful for ensuring that peacekeeping stays in the public eye, but gives a valuable boost to the morale of those participating.

In particular, awards such as the Australian Service Medal should be arranged as soon as possible after the return of an Australian peacekeeping contingent at appropriate public and well-publicised occasions. Consideration should also be given to striking a special medal in certain instances.
Official History

In the course of the inquiry, the Committee became conscious of the dearth of publicly available material about Australia's past involvement in some peacekeeping operations. Australia's past contributions deserve more public attention than they have received.

The Committee has therefore recommended that the Official Historian at the Australian War Memorial be commissioned to write a full history of Australian participation in peacekeeping and that it be distributed widely, as one means of maintaining public awareness of the importance of the principles of peacekeeping.
Service Conditions
Evidence was taken during the inquiry on conditions of service for those serving with Australian contingents to peacekeeping missions.

Overwhelmingly, the Committee gathered the impression that those from the Australian Defence Force and the Australian Federal Police and other civilians who had served in peacekeeping operations were dedicated professionals with a very high level of commitment, proud to represent Australia overseas and concerned to acquit themselves to the very best of their ability.

However, the goodwill and commitment of those embarking on peacekeeping missions, which invariably have the potential to be stressful, hazardous and difficult, does not absolve the authorities responsible from providing consistent, fair and equitable recompense to those who serve in them.
Accurate information about the terms and conditions should be available to participants before they embark on their missions.

The Committee has recommended that a comprehensive review of conditions of service be undertaken to establish mechanisms for both military and civilian personnel to ensure that fair and consistent conditions of service apply to all Australian participants in peacekeeping, and that the determination of these conditions of service is both quick and transparent, and made subject to regular evaluation. The Committee has also recommended measures to assist in the welfare of the families in Australia of Service personnel involved in future peacekeeping operations.
Training

There was almost universal acknowledgment by individuals who gave evidence of their personal experience of peacekeeping that there was one area which they initially found particularly challenging. In nearly all cases of personal testimony, the police or military officers felt that the demands on their mediation skills went well beyond the normal requirements of service in the police or defence force in Australia.

Negotiation and conflict resolution was a crucial function for peacekeeping. All who had participated in peacekeeping missions, especially in the cases of Cyprus and the Iran-Iraq border, felt they had experienced considerable personal growth and substantially developed their negotiating skills during the course of their assignment.
The Committee has recommended that additional emphasis be given to negotiation and conflict resolution skills in the pre-posting training for those embarking on peacekeeping missions.
Policewomen
Australian police officers have been deployed as part of the United Nations Civilian Police in Cyprus since 1964.

A notable feature of the Australian police contingent in Cyprus in recent years has been the presence of women officers, who have performed the full range of duties assigned to the unit. This is believed to be the first time that women have served in a front line capacity with a UN peacekeeping operation.

The Committee has commended the pioneering role of the Australian Federal Police in including women in its peacekeeping contingent in Cyprus, and recommended that action be taken to ensure that women have equal opportunity to participate in future Australian contributions to peacekeeping operations.
NGO Participation

Aside from the International Committee of the Red Cross, which has on occasions worked closely with UN peacekeeping operations in the exercise of its own mandate, there has never been any formal non-governmental organisation participation in United Nations peacekeeping operations.

The Department of Foreign Affairs and the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau told the Committee that non-governmental organisation participation in future operations is by no means excluded, although it is clear that little thought has been given in the UN Secretariat to the formalisation of such participation. It is the Committee's view that, while peacekeeping and activities such as rehabilitation assistance should be conducted in a mutually supportive way, they need not necessarily be formally linked. A parallel but coordinated approach seems the best in the foreseeable future.
Costs and Benefits
The Committee concluded that the benefits to Australia of participation in peacekeeping have so far outweighed the costs.
It cannot, however, be taken for granted that this will always be the case.

Careful judgements will have to be made about each opportunity as it arises. It is my belief that the nineteen recommendations in the Committee's report will help to ensure that the benefits continue to outweigh the costs.
Acknowledgments
Finally, I would like to thank my colleagues on the Committee for their diligence in bringing the inquiry to a prompt conclusion.
I also wish to thank the staff of the Committee for their assistance.

A particular mention is in order for the staff of the Australian Government Publishing Service and their printer for their efforts in having our report ready for tabling today within a week of their having received the final proofs.
I commend the report to the Senate.

speech.speaker: Teague Sen B.C.

talk.start.para: â€”As Deputy Chairman of the inquiry of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade into Australia and United Nations peacekeeping, I support the remarks of the Chairman, Senator Maguire, and note the bipartisan way in which the eight members of the Committee conducted this inquiry so profitably. The substance of our conclusions and recommendations are set out in the report tabled here today. It is a very timely report. In fact, this has been the first parliamentary inquiry into Australia's involvement in United Nations (UN) peacekeeping. On a worldwide scale, I believe that there will be more and more calls for the nations of the world to contribute to the United Nations peacekeeping contingents. In recent times we have seen a very successful peacekeeping contingent in Namibia, which was the midwife to the independence of that country and, indeed, the establishment of a democratic foundation for an independent Namibia.

speech.para: Other recent important roles have been played by UN peacekeeping forces in the conclusion of the Iran-Iraq conflict, which was a positive contribution, despite Iraq's aggression then against Kuwait, and a quite different and terrible conflict leading to the events of which we know only too well that occurred in the Gulf in recent months.

We have also had long-standing peacekeeping arrangements, sponsored by the United Nations, in the Middle East-particularly related to Israel, Lebanon and Cyprus where the Turkish-speaking and Greek-speaking communities are still separated by a buffer zone that is policed by a United Nations peacekeeping force. The Australian contingent to that Cyprus peacekeeping force has made a very proud contribution over a period of about 30 years.

I wish to commend the way in which the inquiry into Australia's involvement in peacekeeping was conducted by the Senate Committee with the very substantial assistance of the Committee Secretary, Mrs Ilze Svenne. I wish to refer to four of the Committee's conclusions in the very brief time that we have to speak at this stage, now that the Senate has received this report. Firstly, in Australia we have never set out in any examination of the objectives of the Australian Defence Force (ADF) an explicit reference to international peacekeeping, or to United Nations peacekeeping in particular. Although Australia has, with a proud record, contributed to some 16 United Nations peacekeeping exercises over the last 40 years, nevertheless, there is no explicit reference in the objectives of the Australian Defence Force to such contributions being made or to the fact that we have a defence force from which, from time to time, contingents will be drawn to contribute to international peace- keeping.

Even in the 1987 Defence White Paper, UN peacekeeping is not explicitly included amongst the objectives of the ADF. I believe this is a serious omission and one that needs to be brought up to date to take into account our long record over four decades and, indeed, the contributions we are likely to make in the years ahead.

This matter has the bipartisan support of the Government and the Opposition in this Parliament and the Australian public is rightly proud to see our very professional defence forces making contributions to United Nations peacekeeping. I believe there needs to be an explicit inclusion of this in the objectives of the Australian Defence Force in the way in which we have set them out in the report.

As an example of how there is a direct transition from our foreign policy to our defence policy, in this country we believe very strongly that there should be independent democratic nations in southern Africa and that the achievement of such outcomes will contribute to the peace of that region and the peace of the world. To achieve this Australian foreign policy objective, we found that it would be a very positive move to contribute a defence group of Australian Army engineers to the transitional peacekeeping group in Namibia. I believe without that contribution we would not now be seeing a sound democratic Namibia and the arrival of a new, independent country. I instance this example of Namibia to show that an explicit foreign policy objective of Australia has been achieved by the deployment of a defence contingent to this peacekeeping group in southern Africa.

This link between our foreign policy and our defence policy ought to be explicit when we contemplate the objectives of the Australian Defence Force. There should be no apology for Australia's contribution to UN peacekeeping. Whilst of course the principle objective of the Australian Defence Force is the direct defence of Australia, it has been proved that there is another objective: to contribute to good international citizenship and the alleviation of tensions, the prevention of war and the achievement of peace in our own region and in other regions where we can make a contribution.

The second area I wish to refer to briefly concerns Cambodia. In this chamber we have often referred to the need for a comprehensive settlement to which all four factions in Cambodia will subscribe. We envisage in our discussions that there should then be a transitional peacekeeping force in Cambodia. Not only has Australia sponsored the shape that that force should take, but also I believe we ought to be ready to contribute very substantially to that force in Cambodia and even to supply the commander of the force. An important conference will be held in Jakarta on 2, 3 and 4 June and we hope that that comprehensive settlement will be achieved by the resolution of the two outstanding matters with regard to Cambodia. The world will then be able to serve Indo-China, and the Khmer people in particular, by providing a peacekeeping force which will have the task of implementing the settlement.

It will cost at least $1 billion in the first 12 months and it may be in place for two years. It will be a very substantial undertaking. I note that at the moment the peacekeeping activities of the United Nations are costing the world an amount that is exceeding the actual administrative costs of the United Nations. At the moment the UN peacekeeping budget is a little more than twice the administrative budget of the UN in order to pay for the various peacekeeping forces that the United Nations Security Council has put in place and to which we, and other nations, have contributed.

The third area to which I wish to refer concerns the need for a secretariat in foreign affairs in order to pull together our foreign affairs inputs to peacekeeping and our defence inputs to peacekeeping. At the moment there is not sufficient integration of policy and planning. We are not even able to detail the exact costs to Australia-including our compensation from the United Nations budget-of the activities to which we have contributed already. Not least, there is a need for the secretariat to implement the recommendations of the report that we are now bringing forward and also to build regional training cooperation in the Asia-Pacific region, which I believe is an important way to complement the defence cooperation schemes that we already have in place with the Pacific nations and the Association of South East Asian Nations. I believe the countries of the South Pacific and South East Asia can move to a closer defence association with Australia by integrated training programs for United Nations peacekeeping.

Finally, I note that our report is already a little out of date. Even though we drafted the report only a few weeks ago, there is perhaps a too explicit reliance on formulas of peacekeeping that require both parties to a conflict to agree to the peace- keeping force being deployed by the Security Council of the United Nations. I note that some peacekeeping operations will have the assent of only one party.

I cite the current example of Unicom's involvement in Kuwait which has the assent of Kuwait only and not the explicit consent of Iraq, given the abhorrent isolationist non-cooperation of Saddam Hussein. In this case there is a useful peacekeeping contingent with contributions from 30 nations. It will be a positive guarantee for Kuwait's independence, but it does not have the assent of one of the parties to the conflict-Iraq. It does not meet the immediate formulas of peacekeeping, as we have set out in the report.

In conclusion, I refer to my participation this past week in a UN peacekeeping discussion in Canada. Beyond the reference of Australia and UN peacekeeping, in our discussion in Ottawa we addressed ways of strengthening UN peacekeeping. I seek leave to incorporate a two-page document outlining the conclusions of the conference in Ottawa. The document was prepared by the Parliamentarians for Global Action and is entitled `The Ottawa Declaration on UN Collective Security'. It was adopted in Ottawa on 22 May and I was one of the signatories, along with those from about 20 other parliaments around the world.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
PARLIAMENTARIANS FOR GLOBAL ACTION
OTTAWA DECLARATION ON UN COLLECTIVE SECURITY
Ottawa, 22 May 1991

We, members of Parliamentarians for Global Action's Commission on Collective Security, call upon all governments and parliamentarians to act together to strengthen the collective security system of the United Nations.
For forty years, the world was caught in the grip of the Cold War. International peace and security was dominated by theories of nuclear deterrence and adversarial defence alliances.

Today, the Cold War is replaced by a new era of co-operation and the search for a new world order. The recent conflict in the Gulf demonstrates the capacity of the international community to take quick and decisive action in response to aggression. But the mechanism for acting through the United Nations remains underdeveloped.

The new order must be based on disarmament and reduced military expenditure. It must rest on a respect for human rights, social justice among nations and a commitment to sustainable development, particularly the development of the South; it must answer the needs of the South as well as the needs of the North. It must rest on the notion of common security and be underpinned by an effective collective security system through the UN Security Council with the strong support of Member States.

The nuclear nightmare of recent decades must be replaced by a rational framework for peace. The mechanism for peace must be put in place during the 1990s. We reject the argument that such a system cannot be afforded: the rule of law will prove less costly than the chaos of war.
1. PREVENTIVE PEACEKEEPING
We call upon governments:

- to initiate, in addition to existing UN peacekeeping arrangements, a system of ``preventive'' peacekeeping by which UN troops could be deployed along the border of a nation legitimately fearing attack, to be backed as necessary by forces authorised by the Security Council, as a deterrent to possible aggression by another State and a signal of the resolve of the international community to remain seized of the situation.
2. PARLIAMENTARY INITIATIVES
We call upon our colleagues in parliaments, assemblies and congresses around the world:

- to begin a major review of the structure of the United Nations, with a view to broadening the political legitimacy of UN collective security actions, and ensure that those actions reflect the interests of all Member States.
3. CHARTER REVIEW CONFERENCE

The mechanism for strengthening collective security already exists in the UN Charter. What is needed now is a political process at a high level in which the international community can focus on strengthening the collective security mechanism of the United Nations. We therefore call upon governments:

- to decide at the 46th General Assembly to convene a UN Special Session on International Peace and Security, in preparation for Charter Review Conference at the summit level in 1995, the fiftieth anniversary of the UN Charter, to ensure that collective security can be made to work.
4. STRENGTHENING UN PEACEKEEPING
While the above measures are matters of urgent priority that deserve high-level political attention, we call on governments to pursue vigorously the following initiatives:

a. to respond positively to the UN Secretary-General's appeal to Member States to identify troops and materiel that can in principle be made available to the UN for peacekeeping operations, and to explore, as a next step, scope for increasing possible contributions through regional cooperation and burden-sharing;
b. to set up UN peacekeeping training centres in each region of the world along the lines of the Nordic UN Peacekeeping Training Centres;
c. to expand the UN Peacekeeping Supply Depot at Pisa, Italy, and establish supply depots in each region;
d. to pay off all financial arrears owed by the opening of the 47th General Assembly;

e. to help ensure that UN peacekeeping operations are financed promptly and fully, by increasing the UN Working Capital Fund by at least $100 million dollars, and by contributions to the Trust Fund for peacekeeping operations;

f. to upgrade the early-warning capacity of the United Nations to anticipate conflict by arranging for the UN Secretary-General to assign representatives to the major regional organisations (such as the OAU, OAS, Arab League, CSCE, South Pacific Forum and ASEAN) to keep the Secretary-General apprised of emerging crises;
g. to strengthen the military liaison between governments and the United Nations for the purposes of peacekeeping;

h. to have the General Assembly delegate authority to the Secretary-General to seek advisory opinions from the International Court of Justice on the legal aspects of border disputes that could threaten international peace and security.
PLEDGE TO THE FUTURE

The twenty-first century must not experience the cruelty, turbulence and dangers of our own times. The planet must be preserved, and the species allowed to prosper in peace and justice without threat of degradation or extinction. We pledge to our children's generation that we shall work together through co-ordinated parliamentary action to ensure that this will be so.

David Lange, MP New Zealand, Mr Raphael Shempemba, MP Tanzania, Dr Ole Espersen, MP Denmark, Hon Lloyd Axworthy, PC, MP Canada, Mr John Brewin, MP Canada, Mr Theo Sambuaga, MP Indonesia, Mr Denis McGinley, MP Ireland, Dr Eduardo Calmell, Dip. talk.start.para: â€”I thank the Senate. Without describing the principal conclusions set out in the document, I look forward to a future opportunity to commend these initiatives to strengthen UN peacekeeping, which I believe are complimentary to the report tabled by the Senate committee.

speech.speaker: Vallentine Sen J.

talk.start.para: â€”The subject of this report is highly topical, coming as it does after the creation of another United Nations (UN) peacekeeping force on the Iraq-Kuwait border and just before the controversial statement on defence, which the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) is to make tomorrow. I agree with many of the points made by the two previous speakers in discussing this idea of United Nations peacekeeping. It is important that we have bipartisan support in the Parliament. That is highly commendable. It is also necessary that we get a specific aim of support for United Nations peacekeeping forces incorporated into the aims of the Australian Defence Force (ADF) because that aim should certainly be there and be clearly specified. I also agree with Senator Teague that we need a secretariat in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade to coordinate the efforts of the Australian contribution to United Nations peacekeeping teams. Without a significant increase in the budget of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, this will not happen.

speech.para: If we got a one per cent cut in the budget of the Department of Defence, which transferred directly to the Foreign Affairs budget, it would result in a 5 per cent increase in the Foreign Affairs budget, which shows clearly the imbalance between those two departments. But that is what has to happen. We need a massive injection of funding into the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade before this kind of coordination can take place. I have always argued that, as part of a strategy of transarmament, for the time being Australia needs a much smaller military force which does not operate beyond our shores, apart from disaster relief operations-for example, in the Pacific and the Asian region, and in service with the United Nations, which is the subject of this report. Forces sent to serve with the United Nations should be non-combatant forces. I am pleased that Australia has a reasonably good record of participating in UN peacekeeping operations over the years. The members of the ADF who have participated in peacekeeping forces deserve our congratulations for having made a fine and positive contribution towards global security.

I believe that our role would be much more constructive if such forces, trained in a peacekeeping role, were part of a much greater commitment to the United Nations as a force for peacemaking as well as peacekeeping and not what we saw so disastrously played out in the last six months or so when the United Nations was bullied, badgered and misused as a war-making organisation rather than-as it was designed-a peacemaking organisation. I further believe that, if the military budget were substantially cut back, we could pass on some of the savings to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. As I said, a one per cent cut in the budget of the Department of Defence is a 5 per cent increase for Foreign Affairs. Apart from establishing a secretariat to coordinate peacekeeping efforts, that saving should be spent on the training of our diplomats in language and negotiating skills. The other very positive contribution of the Department of Foreign Affairs in peacemaking in our region would be in terms of development aid.

However, we live in a world where there are some 27 conflicts going on, many in the Asia-Pacific region. If there is to be a non-military resolution of some of these conflicts, there will be a role for peacekeeping forces in that process. Cambodia is an obvious example for such services, as Namibia was, and Colonel Crocker's testimony to the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade last December was valuable because it came from someone who served with the United Nations Transitions Assistance Group in Namibia.

I realise that there has been some controversy over proposals to extend our peacekeeping role, with some opposition coming from those who seem to believe that the ADF should maintain a sizeable force to defend our territory against potential hostile invaders, although I have never heard any suggestion of who these invaders might be apart from a mythical Kamaria, the country that was created for the purposes of the huge extravaganza, Kangaroo 89-the war games practised by the Australian defence forces.

In reality, Australia would be well served by a force that was simply at the service of the United Nations, much along the lines of the military of the Republic of Ireland. Senator Evans has said that Australia would be willing to support the establishment of an international training centre for peacekeeping troops. I think it would be better for us to contribute towards that with money saved from the Defence review cuts, as will be announced tomorrow, rather than merely keeping that money within the defence portfolio and spending it on unnecessary new hardware, such as a helicopter carrier, AWACS or two more submarines. It is a theft from the personnel side to the hardware side of the Defence budget, but without the real improvements that we need, which is a transfer of that money out of the Defence budget into Foreign Affairs.

United Nations peacekeeping operations are constantly hindered by a lack of money. The Namibia operation nearly fell apart through lack of advance funding. I am constantly amazed at how easily we find money for expensive new submarines or sending our Navy along with the forces of other countries to the Gulf to support the United States in a war-making exercise, yet we baulk at a contribution for real peacekeeping, let alone peacemaking. It shows how skewed our attitudes are and how we are much more prepared to go to war than to make peace. In this respect we are not the only country to have a warped sense of priorities. But a stronger commitment to the United Nations, and in particular its peacekeeping operations, would be a useful step towards redressing that imbalance.

I congratulate the Committee on its work and commend the report as useful reading in conjunction with tomorrow's statement on the future of the ADF and, hopefully, in the not so distant future, a new Defence White Paper to replace the somewhat obsolete one issued four years ago. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TELECOMMUNICATIONS BILL 1991
Mr President
Introduction
This Bill is the first in a package that I am introducing today affecting the telecommunications industry.
Before addressing the detail of the legislation it is useful to put these reforms in context.

The package gives effect to the reform package which the Prime Minister announced to the House of Representatives on 8 November last year. These telecommunications reforms are a central plank of the Hawke Government's Fourth Term commitment to micro-economic reform.

In introducing network competition into this industry, we will not just be improving the efficiency of a major domestic industry. We are also aiming to lift dramatically the performance of a key infrastructure industry.

All three of the current carriers (Telecom, OTC and AUSSAT) have a good technical record but have not been as responsive to customers, as innovative, or as export-oriented as they might have been. The carriers themselves recognise that they can do much better in terms of quality of service, productivity and price of services.

As long as the present carriers had a monopoly on the public switched trunk network, there was only modest pressure on them to minimise costs and to develop new products and markets. Telecom's and OTC's profitability has been largely based on historical accounting conventions and regulated monopoly pricing.
Competition across the network will force the merged entity to become more responsive to customers' needs, to reduce costs and to find better ways of providing existing services.

These reforms, though, go beyond the scope of structural reform, important though that is. The reason for the Government's focus on this industry is that we realise the critical long-term importance for Australia of getting the regulatory framework for this industry right.

First, telecommunications now provides a vital part of the infrastructure for all business operations, be they domestic or international. Having access to internationally competitive telecommunications services is therefore essential if our firms are to be able to meet their opposition in the market place.

Second, with the globalisation of the world economy, and the explosion in information technology, it has become increasingly obvious that telecommunications will be one of the key global industries of the next century in its own right.

New telecommunications services are revolutionising the way people do business. Mobile communications are growing at a phenomenal rate as are the range of value-added telecommunications services. The introduction of intelligent network services is ushering in a whole new range of sophisticated services for consumers. The future for telecommunications companies lies in integrating information technologies and telecommunications networks to connect people and information around the world. Remaining a simple provider of a telephone network is no longer an option for telecommunications companies that wish to survive, let alone prosper.

As a result, Governments worldwide are giving reform of the telecommunications sector a high priority. In turn, the liberalisation of telecommunications markets in Western countries is both advancing and responding to the trend towards globalisation of the industry.

The opportunities in this industry are enormous. The Asia-Pacific region is now experiencing a staggering increase in demand for telecommunications. Some estimates of this growth range as high as $130 billion in the next five years. Half of the world market in fibre optic cables, worth about $13 billion during the 1990s, will be laid in North and South Asia.

Australia has an excellent opportunity to exploit the anticipated growth in the region. We have the skills to design, plan, source, construct, operate and maintain telephone networks. Both Telecom and OTC have been successful in winning lucrative export contracts. It is important that we now build on this early success.

The next century's telecommunications industry will not only be global and dynamic, it will also be very competitive. Many of the world's major economies, including those of Japan and the United States have already broken up their telecommunications monopolies and introduced competition. The Government has carefully observed the experience in those countries and is convinced that its reform package does the job better.
Indeed, the package has received international acclaim as setting a new standard for approaches to telecommunications regulatory reform.

The Government strategy for the industry aims at producing important early efficiency gains for Australia. Beyond that our policy aims to position Australian telecommunications industry to be globally competitive to meet the challenges of the next century. The short and medium term gains for consumers and for the economy as a whole will build into a global impact over a decade or so.
The Government's strategy for achieving this has two basic, closely related features
- to introduce genuine and sustainable network competition for the benefit of the wider Australian economy; and
- to create a world class telecommunications company that has the ability and ethos to compete vigorously in what will be a key industry in a very competitive global environment.

A third important element of the Government's strategy that has yet to be finalised is the industry development arrangements that are to apply to the carriers. I am not in a position to give the precise details of these arrangements yet, as their final resolution is linked to the sale of AUSSAT.

One of the key selection criteria for the AUSSAT sale is that the bidders submit network development proposals that demonstrate how their business plan will also contribute to the development of wider Australian industry. There are two reasons for the importance which the Government places on these industry development proposals.

First, one of the main reasons for fundamentally restructuring the industry now is because we intend Australia to become a significant international telecommunications centre. To exploit fully the potential embodied in the other elements of the Government's reforms, it is essential that the carriers can turn to a dynamic Australian industry, with a research and development ethos that looks beyond Australia's boundaries, for necessary support.

An Australian industry that is innovative, forward-looking and has a commitment to excellence will also be necessary if we are to take full advantage of the opportunities that telecommunications will present in the next century.

Second, we recognise that Telecom's policies have made a major contribution to the development of a significant electronics industry in Australia and a research and development base. It is important that we build on this.

For these reasons, the Government will be examining bidders' proposed industry plans closely, with a view to formulating an appropriate industry development plan for inclusion in carriers' licence conditions.

In developing its framework for reform, the Government has remained mindful of the continuing social importance of telecommunications to Australian society. The Prime Minister has already guaranteed that no ordinary consumer of the phone system will be disadvantaged as a result of the introduction of competition. This assurance can be given for two main reasons.

First, the Government will preserve the merged Telecom/OTC in full public ownership. This enables the Government, in its capacity as shareholder as well as regulator, to ensure that the dominant network provider will continue to meet the Government's social objectives.

Second, the price cap arrangements for Telecom/OTC in the Australian and Overseas Telecommunications Corporation Bill 1991 (the AOTC Bill), in combination with the new entity's universal service obligation in the Telecommunications Bill, will ensure that the price benefits from competition will be distributed among consumers in an equitable way.

In fact, as I mentioned earlier, competition is likely to produce significant gains for all consumers. The overwhelming evidence from Western nations that have introduced network competition is that the real price of telecommunications services to business and household consumers has fallen, and the quality of service has improved.

The package of bills that the Government is introducing today is designed to maximise the benefits for Australia from its telecommunications industry. It will create a robust, globally competitive industry which is capable of seeing Australia into the next century. At the same time it will deliver improved services at lower prices to both the wider economy and ordinary householders.

The Telecommunications Bill 1991 replaces the Telecommunications Act 1989 (which is repealed by the Telecommunications (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1991). As such, the new Telecommunications Bill will provide the general regulatory framework for the provision of telecommunications facilities and services in Australia. The Bill is intended to cover the field in relation to the activities of licensed carriers. Certain specific regulatory matters relating to pricing arrangements that will apply only to the merged Telecom/OTC are dealt with under the AOTC Bill.

During the process of developing the Bill, an extensive process of public consultation has been undertaken. This has involved the circulation of an Exposure Draft of the legislation for public comment and consultation with key affected community groups. The Bill gives effect to the Government's November 1990 decisions in the context of a process which has taken into account legitimate concerns of the main groups with an interest in these matters.
General Principles
In policy terms, this Bill essentially does eight things:
1. it provides a framework for fostering genuine and sustainable network competition;
2. it provides a framework for fostering competition among all service providers (whether carriers or not), consistent with fostering sustainable network competition;

3. it ensures that certain specific social objectives in telecommunications (in particular delivery of the Universal Service Obligation and continued access by residential consumers to the option of untimed local calls) will continue to be met, but on a more secure legislative basis, and in a more efficient and transparent manner;
4. it provides for a licensing scheme for telecommunications carriers;
5. it allows, with minimum attendant bureaucracy, for greater public input into AUSTEL processes, commensurate with AUSTEL's enhanced regulatory role and powers;

6. it gives the carriers, on an equal footing, certain exclusive rights and powers. These include rights to install certain types of telecommunications facilities; and certain powers in relation to land and immunity from laws;
7. it provides an effective and appropriate enforcement regime; and

8. it re-enacts, with some additions and modifications, Parts 5 to 8 of the 1989 Act relating to technical regulation, AUSTEL investigations and AUSTEL's constitution. These provisions have generally worked well.
My following comments address the key features of the Bill against this framework.
Network Competition
The central feature of the Bill is the framework it provides for the introduction of genuine and sustainable network competition in the shortest time possible. It does this in three ways:
(i) Licensing

In contrast with the 1989 Act, the Bill allows for network competition by giving the Minister the power to license Australian trading corporations as ``general carriers''. A general carrier will have complete freedom to use whatever technology that carrier chooses to deliver the full range of telecommunications services (other than public mobile services, unless it also holds a public mobile licence). The general carriers, which are recognised in the objects of the Bill to be the primary providers of Australia's telecommunications networks and the primary providers of Australia's telecommunications services, will also have certain exclusive rights and powers. I shall discuss these rights and powers later. The Bill provides a similar licensing regime for public mobile carriers with respect to the primary supply of public mobile telecommunications services.

The Bill gives the Minister a wide discretion as to the grant of licences. As announced by the Prime Minister, the Government has taken the view that the goal of genuine and sustainable network competition is best served through licensing a single network competitor to the merged Telecom/OTC prior to full competition in 1997. The chief reason for this is that the Government has taken the view that the creation of one strong competitor is the best way of achieving genuine and sustainable network competition quickly in a market the size of Australia's. The aim is to ensure that by 1997 there is a significant, recognised network competitor to Telecom/OTC. Accordingly, on commencement of the Bill, the Government will only be licensing one competitor to Telecom/OTC.
The Government does not intend to issue further general carrier licences prior to 1997. It will issue only one further mobile licence prior to 1995.
The Bill therefore anticipates, but does not attempt to fully prescribe, the post-1997 environment. As already announced, this will be the subject of a review by the Government prior to 30 June 1997.
(ii) Access and interconnection
The second main feature of the Bill which is intended to promote network competition is the inter-carrier access arrangements in Part 8.

Overseas experience, particularly in the United States and the United Kingdom, has shown that the most important element in introducing genuine and sustainable network competition in the long run where there is an established telecommunications monopoly is to have appropriate interconnection and access arrangements between the carriers. It is widely acknowledged internationally that the arrangements proposed in the Government's decisions of November 1990 will be the most effective, pro-competitive and equitable interconnection arrangements that have been introduced anywhere in the world. The framework provided by Part 8 enables those decisions to be implemented while allowing flexibility for dealing with changing market circumstances, and technological developments.

The short term aim of the arrangements is to assist the second carrier in overcoming the formidable advantages associated with Telecom/OTC's control over the customer base, infrastructure and access to information so that the second carrier will be able to compete on terms that are, as nearly as possible, equal. The longer term aim is to create the basis for an open network framework for the provision of telecommunications services.

Part 8 creates two broad categories of access rights. The first is the basic right of any carrier to interconnect its network to that of any other carrier, and to have that other carrier carry and complete calls on its behalf. This right is fully mutual between the carriers and also applies between the general and public mobile carriers. The second, or ``supplementary'' class of rights covers matters relating to supplementary services affecting a carrier's control over the customer base. This is capable of being made carrier specific and in practice will apply only to the provision of supplementary services by Telecom/OTC while it remains the dominant carrier.

The Part also allows for disallowable Ministerial determinations on special pricing arrangements that are to apply between the carriers. This power will be used to set out the details that implement the general principle that the second carrier should have access to Telecom/OTC's facilities and supplementary services at directly attributable incremental cost following AUSTEL's report to the Government on this issue in June.

These rights will be given practical effect by giving a carrier the right to ask AUSTEL to arbitrate on a dispute that it has with another carrier concerning access and interconnection matters. The Bill provides for extensive procedures governing the way in which such arbitrations are to be conducted, although the general principle is that they are to be conducted in a way that is fair, just, informal, economical and quick. An arbitration will generally be conducted in private. However there is provision for AUSTEL to conduct a public inquiry on a particular issue where AUSTEL considers that this will have a significant and direct impact on consumers, and that the inquiry will not significantly delay the arbitration.

Carriers will, in effect, be required to register all access agreements with AUSTEL. These agreements will be public, to the extent that normal commercial confidentiality principles permit. So as to ensure that all agreements actually promote the long term interests of consumers of telecommunications services, AUSTEL will have the ability to refuse to register an access agreement where in AUSTEL's opinion it does not further the objects of Part 8.
(iii) New AUSTEL functions
The third way in which network competition will be enhanced is by giving AUSTEL a charter with a number of pro-competitive functions.

The most important of these new functions is given in clause 37 which charges AUSTEL with the function of promoting competition within the regulatory framework established by the Act. In relation to network competition, AUSTEL has the role of promoting competition between the carriers; of protecting carriers from the misuse of market power by other carriers; and of arbitrating disputes between the carriers. AUSTEL is, therefore, being given a clear mandate to create the conditions necessary for genuine and sustainable network competition between the carriers and is being authorised to take appropriate action to ensure that this occurs. AUSTEL's role and powers in this respect are in addition to the normal application of the Trade Practices Act 1974 and the usual powers of the Trade Practices Commission.
AUSTEL is also being given a number of other new powers and functions which are related to the promotion of competition.

The most important of these is AUSTEL's powers in relation to accounting and charging procedures in Division 5 of Part 5. This requires AUSTEL to draw up a chart of accounts and a cost allocation manual. The primary function of these documents will be to ensure full accounting separation of those areas of a carrier's activities that do not face strong competition. AUSTEL will be able to decide on the extent to which a carrier should be made subject to the accounting separation regime. This is because it is likely that for the first few years of its operations the second network carrier will face strong competition from Telecom/OTC in all of its main business activities. There may, however, be reason to apply a degree of accounting separation to the second carrier when the third mobile operator commences operations in 1993, or in order to safeguard satellite service customers in the initial stages of competition.

Clause 39 of the Bill gives AUSTEL the function of managing numbering.
