AUSTEL will be required to establish a numbering plan for telecommunications services provided across carrier networks, consulting where appropriate with the Standards Association of Australia which also has a role in relation to certain services. In establishing the plan, AUSTEL is required to have regard to its other relevant functions which would include promoting competition and protecting consumers.

A further AUSTEL function given by clauses 40 and 399 will be that of reporting annually to the Minister on the operation of competitive safeguards and carrier performance. As the Minister is required to table the report in Parliament this will ensure that the Parliament and the public are aware of how the competitive safeguards regime is working out in practice. It also ensures that AUSTEL maintains an appropriate level of interest in competition and carrier performance. The fact that this reporting obligation, which also has a consumer protection dimension which I will discuss later, has the status of an AUSTEL function indicates the importance which is placed on it.
Service provider competition

While the main long-term goal of the new regulatory framework lies in fostering network competition, the Government has also moved to foster competition from other service providers, in a manner consistent with that primary goal. The chief reasons for this are to encourage innovation and diversity in the provision of telecommunications services, and to give the fullest possible degree of flexibility to consumers in the way in which they use telecommunications services derived from carriers.
The Bill has a number of features for achieving this end.
(i) Resale

One of the key differences between this Bill and the 1989 Act, both in policy and conceptual terms, has flowed from the Government's decision to remove all restrictions on resale on domestic and international telecommunications capacity currently contained in the Telecommunications Act 1989.

Under the 1989 Act, only the carriers are permitted to provide so-called ``reserved'' services. Even where a person obtains a basic service from a carrier, that person cannot use the basic service to supply another service unless that service can be classified as a ``value-added'' service.

The Government's resale decision removes that artificial distinction, and allows for much more efficient use of capacity within private networks. This is a very significant liberalisation of existing arrangements and the approach of the Bill to resale is among the most liberal, if not the most liberal, in the world.

The decision to allow resale is given effect by ensuring that the Bill does not apply any restrictions on the supply of services other than those contained in an AUSTEL class licence issued under Part 10 of the Bill. These restrictions are primarily intended to deal with
(a) technical and operational matters, so as to ensure the technical integrity and efficiency of public telecommunications networks is maintained and relevant international standards are met;

(b) the provision of international services, to prevent the misuse of market power by foreign carriers through resale; and to ensure that the agreements that carriers enter into with international cabling consortia cannot be used to achieve effective bypass of the carriers; and

(c) services provided over radiocommunications facilities that are connected to a carrier's network and that have been privately installed. The reason for this restriction is that the Bill, again in contrast to existing arrangements, allows complete freedom for anyone to install radiocommunications facilities and otherwise use radiocommunications services. In the absence of a ``safety net'' there is a danger that such facilities might be used to erode significantly the practical value of the carriers' reserved rights.
(ii) Unbundling of basic carriage services

The second main feature of the Bill designed to promote competition from service providers is the approach in Division 2 of Part 9 towards the controlled unbundling of ``basic carriage services'' (or BCS). BCS is one of the central concepts in the Bill, so I will take some time to explain its functions.

The decision to allow full resale has essentially been implemented by framing the carriers' reservations (apart from public mobile services and satellite services) in facilities terms, and imposing no restrictions on the persons who may provide services over those facilities. This fulfils the twin objectives of giving the carriers' licences practical value, while allowing resale, as long as the carriers are allowed genuine control over their facilities and are able to exploit the economies of scale and scope inherent in them, at least to provide basic connectivity and carriage services. Clause 237 underlines the carriers' prerogatives in this regard by giving them the ability to refuse to supply particular BCSs that are not included in the carrier's BCS tariff.

The BCS concept is essentially a functional description, from the point of view of the service as delivered to the consumer, of basic connectivity and carriage services, on which all commercial telecommunications services are necessarily built. The Bill calls all services that are not BCSs ``higher level services'' (or HLS). The conceptual distinction in the Bill, and the basic reasons for it, reflect the thinking proposed by AUSTEL in its Report to the Minister for Transport and Communications on Resale of 14 December 1990.

This ability of a carrier to refuse to supply BCSs, while necessary to maintain the practical value of the carrier's rights and thereby to promote network competition, nevertheless has the potential to have significant anti-competitive consequences in markets for other telecommunications services. To address this, the Bill has a procedure under which AUSTEL, on its own initiative or on application, can direct a dominant carrier to supply a particular BCS. This ``unbundling'' regime has two main purposes.
First, it will prevent a dominant carrier that is supplying a BCS from precipitately withdrawing that service where this will have significant consequences for existing users of that service.

Second, it will allow for a structured process for ``unbundling'' of BCSs. ``Unbundling'' in this context means requiring a carrier to make available ``lower level'' BCSs that are necessary to provide other telecommunications services. This process will promote competition by allowing service providers to use these ``building blocks'' to construct other telecommunications services from an equal base.

It is, however, important that such unbundling of BCSs actually benefits the long term interests of consumers by taking proper account of what is technically practicable, and of the need to promote genuine and sustainable network competition between the carriers by ensuring that their rights have practical value.

Once a service has been ``unbundled'' in this way, a directed carrier will have to supply that service on reasonable terms, and will be required to supply the service to itself on the same terms as to all other service providers. This requirement applies automatically (but in a more limited way) to any BCSs that a carrier itself is using to supply an HLS.
(iii) Safeguards for service providers

The third main way in which the Bill fosters service competition from service providers is by giving them, along with other consumers of telecommunications services, a number of targeted safeguards against particular abuses of market power by carriers.

The first safeguard is that a carrier that is in a position to dominate a market for a telecommunications service will not be able to discriminate between customers in that market unless that discrimination can be justified on a cost basis. Furthermore, carriers in general will not be permitted to discriminate against a person for the reason that the person is or wants to be a service provider.

The second safeguard is that carriers will be required to tariff their BCSs, and will have incentives to tariff their HLSs. This will make it easier for consumers to obtain information about competing carrier services, and in combination with the discrimination provisions, will provide incentives for a dominant carrier to keep its charges down. A carrier that is in a position to dominate a market for a BCS will be required to charge strictly in accordance with its tariff. A non-dominant carrier will be able to charge below its tariff but not above it. The existing carriers will have 6 months in which to tariff all their existing services following commencement of the Act.
The third safeguard is that the carriers are under an obligation to connect a service provider unless another carrier is supplying the connection service.
Social Objectives

While the main thrust of the Bill is directed towards introducing a more competitive framework for supplying telecommunications services as the best means of meeting consumers' interests in the long term, the reforms also aim to improve the regulatory arrangements for delivering certain key objectives.
(i) The Universal Service Obligation

The most important of these is Telecom's Universal Service Obligation (USO). In his November 1990 Statement, the Minister for Transport and Communications gave the commitment, on behalf of the Government, that:
- community service obligations (CSOs) would be maintained, in particular to rural and regional areas, to pensioners and to people with disabilities;
- Telecom/OTC would be required to continue to provide and maintain its basic telephone services to residential and business customers throughout Australia; and

- the management and funding of community service obligations would be considered by an Interdepartmental Committee chaired by the Department, and that the IDC, in preparing its report, would have regard to the notation to the ALP policy that the cost for the competitor to interconnect into Telecom/OTC's network should underpin Telecom/OTC's community service obligations on a pro-rata basis.

After full consideration of the IDC's report, the Government decided that the most appropriate and least administratively-complex way of giving effect to its aims in the continued funding and delivery of universal telephone service would be:
- to obligate Telecom/OTC to continue to provide a standard telephone service between places in Australia including payphones

- to require the second carrier to pay Telecom/OTC a fee which covers an equitable share of Telecom/OTC's costs of fulfilling its universal service obligation with the payment to be in direct proportion to minutes of interconnect time between each carrier's trunk/international network and all local access networks.

Part 13 of the Bill gives effect to these decisions. This empowers the Minister to declare a carrier to be the Universal Service Carrier for Australia. Telecom/OTC will be designated as this carrier. Clause 292 makes it a ``prescribed carrier obligation'' of the Universal Service Carrier's licence to fulfil the USO. The USO has two strands:
- the obligation to supply the standard telephone service to people in Australia; and

- to supply payphones in a way that ensures that they are reasonably accessible to all people in Australia on an equitable basis. This can be backed up by a Ministerial determination that payphones must be installed in specified places.

This has the effect of placing the USO on a more secure legislative basis that under current arrangements, where their management and delivery are largely at Telecom's discretion. This is because any person may complain to AUSTEL about a possible breach of this licence condition. If AUSTEL finds that the carrier has unreasonably failed to fulfil its USO, AUSTEL must direct the carrier to fulfil it.

The net costs incurred in fulfilling the universal service obligation are to be calculated by participating carriers using a long term avoidability methodology. These are the costs that will be used by AUSTEL, along with the number of minutes of interconnect time, to determine the pro-rata contribution of all participating carriers in the levy. For practical purposes, interconnect time is to be measured as the number of minutes of timed traffic interconnected by a carrier.

The Government decided, in December 1989, that Telecom is to use the avoidable cost approach in determining the costs incurred in delivering universal service. Accordingly, this Bill places in legislation the requirement that a universal service carrier (in this case, Telecom/OTC), calculate its net costs using a long term avoidable cost approach. This will require Telecom/OTC, in calculating its USO costs in a particular area, only to take into account the justifiable net costs it need not have incurred had the services not been provided to that area.

The arrangements, as proposed, give AUSTEL the responsibility for auditing the net costs and timed traffic figures provided by the carriers. However, with the Government's dual aim in mind of, on the one hand, delivering the universal service obligation to the highest standard and at the least cost possible and, on the other, of making the arrangements as open and transparent as possible, the Bill also requires AUSTEL to make available to the public, and to participating carriers, information about the basis and methods of assessment, in as much detail as it thinks appropriate, bearing in mind the need to protect a carrier's valid commercial or other interests.
(ii) Untimed local calls

Clauses 72 and 73 make it a licence condition of all general carriers that they offer residential customers continued access to untimed local calls as a payment option. In the case of Telecom/OTC the price of Fuese untimed local calls will be governed by the operation of the price caps.
(iii) Quality of Service

AUSTEL is to be given the additional specific consumer protection function of developing indicative quality of service, or performance standards relating to the standard telephone service; services ancillary to the standard telephone services (such as directory assistance); and any other services AUSTEL considers appropriate. While these standards will not be binding on a carrier (unless they are included in licence conditions), AUSTEL will gather data and will use these standards as a key test of carrier performance for the purposes of its annual report to the Minister on carrier performance.
Licensing

One of the important features of the new Bill is that it establishes a licensing regime for carriers with broad discretions for the Minister to impose and vary licence conditions. However, it is important to note that a number of key licence conditions, in particular those relating to the USO and untimed local calls, have been included in the Bill and therefore will not be capable of change, except by the Parliament.
Other matters likely to be dealt with in licence conditions are listed in subclause 63(4). They include
- the term of a licence
- industry development
- foreign ownership or control
- supplementary access rights (for interconnection purposes)
- consumer inquiry and complaints procedures (such as a requirement that a carrier develop a Code of Practice for handling such inquiries and complaints)
- compliance with technical standards
- law enforcement issues
- geographical limitations on a licensee's scope of action

It is also intended that there will be licence obligations on AUSSAT relating to Remote Commercial Television Services, the ABC's Homestead and Community Broadcasting Satellite Service, and defence and aviation requirements.

A number of issues on this list (which is not exhaustive) are clearly going to require further detailed work. Others will be issues to be negotiated during the sale process for AUSSAT and will be the subject of a commercial contract.

The Government recognises that there will be many occasions where a public process would be desirable to assist in clarifying the issues involved with important licence conditions. Clause 69 provides for a Minister to request AUSTEL to conduct a public inquiry before the Minister varies an important licence condition.

The Government also recognises that carriers have a legitimate interest in regulatory stability in order that they can make sensible investment decisions. To this end, clause 68 requires a Minister to consult with a carrier before varying a licence condition. Clause 70 allows a Minister to enter into an agreement with the carrier about the way in which the Minister will exercise a particular licensing power. At the end of the day, though, it is not appropriate to unduly fetter the Minister's ability to impose or vary licence conditions as there may be important issues of public policy at stake.
Public Processes
In general the Bill adopts a more open approach to policy formulation than the 1989 Act. The following measures have been adopted (in addition to those in the 1989 Act) to achieve this:

(a) A new Part 14 of the Bill has been added to give AUSTEL a simple and straightforward public inquiry process. This is largely intended to codify AUSTEL's existing practices, although some new features of the Bill (e.g. unbundling of BCSs) will depend on a public inquiry.

(b) AUSTEL will be required to keep a simple and publicly accessible register of complaints and investigations under Part 15 of the Act. This will also assist AUSTEL in meeting its annual reporting obligations.
(c) AUSTEL will be required to keep a register of access agreements between the carriers.

(d) Carriers will be required to keep a publicly available schedule of BCS tariffs and to file these with AUSTEL. They will have substantial incentives to include their standard terms and conditions in these tariffs.
Carriers' exclusive rights, powers and immunities
Under the Bill the carriers' exclusive rights are essentially based on a facilities reservation only, rather than a services and facilities reservation as in the 1989 Act.

The general carriers will have the exclusive right to install ``line links'' between ``distinct places''. A line link essentially is any combination of connected wires or cables that is used or intended for use in carrying electromagnetic energy. A ``distinct place'' will be
- any freehold or leasehold title; or

- any combination of adjoining freehold or leasehold titles that are occupied or principally used by the same person; or that are the subject of a Ministerial determination (which is subject to certain limitations).

Division 2 of Part 2 makes it clear that the network termination point (or network boundary) for a line link in a distinct place will be the main distribution frame or telephone socket as appropriate. The regulations will allow this to be changed both to take account of changing technology, and to give effect to the Government's decision that from 1 July 1993, the network termination point for new telephone services be the property boundary, unless the customer contracts with a licensed carrier to supply an alternative point within the property.

The general carriers will also have the exclusive right to be the ``primary suppliers'' of services that use satellite facilities. I say primary supply because, of course, resale of such services will be permitted.
Public mobile carriers will have exclusive rights to supply public mobile telecommunications services.
The formulation of the reservations based on these concepts remedies a range of problems under the existing Act and allows for an appropriate level of flexibility.
The exceptions to the carriers' reservations remain broadly as they are under the 1989 Act with the following extensions
(a) the Defence forces and the Civil Aviation Authority have been given special purpose exceptions to the carriers' reservations
(b) a person who has an exception to a carrier's reservation will now be able to supply a service to a carrier or dispose of his or her facilities to a carrier

(c) the exception granted to broadcasters has been widened to allow broadcasters to supply programs to each other by means of their own exempted line links and to use those line links in relation to the supply of Ancillary Communications Services

(d) the Government's international Private Satellite Earth Station policy has been formalised as an exception to the carriers' satellite reservation. Any person will be able to obtain an international satellite service from any satellite operator (whether or not a carrier). For the purposes of resale, these services will be treated in a manner that is directly analogous to other interconnected radcom services, that is they will be subject to use restrictions under AUSTEL's services class licence

(e) AUSTEL will be able to issue authorisations, under Ministerial direction (which is subject to certain constraints), for persons other than carriers to install exempted classes of line links or use satellite services.

The existing land access power of Telecom under Part 8 of the Australian Telecommunications Corporation Act 1989 will be extended to the general carriers with compensation agreed or assessed with a right of appeal to a State or Federal Court This is essential to carrier activities and to allow the second carrier to roll out its network.

Telecom's pre-existing immunity from suit is removed. Any exclusion or limitation of liability becomes a matter of normal contractual principles and negotiation. AUSTEL is empowered to determine appropriate ceilings in respect of tort liability.

Telecom's exemption from State and Territory laws has been replaced by a more focussed and balanced regime. Essentially, the regulations will be able to specify that certain network related activities are exempt from State and Territory laws, and a carrier will be able to engage in those activities, despite any State or Territory law. This will be balanced by a National Code of Practice for the carriers, to be discussed with the States and Territories, which will impose parallel obligations on the carriers to the extent that this is warranted. However, a carrier will not be subject to any State or Territory laws that discriminate against the carriers.
Enforcement

The Bill contains new enforcement mechanisms that reflect the changed nature of the regulatory environment. Essentially, the chief sanction against a carrier is based on AUSTEL's ability to direct a carrier. The sanction for a carrier failing to comply with an AUSTEL direction is enforced by AUSTEL having the ability to take the carrier to court for a civil pecuniary penalty of up to $5 million, an injunction or a declaration.

AUSTEL enforces licence conditions in a similar way. First by investigating to satisfy itself that a breach has occurred, then issuing a direction to the carrier to rectify the breach. It is only if the carrier does not rectify the breach that AUSTEL can go to Court. The Minister also has the power to enforce licence conditions by taking a carrier directly to Court (the same penalties apply) without the need for an investigation. However, this is intended to be a reserve power.

AUSTEL has also been given certain limited powers of entry and seizure in relation to its technical regulation functions. The reason for this is that AUSTEL's practical ability to enforce its technical regulation powers are, under the 1989 Act very limited. These additional powers are necessary to give meaning to AUSTEL's function in this area.
Re-enactment of existing parts

Essentially, Parts 5 to 8 of the 1989 Act relating to technical regulation, AUSTEL investigations, AUSTEL's constitution, and miscellaneous matters have been re-enacted. The following changes are worth noting, however.

With technical regulation, AUSTEL has been given the power, at Ministerial direction, to formulate technical network standards. It is a condition of a carrier's licence that the carrier comply with any such standards.

AUSTEL has also been given the power, at its own initiative, on application or on Ministerial direction to exempt certain types of equipment and customer cabling from the scope of technical regulation requirements where such equipment does not have the ability to affect the integrity or efficiency of a carrier's network.

When the Bill comes into force the Minister has indicated that he intends to issue a direction to AUSTEL under relevant provisions to exempt computing equipment and equipment in broadcasters studios that are beyond an appropriate line isolating device.

In relation to AUSTEL's Constitution, there are some minor changes relating to AUSTEL membership and AUSTEL finances. In relation to membership, the changes are intended to clarify the status of associate members. The new provisions relating to AUSTEL finances are standard provisions relating to the financial arrangements for statutory authorities.
Other issues

There are two other features of the Bill that deserve comment. The first relates to the Minister's general powers of direction to AUSTEL under clauses 49 and 50 of the Bill. These powers of direction re-enact sections 28 and 29 of the 1989 Act essentially without change. These powers of direction were somewhat controversial at the time of passage of the 1989 Act, however their use has attracted no criticism subsequently. Section 28 has been used to give effect to the Industry Development Arrangements for customer equipment. Section 29 has been used to direct AUSTEL to undertake a number of studies and reports. These provisions play an important function in ensuring that AUSTEL remains accountable and takes account of the full range of policy perspectives.

Another feature worthy of note is the International Code of Practice in Division 4 of Part 5. This is intended to give the Government flexibility in dealing with possible misuses of market power by foreign carriers that become possible with the advent of full resale. It is the Government's intention, however, to impose minimal restrictions on those carriers and trades where reciprocal rights of resale are permitted.
Financial Impact

It is estimated that the measures in this Bill which give AUSTEL new functions will require additional expenditure on AUSTEL of $4.6 million in the 1991/92 financial year and $3.8 million in the following financial year.

It is expected, however, that the increase in expenditure on AUSTEL will be more than offset by the additional revenue raised from the carrier licence fees imposed by the Telecommunications (Carrier Licence Fees) Bill 1991, and the fees imposed under the Telecommunications (Application Fees) Bill 1991 and the Telecommunications (Numbering Fees) Bill 1991.

The measures in the Bill which introduce competition are expected to have a major financial impact on Australia's telecommunications industry, with new players entering the market and greater efficiency in the provision of services.

The increased efficiency in the telecommunications industry and the new services likely to be offered by the players in the industry as a result of this Bill are designed to enhance the long term competitiveness of the entire Australian economy.

In terms of financial impact on the ordinary customer, no householder or ordinary subscriber in rural areas will be disadvantaged by the reforms. All residential consumers who currently have access to untimed local calls will continue to have that access.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill.
TELECOMMUNICATIONS (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1991
Mr President

This Bill is a companion bill to the Telecommunications Bill 1991 and provides for the repeal of the Telecommunications Act 1989 and transitional provisions and consequential amendments relating to that repeal. It also provides for the repeal of the Australian Telecommunications Corporation Act 1989 and the OTC Act 1946 consequential to the Australian and Overseas Telecommunications Corporation Bill 1991, and amendments to other Commonwealth legislation consequential to that bill.
FINANCIAL IMPACT

I have outlined the financial impact of the package as a whole when introducing the Telecommunications Bill 1991. The measures in this Bill are not expected to have any identifiable financial impact on their own account.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this bill.
TELECOMMUNICATIONS (APPLICATION FEES) BILL 1991
Mr President

This is a companion piece of legislation to the Telecommunications Bill 1991. It provides for the setting of fees for a range of applications made to the Australian Telecommunications Authority (AUSTEL), and updates previous legislation to this effect.

Fees will continue to be payable in relation to the categories of applications for which fees have been payable up to now will continue including applications relating to customer equipment permits, cabling licences and test house accreditation. Fees will also apply to the same types of applications relating to eligible services under the Telecommunications Act 1991 as applied to applications relating to value added and private network services under the Telecommunications Act 1989.

In addition, fees will apply to applications for authorisations for the use of certain line links and satellite facilities, and for enrolment as a supplier of public access cordless telephone services.
FINANCIAL IMPACT
This bill will allow AUSTEL to recover its costs in processing these applications.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this bill.
TELECOMMUNICATIONS (CARRIER
LICENCE FEES) BILL 1991
Mr President

This is a companion piece of legislation to the Telecommunications Bill 1991, and provides that the holders of general telecommunications licences or public mobile licences must pay a fee to the Commonwealth for the licence.

The amounts of the fees, or the formula by which the fees are determined, are to be set by regulation. It is intended that the amount or the formula determined by the regulations should represent a reasonable estimate of the administrative costs borne by AUSTEL in directly regulating the activities of the carriers. Fees prescribed for the holders of telecommunications licences may differ from those provided for the holders of public mobile licences.

There is an upper limit on the total of the fees that may become payable under this legislation in any one financial year. This limit is the amount of AUSTEL's appropriation from the Consolidated Revenue Fund for the previous financial year.
FINANCIAL IMPACT

The purpose of the carrier licence fees is to recover regulatory administration costs associated with AUSTEL's work on carrier regulation. It would therefore be inappropriate for the total of the licence fees raised from the carriers to exceed AUSTEL's total cost.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this bill.
TELECOMMUNICATIONS (NUMBERING FEES) BILL 1991
Mr President

This is a companion piece of legislation to the Telecommunications Bill 1991 and provides for the payment of fees to the Commonwealth for the allocation of numbers for public telecommunications services. The allocation of numbers will be the responsibility of AUSTEL under Division 2 of Part 11 of the Telecommunications Act 1991.
The bill provides for different levels of fees to be charged for ordinary and ``special'' numbers.

The fees for numbers will be fixed by, or determined under, regulation. The maximum fee that can be fixed for ordinary numbers will be $2,000. In the case of special numbers, the regulations will be able to provide for a premium, a tender process, or a public auction for fixing the fee.
FINANCIAL IMPACT

It is expected that this bill will generate significant Commonwealth revenue, particularly in the sale of ``special'' numbers. This revenue will contribute towards offsetting Commonwealth expenditure on AUSTEL.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this bill.
TELECOMMUNICATIONS (UNIVERSAL SERVICE LEVY) BILL 1991
Mr President

This is a companion piece of legislation to the Telecommunications Bill 1991, and imposes a levy in connection with ensuring the future delivery of the universal service obligation in Australia as defined in the Telecommunications Bill 1991.
The bill allows for a carrier to be declared to be a participating carrier for a particular financial year, and for a carrier to be liable to pay an amount equal to the carriers levy debit balance.

Details of the assessment, collection and distribution of the universal service levy are contained in Part 13 of the Telecommunications Bill 1991, as is the formula to be used by AUSTEL to calculate levy credits and debits. Briefly, the formula allows levy credits and debits to be calculated based on the net costs incurred by carriers in delivering the universal service obligation, and apportioning liability for those costs to each carrier according to minutes of interconnect time. A levy is payable, therefore, only where a carrier's liability outweighs its net costs incurred.

In combination with the Telecommunications Bill 1991, this bill will enable effect to be given to the Government's commitment to the future funding and delivery of the universal service obligation, and to its decision that the second telecommunications carrier should contribute on a pro-rata basis to the costs of providing universal service.
FINANCIAL IMPACT

The relative contributions of participating carriers will depend on the carriers identifying loss making areas of their operations where they have a universal service obligation, the extent of those losses, and the amount of interconnect time between the carriers' trunk and international networks and all local access networks. Accordingly, it is impossible to quantify what amounts will be payable under the levy. It can be expected, however, that as the second general carrier's business grows, its contribution to cover the net cost of lossmaking services will increase.
I commend the bill to the Senate and I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this bill.
AUSTRALIAN AND OVERSEAS TELECOMMUNICATIONS CORPORATION BILL 1991
Mr President

The primary purpose of this bill is to permit the amalgamation of the Australian Telecommunications Corporation (Telecom) and OTC Limited (OTC). The new corporate entity will be named the Australian and Overseas Telecommunications Corporation. The merger was one of the central elements of the Prime Minister's Parliamentary Statement of 8 November 1990 on Transport and Telecommunications reform. Further details were spelled out in the announcement of the Minister for Transport and Communications of the same date.
This bill requires that the new company remain in full public ownership.
It has been a central tenet throughout the Government's reform processes that a strong public sector presence in Australian telecommunications be maintained.

The decision to retain the merged company in public ownership will enable the Government to meet the guarantee that no householder or ordinary subscriber in rural areas will be disadvantaged by the introduction of competition.

It is only through public ownership that the Government can satisfactorily ensure that the requirement that a standard telephone service be available to all residential and business customers throughout Australia is met. Public ownership allows direct control over this universal service obligation to the clear benefit of the people of Australia. Privatisation of our national carrier would seriously weaken the Government's ability to require that carrier to continue to meet important social goals.
Public ownership also maintains a capacity for the Government to exercise appropriate oversight of the new company's market conduct with respect to the emergence of competition.

Retention of the new company in full public ownership will also mean that Australian taxpayers will continue to receive dividends in their capacity as shareholders. This means that future generations of Australians will continue to benefit from the rapid growth in telecommunications which this package of reforms will engender.

The major focus of this package is introducing competition, not privatisation for its own sake. The experience of other countries that have simultaneously attempted to privatise telecommunications companies and to introduce competition has been that competition has always been compromised. This package reflects our view that the fundamental issue is to get the regulatory framework right.
The Government's decision to merge Telecom and OTC followed consideration last year of the review of the ownership and structural arrangements among the Government owned telecommunications carriers.

The Government intends that the merger of Telecom and OTC not represent a mere amalgamation of the two carriers. It is far more than that. The Government is seeking to bring these two carriers together to create a new entity with a streamlined organisational structure, which is capable of being not only an efficient national carrier but a major player in the telecommunications trade in this region.

This company must operate in a vigorous new competitive environment. It must therefore develop a genuinely competitive ethos and an overriding commitment to meeting the needs of Australian users. To do this, it is essential that the board and management of the new company pursue the achievement of standards of technical quality, service and price which are not only better than those achieved by Telecom and OTC individually but are equal to the best in the world.

It is expected that significant synergies will be realised by removing the current distinction between domestic and international telecommunication services. A united entity, exploiting the existing abilities and expertise of Telecom and OTC, will be able to provide customers with a comprehensive, globally interconnected service.

It will also provide the foundation for an increased export focus within the Australian telecommunications industry by building on the successes so far of Telecom Australia International and OTC International.

The first stage in the merging of Telecom and OTC commenced with the appointment in December 1990 of an ``Interim Board'' comprising representatives of both the Telecom and OTC Boards. The Interim Board's primary task is to advise the Government on the corporate and management structure which will best facilitate the merger of the two organisations and to prepare Telecom and OTC to face a competitive environment.

The Interim Board is progressively refining its position on a proposed structure for the new company. The Board aims to ensure that the new structure will provide focus, accountability, and authority so as to achieve strategic business objectives. As well, the structure of the new company will promote transparency of revenues, costs, and assets to support accountability. A further aim will be to ensure that the new company's performance in regard to prices, costs, productivity, and quality of service is comparable with the best in the world.

The new entity will be established, as a company with share capital, under normal Corporations Law processes. Consequently, the fiduciary responsibilities of the directors of the company will be the same as those applying to directors of private sector companies.

The operation of this bill is directed at vesting in the new company all the rights, property, staff and liabilities of Telecom and OTC. It is the intention of the relevant provisions of the bill, that the new company be recognised as the legal successor of Telecom and OTC. In effect, the new company ``stands in the shoes'' of Telecom and OTC in respect of all their contractual arrangements.
Provision is expressly made to ensure preservation of the rights, accrued entitlements and continuity of service of all Telecom and OTC staff transferred to the new company.

It is a deliberate policy decision of the Government that the merger provisions of the bill will not commence until a day to be fixed by proclamation rather than commencing automatically after 6 months from the passage of the bill. This is so that proclamation can be made to coincide with the certification by AUSTEL that interconnection and equal access arrangements between the networks of Telecom and OTC and the second carrier are fully in place in all capital cities and that a timetable for the early installation of such arrangements for provincial cities has been agreed to by Telecom and OTC. This approach recognises that the terms and conditions of interconnection are fundamental to the successful launch of the second carrier. In short, there is a powerful incentive on Telecom and OTC to move quickly on interconnection as they will be required to continue to operate as separate entities until the AUSTEL certification is issued.

I would like to emphasise that this merger is not simply about subsuming one government-owned organisation into another. The merger is concerned with the creation of a new organisation that will be much more than a simple ``adding together'' of OTC and Telecom. The Minister for Transport and Communications has previously stated that the Government is interested in achieving the creation of a dynamic, customer-driven, commercial entity. I reiterate that our goal is exactly that, and I am confident that it will be realised.

The bill I am about to introduce empowers the Minister for Transport and Communications to give directions to the new company in relation to its operations when it is in the public interest to do so. This emphasises the Government's commitment to providing the Australian consumer with the most efficient and responsive telecommunications carrier possible.

Nevertheless, this provision should be viewed as primarily providing the Minister with a reserve power. Indeed the whole thrust of our competitive reforms will ensure that the Board, management and staff of the new company will have every incentive to ensure that the new company performs efficiently and is responsive to customer requirements. If the new company is not responsive to the community's expectations it will inevitably see its market share and market power diminish.

The bill also empowers the Minister for Transport and Communications to regulate charges levied by Telecom or OTC (or by the new company after the merger) for a telecommunications service or facility. This provision continues existing arrangements. At present, Telecom and OTC are subject to price cap arrangements which work to keep average price increases to consumers well below the inflation rate and thereby encourage Telecom and OTC to actively pursue improvements in their productivity.
In the case of Telecom, control is also exercised through the notification and disallowance powers of the Minister in relation to a number of reserved services.

Both the price cap and notification and disallowance arrangements will continue until 1 July 1992, when the number of services regulated by notification and disallowance of charges will be reduced, with greater emphasis on the price cap mechanism.

The price control mechanisms are included in this bill rather than in the Telecommunications bill because they apply only to Telecom and OTC (and, following the merger, the new company). This reflects the fact that as long as Telecom and OTC retain substantial market power it is necessary and appropriate to be able to influence their pricing practices. It can be expected that as the market presence and power of the second and subsequent network providers grows, the need for these provisions will diminish. Ultimately they will be repealed.

In opening the telecommunications sector to more competition, the Government has been conscious of the need to create, as far as possible, a fair basis for the efficient emergence of competition between the two general carriers. Accordingly, the Government gave careful consideration to which laws and policies should, or should not, apply to the new company.
Because it is being established as a company under the Corporations Law, the new company will be automatically subject to certain laws which Telecom, as a statutory authority, was not.

At the same time, some exemptions from Commonwealth, State and Territory laws are carried over in this bill and further exemptions may be accorded by regulation. Such exemptions will be kept to a minimum and will only be provided in cases where exemption raises no significant problems but where the cost to the new company of complying with the particular legislation would be particularly onerous and would result in substantial flow-on to customers; where the introduction of effective competition would be hampered; or where an exemption is essential in order to satisfy other Government policy objectives.

A provision in the bill also requires that the new company submit its annual report and financial statements to the Minister for Transport and Communications. The Government will require that the directors of the company will include in those financial statements a full consolidation of the accounts of all subsidiaries and all joint ventures (including where the company only has a minority shareholding) of the new company. I consider it entirely appropriate that a Commonwealth-owned company should conform with the highest accounting and corporate conduct standards possible. In any event, under forthcoming amendments to the Corporations Law covering consolidation of subsidiaries, the new company will be obliged to compile financial statements in this form.
Financial Impact
Direct Commonwealth outlays will be minimal, being essentially limited to the costs of establishing and registering the new company.

As regards additional revenue to the Commonwealth, a fee will be paid to the Government as a result of the merger of Telecom and OTC. The level of that fee will be set by the Government following consideration of advice from the Interim Board on the likely financial results of the merger.

The bill provides for certain exemptions from Commonwealth, State and Territory taxes with regard to the succession process, recognising there has been no change in beneficial ownership of the carriers.
I commend this bill to the Senate and I present the explanatory memorandum to this bill.
VETERANS' ENTITLEMENTS (REWRITE) TRANSITION BILL 1991

This Bill is the second of three Bills required to give effect to the ``plain English'' rewrite of Part III of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986. It provides the necessary legal machinery for the transition from the former Part III to the new plain English Part III. In keeping with the promise I gave to the ex-service community, the Bill contains no changes to policy. It does, however, ensure that changes to the VEA arising from the 1990 Budget Sittings are included in the rewritten Part III.
The primary objective of the Bill is to:
- make the necessary savings and transitional provisions to ensure that existing rights are protected;
- add ``plain English'' indexation provisions and 1990 Budget amendments to the Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill 1991 (the Rewrite Bill);
- make consequential amendments to other Parts of the VEA, other Veterans' Affairs legislation and other Commonwealth Acts; and
- make minor technical amendments to the Rewrite Bill;
This Bill will ensure that:

- service pension processes begun under specific provisions of the VEA prior to the commencement of the rewritten Part III on 1 July 1991 will continue to be operative after that date under the equivalent provisions of the rewritten Part III without any break in continuity;
- all legislation containing references to the former Part III are updated to reflect the structural and other changes to the rewrite of Part III; and
- the Rewrite Bill as introduced is amended to correct any minor drafting or unintentional errors.

As I said, Mr President, the Bill reflects the undertaking I gave to the ex-service community at the beginning of the exercise in 1990 that the rewrite of Part III would not involve any policy changes. My Department has discussed the development of the Bill with ex-service organisations.
This Bill therefore has no financial impact for the Government or veterans and their dependants.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the Explanatory Memorandum.
CUSTOMS AMENDMENT BILL 1991
This Bill proposes to amend the Customs Act 1901 (``the Act''), to:
(i) implement certain reforms to the current anti-dumping/subsidisation regime which were announced by the Government in the 12 March Industry Statement,
and
(ii) effect technical drafting changes to the internal body search provisions of the Act to clarify the nature and function of judges' orders made under those provisions.
The proposed amendments to Part XVB of the Act, relating to the anti-dumping and subsidisation provisions, focus on three aspects of Australia's anti-dumping and countervailing system:

- Clause 7 of the Bill proposes the inclusion of several new subsections modelled on the relevant sections of the United States Tariff Act of 1930, to expand the definition of an Australian industry, and thus effectively allow material injury suffered by vertically integrated agricultural industries as a result of the dumping or subsidisation of processed agricultural products to be taken into consideration when determining the material injury caused by the dumping of such processed products;

- Clause 8 of the Bill proposes to simplify the determination of provisional dumping measures by providing for the calculation of a full dumping margin at the preliminary finding stage of a dumping or subsidisation inquiry;
and

- Clause 9 of the Bill proposes a modification to the provision in the Act relating to the 3 year sunset period for dumping measures, to ensure that any such measures which may be in place for a particular product apply for 3 years, unless earlier revoked.

In making these changes, the Australian Government retains its commitment to promoting a fair and orderly international trading system under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. The Government will, as appropriate, review and if necessary amend Australia's legislative provisions and actions taken under the Act in the light of future developments in the international economic and trading arena, particularly in regard to our continuing obligations under the GATT and the GATT Anti-Dumping Code.

The principal objective of the anti-dumping amendments in this Bill is to provide that where agricultural producers who are vertically integrated with the processors to whom they sell their products suffer material injury as a result of dumping or subsidisation of processed products, the agricultural producers will be included as part of the relevant Australian industry and thus will be taken into consideration in cases involving those imported processed products.

The new provision in Clause 7 of the Bill will apply to those involved in the production of crops (including viticulture, horticulture and apiculture), as well as the rearing of livestock, and the conduct of forestry and fishing operations.

This change recognises the vulnerability of vertically integrated agricultural producers, who are generally price takers in their markets, with the prices they receive dependent on the prices their buyers are able to command for their processed products. Agricultural producers can, therefore, be materially injured as a result of the impact of dumping or subsidisation on the processors to whom they sell their produce.
The new provision in relation to the definition of ``industry'' has been modelled on existing United States legislation which serves a similar purpose.

It includes strict tests of vertical integration. For a primary producer to be considered part of a processed agricultural product industry, the raw agricultural goods of the primary producer must be devoted substantially or completely to the processed agricultural goods and the processed goods must be derived substantially or completely from the raw agricultural goods. In addition, vertical integration is subject to an economic test requiring either a close relationship between the movement in the prices of the raw agricultural goods and the processed goods, or that the raw agricultural goods constitute a significant proportion of the production cost of the processed agricultural goods.

The second objective of the anti-dumping amendments in this Bill relates to the three year sunset provision on anti-dumping and countervailing measures. This was introduced into the Australian system in 1988 as a safeguard against the use of anti-dumping and countervailing measures as a means of long term industry protection. The Government continues to regard the sunset provision in Section 269TM of the Act as a valuable aspect of the system.

At present, however, new anti-dumping or countervailing measures imposed while a measure is in place against the same product from a different source may only be applied for as long as the existing measure on that product remains in place.

The implications of this are that, where companies engaged in injurious dumping into Australia seek to avoid duties by relocating their operations, any new dumping measures imposed on the relocated source will terminate at the same time as the original measure-no matter how short a time the new measure has been in place. Given the time, effort and cost involved in pursuing action against dumping, the shortened life of such anti-dumping measures is a disincentive for Australian industry to seek action where companies dumping products move their source to avoid the penalties for dumping.
Clause 9 of the Bill will therefore ensure that, except in the case of a successful request for revocation, all anti-dumping and countervailing measures will be applied for the full three years.

Finally, with regard to the anti-dumping amendments in this Bill, Clause 8 effectively provides that the Australian Customs Service will no longer calculate ``non-injurious'' free on board values for the purpose of setting provisional dumping measures. While that calculation, which attempts to set the price at which a product could be exported to Australia without causing injury to the Australian industry, will continue to be used at the final finding stage for the setting of dumping or countervailing duties, the elimination of it and use instead of the full margin of dumping or subsidisation at the preliminary finding stage will simplify the investigation process and will assist with the reduction in the time taken to process anti-dumping and countervailing cases.

The other amendments proposed by this Bill effect technical drafting changes to the new internal body search provisions of Part XII of the Act, and relate in particular to the conferral of power on judges to make the detention and internal search orders which were part of the Customs (Detention and Search) Act 1990, which was assented to in October last year, and commenced operation on 24 April this year. These amendments, contained in clauses 3, 4, 5, and 6 of the Bill, are explained in detail in the Explanatory Memorandum to the Bill.
Financial Impact Statement
The proposed amendments in this Bill have no direct financial implications.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the accompanying Explanatory Memorandum.
NATIONAL HEALTH AMENDMENT BILL 1991
This Bill gives effect to a number of Government initiatives relating to nursing homes and to the domiciliary nursing care benefit.
The Bill aims to change the Commonwealth nursing home benefit arrangements for a specified number of government nursing homes.

The purpose of these amendments is to allow payment of increased Commonwealth nursing home benefits to a special category of government nursing homes, to be referred to as adjusted fee government nursing homes. The increased benefit will be paid on the same general basis as that paid to non-government nursing homes, and will be based on the CAM system and a modification of the SAM system currently used for non-government homes.
Commonwealth nursing home benefits paid in respect of residents of government nursing homes have been frozen at November 1984 levels.

Since 1987, the Government has progressively taken steps to introduce an equitable national standard funding approach to financing nursing home care. This approach links Commonwealth funding to the care needs of individual nursing home residents. Quality of life and quality of care standards are a key element of the Government's policy on nursing home care.

The new arrangements will result in a higher level of benefit for these adjusted fee government homes. The higher level of benefit will only apply to a limited number of recently established smaller government homes which are likely to meet the Commonwealth's outcome standards for quality of care and quality of life. The nursing homes to become adjusted fee government nursing homes are listed in this Bill. This list will become a schedule to the Act. For these homes the new rate of benefit will apply retrospectively to 1 January 1991.

Payment of higher levels of nursing home benefits to this limited number of government nursing homes will be defrayed by the offset provided by the relevant State Government's withdrawal of a number of other government nursing home beds in that State. The only long term financial impact will be through the routine process of indexation which is currently applied to non-government nursing home funding, and will now apply to adjusted fee government nursing homes.
Several amendments are proposed in this Bill for the exempt nursing home arrangements.

The Government introduced the exempt nursing homes provisions last year. These cater for residents who wish to pay a higher resident contribution in return for receiving a higher level of accommodation and services. However, experience in the operation of these provisions has shown that they do not adequately cater for those people who did not choose to enter an exempt home, but were already in the home at the time it became exempt.

Under the existing legislation, a resident in a nursing home at the time it is given exempt bed status can remain in the home for two years after that date without paying an additional contribution. Beyond that period they are automatically classified as exempt and so must pay the additional contribution or leave the home. Many of these people cannot afford the additional contribution, and so must leave the home.

This provision has caused distress to many of the residents of the homes which were given exempt status last year, and to their relatives. The Bill proposes changes to the legislation to allow residents in homes given exempt bed status in the future to stay permanently without paying the additional exempt bed resident contribution.

Under the current legislation, if a home's approval as exempt expires and is not renewed, its exempt residents will immediately cease to be exempt. These people chose to enter that home specifically to obtain the additional accommodation and services an exempt home provides, and it is reasonable that they be allowed to remain exempt for as long as they stay in the home. This would also ease the home's transition to non-exempt status. This Bill will implement these changes sought by the Industry.

Currently if a nursing home, in its application for exempt status, makes an error in the list of additional accommodation and services it promises to provide, it is bound by that list. The Bill will give the Minister the power to amend this list if the proprietor so requests.

When a nursing home applies for exempt status it promises to provide certain services. If the home then does not provide these services the Minister can currently take no effective action to remedy this situation. People choosing to enter exempt homes deserve better protection than this. Accordingly the Bill will allow the Minister to remove a home's exempt status where it does not meet the conditions under which it was given this status.
Other related changes in the Bill in relation to exempt homes improve the safeguards for residents in exempt homes and make minor changes to assist the proprietors of exempt homes.

The Bill also introduces an amendment to allow certain payments to nursing homes outside the fees and benefits system. This is a purely machinery amendment, with no policy or funding implications. It is designed solely to reduce the administrative workload on the Department and on the Industry.

Currently all nursing homes are eligible for additional funding to assist them to employ a registered nurse at all times. Only the smaller homes, however, need this assistance, so the funding formula is such that only these smaller homes receive it. The funding formula and other necessary details are set out in Principles formulated pursuant to the Act. The Bill retains this situation.

However, currently the additional funding is provided by way of a variation to the home's approved fees, which means that, for all homes receiving this funding, the fees change each month. These fees have to be authorised, fed into the computer and notified to the home. This creates considerable work for the Department. It also creates considerable work for the Industry, which must change its billing arrangements each month to allow for this. This Bill will allow the additional funding to be provided directly, without the need to change the home's fees.

A similar situation applies for some small nursing homes, which are receiving additional funding to assist them to achieve financial viability. The Bill retains the existing arrangements for determining eligibility and the level of additional funding, and allows this funding to be provided without the need to change the home's fees every month.
The Bill also clarifies the Commonwealth's power to recover overpayments from nursing homes.

This Bill also strengthens the legal power of the Government to take action against nursing homes with poor standards of care. In a small number of cases, nursing home proprietors have not provided the quality of life and care expected by the Government. As the Commonwealth subsidises each resident in a nursing home an average of twenty three thousand dollars per year (as well as the resident's contribution from their pension), it is essential for the Commonwealth to be in a position to ensure accountability for the funds it makes available and to protect the rights of a potentially powerless group of individuals in our community.

This Bill makes it clear that the satisfaction of the Commonwealth outcome standards is a condition of approval of all Commonwealth funded nursing homes. It also clarifies the ability of the Commonwealth either to take sanctions action against the home or, if necessary, to withdraw or suspend a nursing home's approval to receive Commonwealth funding.

A minor amendment is also included in this Bill to ensure that the role of the Community Visitor, as spelled out in the Act, does not conflict with the role of Standards Monitoring Teams, and Departmental Complaints Officers.
Changes to the method of approving applications for domiciliary nursing care benefit are also contained in this Bill.

Under the National Health Act as it currently stands, the Secretary's power to approve a person for domiciliary nursing care benefit can only be delegated to a medical practitioner employed by the Commonwealth.

The proposed amendment will have the effect of extending this delegation to registered nurses. Delegates will also no longer be required to be employed in a Commonwealth Department. This will allow the Secretary to delegate this power to medical practitioners and registered nurses who are not officers of the Department, but who may, for example, be employees of a State or Territory Department.

Since a decision to approve an application for domiciliary nursing care benefit is primarily a decision about the need for continuing nursing care, it is appropriate that nurses be included as delegates of the Secretary. Medical certificates, however, will still be required with every application.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
I now present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill.
Motion (by Senator Richardson) agreed to:

That the Veterans' Entitlements (Rewrite) Transition Bill 1991, the Customs Amendment Bill 1991 and the National Health Amendment Bill 1991 be listed on the Notice Paper as separate orders of the day.
Debate (on motion by Senator Knowles) adjourned.

APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL (No. 2) 1990-91
APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 4) 1990-91

REPORT OF ESTIMATES COMMITTEE C

speech.speaker: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

talk.start.para: â€”Mr Chairman, you might appreciate that when I was speaking just before the suspension of the sitting for lunch I was answering a matter that was raised by Senator Walters concerning a letter received by a Tasmanian constituent in respect of matters to do with Tasmanian transport. I had undertaken to find out more about the circumstances in which the letter was sent.

speech.para: I can confirm that the mail-out was conducted in mid-April 1991 by the Department of Social Security (DSS) on behalf of the Tasmanian Department of Roads and Transport. Because the Department of Social Security was in fact doing the mail-out for the Tasmanian State Department, there was no positive identification of the material sent to the client by the Department and there was no information provided to the State Government. So, in that sense, no privacy rules were breached.

However, there was a failure by my Department to identify that it was the Department of Social Security that issued the material and that failure is contrary to departmental guidelines and practices in this area. The Department assures me that it has taken steps to strengthen and re-emphasise those guidelines to prevent a recurrence.

Notwithstanding the difficulties that were created for some clients in Tasmania in this case, it should be noted that the information was provided to enable clients to take advantage of a benefit which should have been available to them. The motives were correct. No information was disclosed to any party to whom it should not have been disclosed. But I regret that guidelines were not followed and that this situation was not made clear to those who received the letter.

talk.start.para: â€”I thank the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) for that information. I have one remaining question. Could the Minister tell me how this is normally carried out. What is the normal identification on a letter to one of his Department's clients? How is it indicated that his Department is sending out information on behalf of another department so that people are aware that there has been no breach of their privacy?

speech.speaker: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

talk.start.para: â€”Perhaps I could take a couple of seconds to read out a few paragraphs of what clients would normally be told. The following would be included in a letter to them:

speech.para: The Department of Social Security has been asked by the Action Group for Disabled Children Inc for assistance in conducting a survey relating to the service needs of families caring for children with disabilities.
The Department has agreed to cooperate because it is considered that the survey will be generally beneficial to . . . clients.

I would like to assure you that the Department has not or will not release any information on departmental clients to the Action Group. The system adopted is that the Department of Social Security will forward a questionnaire and a covering letter from the Action Group to all recipients of Child Disability Allowance in Victoria. However it should be noted that the Department will not provide the Action Group with names of the people who received the questionnaires.

On behalf of the Department of Social Security I also want to emphasize that no one is compelled to answer the questionnaire. It is entirely for you to decide whether you wish to complete and return the form to the Action Group. It should also be noted that you are not required to sign or in any other way identify yourself on the form unless you make that choice.

That would have been signed by the State Director in Victoria. So that is the kind of warning, if one wants to call it that-or caution, in any event-that clients would be advised of in that circumstance.

talk.start.para: â€”I would like to ask a question in relation to the video on the young homeless allowance (YHA) that has been recently produced by the Minister's Department. Is that merely a promotional video? What audience is it designed to appeal to?
â€”A young homeless allowance video was produced. I am informed that it was broadcast on television as a community service announcement.
â€”That is the extent to which it is going to be used?

â€”I do not have any further information. I will get it for Senator Alston. But I would imagine that it would also be available to be played in our offices upon request from those who would be seeking information on YHA.

â€”I would be grateful to the Minister if he could provide that information. Could the Minister also obtain information as to the target audience for whom this video was designed in the first instance? In particular, could he indicate how it is anticipated that young homeless are going to be watching this unless they happen to be residing in their own homes and are hopefully to be persuaded to leave home in order to qualify for the allowance? I would also appreciate some elaboration on that. Could the Minister also tell me whether the video was produced by a unit within the Department? If so, what is the function of the unit and what average staffing levels operate?

â€”I have some information on that. I am not certain whether it is all that Senator Alston would require. Nonetheless, I will give what I have. I might say that a video of this kind would also presumably be shown widely so that those who know of people who might wish to avail themselves of this allowance would become aware of it. The information that I have is that an ASO 6 and an ASO 5 worked on this; and that the total cost was $2,203, $1,103 of which was salary and the other $1,100 was production costs.
â€”Are these sorts of videos ever produced outside the Department? In other words, does the Department contract out?
â€”Senator Alston, while the Minister is seeking advice, are you working on the question which relates to use of videos in departmental communication and training?
â€”Yes, I am.

â€”Senator Alston asked a question on notice on that point. A number of firms were given as examples such as Media Dynamics Pty Ltd, Green Ant Productions, a joint exercise with the Department of Employment, Education and Training, and Broadcom Australia Pty Ltd on a number of occasions. It does happen, although I think quite obviously that most of the videos are produced in-house.

â€”I now take the Minister to an answer to a question that appears on page C31 of the Hansard. The question related to the breakdown of the Department's running costs, which were identified as being 3 per cent of total Department of Social Security outlays. The answer gave just a couple of simple figures: salaries, $525.8m and administration costs, $241.3m. Could I ask for a detailed breakdown of the administrative expenses?
â€”Yes. I am happy to provide that.
â€”In relation to unemployment benefits, so far this financial year how much has been spent on unemployment benefits and Job Search allowance payments?
â€”I am assured that the advisers who are sitting outside the chamber will have the exact figure. If Senator Alston can wait for a minute or two, I will be able to provide it.

â€”Could I have the April figure at the same time? Regarding the survey on the effectiveness of the jobs, education and training (JET) program by the Australian Council of Social Service, could the Minister indicate what other organisations were invited to express interest in that process?

speech.speaker: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

talk.start.para: â€”Again, my understanding is that Senator Alston has an answer on this matter. I am not sure exactly what he is seeking. I can read out the answer. I might as well do that as it is only a couple of paragraphs. The answer states:

speech.para: As part of the comprehensive evaluation of JET, information is needed on community and employer reactions to the program and the influence of various local factors on its success. There was no open competition for the contract to undertake the necessary survey but a selection process was adopted in which expressions of interest were invited from six organisations thought to be likely to have the required expertise.

Three organisations responded and their proposals were subjected to an evaluation, conducted in a similar way to a formal tender evaluation, by a joint committee with representatives of the Departments of Social Security, Finance, Community Services and Health, and Employment Education and Training. These Departments had also been involved in the choice of the organisations to be contacted initially. It was considered that the proposal from ACOSS best satisfied the criteria laid down for the evaluation. Their cost of $70,000 was not the lowest but was within $3,000 of the lowest bid and was judged to offer the best value for money. The contract with ACOSS is in the process of finalisation.

talk.start.para: â€”I am indebted to the Minister. My question was building on that. We certainly received that answer. We now want to know the names of the six organisations which were originally invited to respond and, in particular, the three that did.
â€”We will certainly try to get that information for Senator Alston now.

speech.speaker: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

talk.start.para: â€”On page 7 of the explanatory notes, it is stated that there has been a $2.1m adjustment in the allocations to the Department of Social Security for transfers to the Australian Taxation Office and the Privacy Commissioner in respect of costs incurred due to computer matching. On page C27 of the Hansard for the Estimates on 16 April, it is recorded that I asked the Department of Social Security to outline specifically the nature of this $2.1m saving. A reply was given by the representative of the Department of Social Security as follows:

speech.para: A transfer of $2m in administrative costs to the Australian Tax Office was to assist in its administrative costs of processing the tax file numbers that are required for the computer matching exercise, being a part of the 1991 Budget initiative.

I now want to ask: what amount of money was not transferred to the Privacy Commissioner to fund his overseeing role in the data matching process and why was the money originally allocated and why was it not transmitted to the Privacy Commissioner?

talk.start.para: â€”I will check the exact amount. I think that about $100,000 was given to the Privacy Commissioner this year for staff for the purpose of looking at the tax file numbering system.
â€”Is the Minister saying that $100,000 was transferred?
â€”Yes. We have given $100,000 up for that purpose.
â€”Why was the $2m that was allocated to the Australian Taxation Office to assist it in its processing of tax file numbers not required this financial year?
â€”I cannot undertake to provide that information immediately because that is the Tax Office's arrangement but I will certainly get an answer for Senator Patterson. I doubt that it will be tonight.
â€”When was it originally intended to have the tax file number processing undertaken?
â€”The original intention was October last year.
â€”When is it expected to have the first run of the tax file number processing undertaken?
â€”The first matching cycle began on 18 April. The first cycle has been completed.
â€”Specifically, how will tax file numbers be integrated into the Department of Social Security computer system? Will they be scanned or punched in and what will be the cost of this?
â€”I cannot even undertake to give Senator Patterson an answer on that yet. It is still being examined to find the best and most efficient way of doing it. We have not yet made a final decision.
â€”Does the Minister have any idea of when the final decision will be made and what will be the likely cost?
â€”I cannot give any idea as to the money, but we think that the decision will be made within a month.

â€”There is a $2.1m adjustment, with $2m not being used by the Australian Taxation Office to assist it in processing tax file numbers. Can the Minister explain what the other $0.1m adjustment was for? I presumed that it was money that had not gone to the Privacy Commissioner.

â€”I am still not quite sure about what Senator Patterson wants out of this question. We have undertaken to provide the $2.1m to agencies which have a central role in the tax file number system. We have given up money for that process. I am not sure what other information Senator Patterson requires. In other words, I do not quite understand the question.

â€”There is a variation of $2.1m, with $2m of it adjusted from the Taxation Office. I presume that the $0.1m was to do with the Privacy Commissioner. There is a minus $2.1m adjustment. I am referring to page 7 of the explanatory notes.
â€”I presume that Senator Patterson is talking about the process itself. We would give that money up to the Department of Finance. That is why it is a minus $2.1m.
â€”Does that mean that the Privacy Commissioner has less money for the manpower and administrative resources needed to oversee the conduct of the data matching?

â€”One of the difficulties is that these adjustments are spread across portfolios. In whatever Estimates deal with the Attorney-General's Department-off the top of my head I do not know-there should be a corresponding adjustment relating to the Privacy Commissioner.
â€”That still has not answered my question for me. The Minister is saying that he got the money but through another source.

â€”No, I am saying that we give the money to the Department of Finance, which gives it to the Attorney-General's Department, which gives it to the Privacy Commissioner. But it would not be recorded in these Estimates. All we can record is the giving up of, not the giving to.
â€”Maybe we should pursue that at the next Estimates in more detail.
â€”By all means.

speech.speaker: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

talk.start.para: â€”I want to discuss the additional costs entailed in providing benefits to the large number of extra unemployment benefit recipients. In the Additional Estimates it was stated that $6.7m in additional salaries and about $1m in administrative moneys were to be provided to cope with the larger than anticipated number of unemployed people. In the Senate Estimates hearing I was told that the Budget estimate for the number of unemployment benefit and Job Search allowance recipients was 475,000 persons. This estimate has been exceeded but has not been reassessed.

speech.para: The Department of Social Security informed us that the equivalent of 650 extra staff have been employed to meet the extra demand. Officials informed us that they make Forward Estimates concerning the payment of unemployment benefit and allocate staff accordingly. Can the Minister tell me on what the estimate of the number of unemployment benefit recipients and the extra allocations of $6.7m for staff and $1m for administration were based?
