talk.start.para: â€”(5.43 p.m.)-I think I have answered the questions on this matter in Senate Question Time on other occasions. It is not the Department of Social Security which does the Forward Estimates for the numbers of unemployed; it is done by the Treasury. It is Treasury's parameters within which we work. There are then formulas, which have been agreed over time between the Department of Social Security and the Department of Finance, whereby our numbers increase commensurately to handle the extra numbers of unemployed. But we do not actually set those unemployment parameters; they are done by Treasury. Senator Patterson would have to take up with that Department the request for any information that she wants. I wish her the best of luck.

â€”Yes; it takes six months to get an answer or a letter from Treasury. In the Estimates, the Department of Social Security claimed that another 650 staff have been put on to cope with the increased demand for unemployment benefits. Will further extra staff have to be employed to cope with further increases in the number of unemployment beneficiaries since April? If so, how many additional staff will have to be employed?
â€”We will monitor the numbers as they come through. If numbers exceed Treasury parameters, then we will be seeking extra staff to cope.
â€”Have they exceeded Treasury parameters?

â€”Quite clearly, if one looks at the Budget estimate from last year, which the honourable senator just read out, the numbers have definitely exceeded Treasury parameters and hence we have had staff increases.
â€”Do you expect the staff to increase even more?
â€”It is possible.

â€”Can the Minister tell me how much money has been spent on the payment of unemployment benefits since 1 July 1990 given, as I said before, that the Treasury parameter for unemployment beneficiaries was 475,000 and it is presently well in excess of 600,000? By what amount has the Budget estimate for this item been exceeded to date? What is the total estimated increase for the financial year?

â€”The amount spent on unemployment benefits and the Job Search allowance up until 25 April was slightly over $3 1/2 billion; the round total is $3,555m. But I think the honourable senator was asking a little more than that. I do not think I can give her a figure on the other part of the question until the end of the financial year.
â€”You have no predictions at all as to what the expenditure might be?
â€”I would not for a moment consider myself qualified to make predictions.

â€”I seek the indulgence of the Committee and the Minister to ask a short series of questions on the deeming issue. I did not put a reservation on it because at the time it had been settled at 10 per cent.
â€”I would not say it is a plenary indulgence. I am happy to grant it, but I am not certain that I have a deeming expert present. I will just do my best with the questions and see how we go.

â€”I thank the Minister. I should most probably have advised him of my intention to ask these questions prior to the consideration of this section of the Estimates, and I apologise to him for that. Although not mentioned in the explanatory notes for the Additional Estimates, it is reasonable to assume that the announcement in the first week of May that the deeming rate would drop to 8 per cent will cause increased expenditure by the Department of Social Security. Can the Minister tell me what administrative procedures have been followed to ensure that pensioners' entitlements are varied in accordance with the drop in the deeming rate? Maybe the Minister cannot give me this figure, but what will be the total cost of undertaking these administrative procedures?

â€”I do not think I have a costing on that. I will have to take that question on notice. We are asking pensioners to notify us of the pensioner accounts in which they have their money so that from then on we can deal with banks to determine the interest rates, and they will not have to worry about the other occasions because I said I would vary the rate twice a year. We timed the announcement with an impending issue of Age Pension News. I think I made the announcement on the Tuesday and most pensioners in Australia had Age Pension News, which went into quite some detail on the question, by the Friday. We tried to minimise the costs by timing the announcements to match. But I will have to get the costs for the honourable senator.

speech.speaker: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

talk.start.para: â€”There are a couple of questions that I want to ask but, given the fact that I did not forewarn the Minister, I was wondering whether I could put them on notice. But there was one question in particular which may not need that treatment. In the last few days an advertisement from the Department of Veterans' Affairs entitled `Important News for Service Pensioners' appeared in the newspapers. It reads:

speech.para: The deemed interest rate on pensioners' savings has been cut from 10 per cent to 8 per cent. Those service pensioners who are affected will have their pensions increased automatically from payday 13 June.

Improvements to the Department's computer system will enable changes in interest rates for bank, building society and credit union accounts to be recorded automatically. This means that you do not have to advise the Department when interest rates on your cheque and savings accounts vary- we will record the new interest rates for you.
Remember: you do not have to contact Veterans Affairs about these changes.
Can the Minister explain why there is a difference between Veterans' Affairs and the Department of Social Security in pensioners having to advise Social Security and not Veterans' Affairs?

talk.start.para: â€”As Senator Patterson would be aware, the departments have separate computer facilities, which is a matter of continuing consternation for some, but it is nonetheless the case. Social Security is building into its system the facility to which the honourable senator has just referred. It does not have it yet and, in any event, that would be affected by what information either department held on the pensioner and their financial situation. Of course, that varies as well. I am confident that that will be standardised fairly shortly.

â€”I have a couple of questions that the Minister may have to take on notice. What will be the cost of manning a special deeming hot line and a multi- lingual telephone information service for the purposes of receiving calls in relation to the drop in the deeming rate?
â€”I'll have to take that on notice.
â€”Have the financial institutions who offer the 60-odd special pensioner accounts reduced their interest rate to 8 per cent?

â€”Some have made announcements already that that is what they are doing; others are yet to make announcements. We are in contact with them to try to find out when they will, but of course we cannot instruct them. In any event, it is not the case that we can guarantee that all institutions will stick to 8 per cent. Certainly, the indications are that the overwhelming number will do so. Some may seek to gain a commercial advantage by keeping it higher than 8 per cent. I imagine it would be only slightly higher. Some might try to do that-and good luck to them; I hope they do. We will not know until a little closer to the day. We will be trying to keep pensioners informed as we obtain the information.

â€”What is the basis for the decision to reduce the deeming rate? Is it based on a set formula or is it based on an arbitrary decision made by the Minister and the Department that it is time to reduce the rate?

speech.speaker: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

talk.start.para: â€”The Australian Bankers Association had a number of meetings with me on what was an appropriate rate, and a number of further meetings were held with officers from my Department. It was a matter of determining what would be the right rate. The Australian Bankers Association wanted us to adopt a formula. A number of formulas were presented to us by the Association as to what might be the right rate. At the time most of those worked out at about 7.5 per cent.

speech.para: However, I did not make the decision to drop it to 8 per cent on my own. I had a meeting with the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and with their officials, and they were provided with details of the Australian Bankers Association request. My recommendation to them was not to agree to the formulas suggested by the Australian Bankers Association, on the basis that all of them involved regular-on some occasions, very regular-fluctuations. Given the difficulty in ever introducing a reform such as deeming, which I have always admitted would cause some consternation and confusion, much of which we have managed to settle down, if the rate were to vary every week, we would have no hope of explaining that to many pensioners. I thought it would be too complicated and too difficult.

The other Ministers accepted my recommendation that we not agree to a formula but agreed that a rate of 8 per cent was a rate which could be held for some time as being, in any event, very near to that which was requested by the Bankers Association but also giving pensioners perhaps a very slight edge.

speech.speaker: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

talk.start.para: â€”I remind the Minister that during the debate on deeming a suggestion from this side of the chamber was made that that rate be looked at. It does concern me that so soon after the introduction of deeming at 10 per cent we had to change to 8 per cent. I believe that it has caused consternation and difficulty with many pensioners, who have had to face some difficult changes. I gave the Minister credit when, on Friday night in Western Australia, I spoke about the introduction of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme charge. We have seen a reduction in the use of pharmaceutical benefits. Hopefully, that will continue for people who do not need medication as opposed to those who really need it.

speech.para: We were not opposed to the Minister bringing in the deeming but we did have some concerns about the rate, and I think that was justified. I do hope that the Minister and the Department will make every attempt to ensure that, when rates like this are set, a little more foresight is used and we see what is happening in the market. If that were the case, we may have been able to set 8 per cent in the beginning and not have this change so soon afterwards.

talk.start.para: â€”Before I call the Minister, I advise the Committee that last night the Chairman of Committees ruled that matters not the subject of reservations perhaps should not be looked at. Perhaps the Minister could advise us as to the situation with respect to the questions just asked by Senator Patterson and whether we should leave the matter of deeming or whether the questions should be put on notice.

speech.speaker: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

talk.start.para: â€”I did not know about last night's ruling; nor do I know whether there is a reservation here on deeming or not. I can give a very short answer to Senator Patterson. I absolutely disagree with her, although I am grateful that she gave me a run in Western Australia. The 10 per cent rate was set quite deliberately in line with markets at the time. The fact that it could be held from August right through to June, I think, is testimony to the fact that it was right at the time we announced it.

speech.para: I was told by many on Senator Patterson's side of the chamber-although not by her-that pensioners would not be able to obtain 10 per cent at call. At the time of making the announcement to drop it to 8 per cent, there were 62 at call accounts around Australia. This is one occasion on which I can say, `I told you so: the 10 per cent rate was right'. We held on to it for a long time. I did not want to penalise the banks; that was never the intention. It was to get a fairer system and simply not to have them take advantage of pensioners. That being the case, 10 per cent could never be kept for ever. I said that it will be varied twice a year, which means every six months, not the 10 months that we held the last rate.

speech.speaker: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

talk.start.para: â€”In the Estimates hearings, we asked the Department:

speech.para: Has any approach been made regarding the use of the DSS beneficiary number in relation to the Health Insurance Commission's planned computerised pharmaceutical eligibility checking procedure if a person does not have his or her Medicare number?

In the written answer of the Department, which I received on 28 May, the Department stated that the Department of Social Security beneficiary numbers are used now because they are included on pharmacists' claims which are cross-checked with DSS eligibility information held by the Health Insurance Commission. The answer from the Department continued:

The Health Insurance Commission has approached the Department of Social Security about a new system of verification. Under the proposals the Social Security pensioner/beneficiary number would continue to be in the verification procedures.
Will pharmacy clients be able to provide a DSS beneficiary number as evidence of their identification if they do not have a Medicare card with them?

talk.start.para: â€”The problem is that many pensioners-it has just been suggested to me most, but I will be conservative and say many-will not have a Medicare card. If the onus is to be put on them, which Senator Patterson has suggested, it will be a real problem.
â€”Will the pharmacists be able to crosscheck the bona fides of this DSS beneficiary number by way of an on-line checking mechanism connected to the Health Insurance Commission?
â€”I cannot give answers for what is in the portfolio of my colleague, Mr Howe. Senator Patterson will have to ask him. They will not be able to have any online checking with us.

â€”Can the Minister tell me how the DSS number will be incorporated? The Health Insurance Commission will say whether a person is eligible. How will the Health Insurance Commission know whether the person is a Department of Social Security beneficiary?

â€”Senator Patterson has already been provided with the actual detail of what Social Security provides to the Health Insurance Commission-with the exact information, in an answer to one of her questions. I am not sure when Senator Patterson would have received that answer but I would say fairly recently. Nothing is provided beyond that. Obviously it is necessary that Social Security verify eligibility. It would have to because HIC is administering this, not us. For that reason the tapes that are provided go through a whole list of information, but I do not think it is necessary to read it out because Senator Patterson already has it.
â€”Does the Department of Social Security agree with the findings of the Auditor-General about the extent of inaccurate claims on the pharmaceutical benefits scheme using DSS beneficiary numbers?

speech.speaker: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

talk.start.para: â€”All I can say in answer to that is that our Department provides accurate information. Beyond that, if there are criticisms of an administration that is not ours, they have to be levelled at those who are responsible for that administration.

speech.para: I wish to read a couple of answers that I promised Senator Alston I would give when he was asking questions earlier on. We were talking about the jobs, education and training evaluation scheme. I undertook to name organisations which had been contacted. They are the Australian Council of Social Service (ACOSS), the Brotherhood of Saint Laurence, the Australian Institute of Family Studies, Brian Sweeney and Associates, the Social Policy Research Centre of the University of New South Wales and Reark Research Pty Ltd.

The ACOSS, the Brotherhood of Saint Laurence and Reark Research were the ones that responded. The selection was carried out by an interdepartmental committee including the departments of Social Security, Finance and Community Services and Health. In respect of the Young Homeless Allowance video, which we were discussing, the video is shown in DSS public contact areas. It is used as a community service announcement in non-metropolitan areas generally. It is also used in youth drop-in centres, refuges and the like.

talk.start.para: â€”Now that we have completed consideration of the estimates of the Department of Social Security, I call on the estimates of the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories.

speech.speaker: Calvert Sen P.H.

talk.start.para: â€”I wish to ask a few questions relating to some questions that were placed on notice by my colleague Senator Michael Baume under the reservation that was put in by Senator Alston concerning questions for which answers were subsequently provided. I presume that allows me to ask some of these questions. Senator Richardson would be disappointed if I did not ask some questions about Antarctica, so I hope he is ready and has his parka and everything else on.

speech.para: On program 3.2 on expeditions, a question was asked about the existing arrangements regarding the supply of marine diesel oil, bunkering and whatever. The answer provided pointed out that prices varied in accordance with movements in capital city price lists, et cetera. Right at the finish of the answer to the question it says, `However, the Antarctic Division has asked the Department of Administrative Services to review its arrangements'. I ask the Minister: how does the Department intend to do that and what sorts of matters will be looked at?

talk.start.para: â€”I will read this out. I will not pretend to know the answer. This is the information with which I have been provided: the Department has asked the Department of Administrative Services to establish whether the prices obtained on the standard Commonwealth contract are the best that can be obtained on a long term basis. The review has been requested because there are situations where the spot price for fuel is well below the Commonwealth's contract.

speech.speaker: Calvert Sen P.H.

talk.start.para: â€”I thank the Minister. I am sure that answer is the sort of thing we are looking for. Another question that my colleague Senator Baume put on notice concerned an ice pilot for the Aurora Australis. The Minister may remember that I previously raised a question about the ice pilot and the fact that the Commonwealth will pay for that over and above a normal crew.

speech.para: Back in this place on 14 November 1990, I think in answer to a question I put to the Minister about the cost of an ice pilot-it was about $28,000, which I believe is now $34,000-the Minister told me:
The gentleman occupying the role at the moment is a Norwegian. We will not need an ice pilot for long, once we get an Australian captain with sufficient ice experience . . .
How far away are we from that? Will an ice pilot be used during the next season?

talk.start.para: â€”The experience of the Australian crew is such now that we will not be using the pilot in the next season.

speech.speaker: Calvert Sen P.H.

talk.start.para: â€”I thank the Minister; that is very nice to know. I have another question regarding the Aurora Australis. In an earlier question, I asked the Minister who was responsible for the off-season layup costs. Seeing that the ship is just out from my office, I often walk down there and see that it has been sitting there for quite some time.

speech.para: In answer to a question Senator Richardson said that the lay up costs to be paid by the Commonwealth will only apply if the vessel is actually laid up and not being used for other purposes. Obviously, anybody in Hobart can see that it is not being used for other purposes at the moment. I wonder whether the Division has been successful in finding other work for it in the future-whether it is this year or next year-and I would appreciate an answer to the question.

talk.start.para: â€”We have identified some other work. It is expected that from 1992-93 the vessel will be used for about 40 days a year in the off season by the new cooperative research centre on the Antarctic and Southern Ocean environment which is being established in Hobart.

speech.speaker: Calvert Sen P.H.

talk.start.para: â€”I attended the opening of that centre and I hope that, along with everything else that is happening in Hobart, it will enhance the stature of the Department in our capital city, and that further down the track we will see Hobart becoming more and more used by not only our vessels, but others.
â€”Hobart will be enhanced by the Labor Party conference on 24 June.

â€”Yes, I believe the banks are taking in extra money-or the casino is. The Minister may be aware of an article that appeared in the Canberra Times regarding husky dogs in Antarctica. As a member of the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare, I was concerned to see that as a result of the new Antarctic Treaty that has been negotiated it is proposed to remove our Mawson huskies which have been in Antarctica for some 43 years. I know that this matter was raised in 1988. In fact, I have had correspondence from a concerned constituent here in Canberra who said that in 1988 a group of misinformed trendies proposed the removal of Mawson huskies for the same reasons that are proposed now.

speech.para: The reasons given for the removal of the huskies is that they could create disease threats to animals in Antarctica and also environmental threats. My constituent points out that the Mawson huskies have been disease free for 43 years and have been isolated in the Antarctic environment, so it is impossible for them to introduce diseases. I just wonder whether any further consideration has been given to retaining our historic huskies there because they have been responsible in the past for saving lives, as was pointed out in this particular letter. I wonder whether the Minister has any more information at this stage.

speech.speaker: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

talk.start.para: â€”I was not aware of the article, so I will just read this answer. If Senator Calvert is talking about the introduction of new dogs-and, essentially, I think we are talking about the necessity of their being introduced to keep up the breeding stock-it would be necessary to introduce a new strain roughly every five years to prevent inbreeding.

speech.para: However, that is not the major concern. The major concern is that, if treaty nations set an example by maintaining introduced species such as dogs, it is more difficult to prevent private expeditions using dogs which could introduce disease to the wildlife of Antarctica. Of course, private expeditions from quite a number of places are visiting the Antarctic much often than was the case in the past.

talk.start.para: â€”I would like to clarify that. The letters that were sent to me and also, I believe, a letter that appeared in the Canberra Times, made the point that the disease free Mawson huskies have been isolated in Antarctica for 43 years. I ask the Minister whether, in the last 43 years, there have been other dogs introduced into Antarctica from outside to increase or improve the strain.
â€”Yes.
â€”On what time basis?
â€”I am informed that the last time was about three years ago.

â€”I only have one other matter I wish to raise and that concerns a question that Senator Baume put on notice and the answer regarding the hire rates for the Aurora Australis. The answer to the question was that the Antarctic shipping charters normally provide for annual increases and the charter for the Aurora Australis provides for an annual increase in the hire rate linked to movement in the consumer price index. I wonder whether the arrangement that was arrived at with P and O, which Senator Richardson negotiated, included the wages for the crew.

â€”They are part of the hire rate on agreed award rates. I think I should make one thing very clear: I did not negotiate the agreement with P and O. At no point could it be said that I negotiated the agreement with P and O.
â€”In a case where crew members are seeking wage increases, who is responsible for the increase in salaries if one is granted? Is it P and O or does it eventually come back to the Commonwealth?

â€”The terms of the charter are such that P and O must consult with the Commonwealth-and I understand it does, so that has not been a problem. Obviously, if disputes go to arbitration, decisions can be made which would be binding and once that is done there is not much point in consultation; one has got to pay.

â€”I ask the Minister whether it is correct that the arrangements for paying the wages of the crew of the Aurora Australis are different to the arrangements that were made in the past with other ships that have been chartered.

â€”Essentially, Senator Calvert is right, but for the simple reason that previous charters were short term charters and this was a long one. I do not think the same arrangements for wages could be applied to a ship that was to be hired for a year or two, or a season or two, as would apply to a 10-year charter. There obviously had to be a change.
â€”In the case of the Icebird, that has been under charter to us for many years. What is the situation with the Icebird? Does it have a set rate in its charter for wages and salaries?

â€”There are fixed annual increases in the charter for the Icebird. It must be remembered that, when Senator Calvert says we have had the Icebird under charter for many years, we did not have a long term charter for the Icebird we kept renewing charters for smaller periods. We never had a 10-year charter for the Icebird. I am just informed that five years was the maximum ever.
â€”In the case of the Aurora Australis it is 10 years, is it not?
â€”Yes.
â€”Is the Minister saying that the arrangement with the Aurora Australis is the same as it was with the Icebird over 10 years as against five?

â€”The difference is that with Aurora Australis the wages were to go with award rates, which would be set by the Industrial Relations Commission. I am not sure how it will effect that, but that is the theory. In respect of Icebird, though, there was a fixed amount that would alter each year.
â€”If the Seamen's Union of Australia wanted to negotiate a wage increase for the crew, would it approach P and O or would it go straight to the Department?
â€”It would approach P and O.
â€”It would approach P and O and negotiate with it.
â€”The situation would be that the union would approach P and O, and P and O would consult with the Antarctic Division.
â€”If the Department, or the Government in this case, was liable for the extra salaries negotiated, P and O would not put up much of a fight if the Seamen's Union was pressing for extravagant claims.

â€”If the Antarctic Division, the Department or the Government-it is all one and the same-were unhappy with the results of consultations with P and O, and as far as I am aware P and O have consulted with us and we have been kept up to the mark with what discussions it has had with the union, and if it was of the view that P and O was going to do something that was unacceptable, it could require P and O to go to the Commission.

â€”Is the Minister aware that the Seamen's Union is presently pursuing a claim for a 30 per cent salary increase for the crew of Aurora Australis and of a further ambit claim for a 300 per cent increase in Antarctic allowances, and how does this fit in with the Government's current wages policy?
â€”Accord mark VII.

â€”It will be accord mark LXXVII by the sound of that. P and O may well be conducting negotiations with the Seamen's Union. I do not know about that. But P and O will have talks with the Seamen's Union, work out how far it thought it ought to go in coming to some terms with the union and, at that point, it will then consult the Department. Quite obviously, that point has not been reached because the Department informs me that it has not been consulted on this matter. So those talks with P and O are not even at the stage where P and O wants to talk to the Department about them. Union claims of that kind do occur from time to time, as Senator Calvert would be aware. There is a long way to go, however, between a claim being made and the granting of it.

â€”Yes. If something like that were granted, it would lift the salary bill. I would just like the Minister to confirm that the current salary bill for the Aurora Australis is $1.1m. If something like this went ahead, the bill would increase by $400,000 to $1.5m.
â€”I am advised that the bill is in the order of $1.1m. Department representatives have just said that they will check to get an exact figure for the honourable senator.

â€”I go back to the point of what incentive there is for P and O to resist any of these salary claims when we know that they are merely going to be passed on to the taxpayer? The Minister has said that the Department will negotiate with P and O, but is this the first time under the chartering arrangements with other vessels that the Government has been put in a position like this?

â€”This is the first time, but this is for the reason that I have explained before, that is, it is the first time we have had a 10-year charter. As the length of the charter is extended, there becomes a need to change the arrangements in the negotiation of salaries. Prior to that, I think Senator Calvert used the word `sanction' when asking about P and O. I cannot remember the word he used. Was it `pressure'?

â€”I asked what incentives are there for P and O to resist extravagant salary claims when it knows that at the end of the day it will not be paying for them and that the Government will be paying for them. What sort of limit is there on any scale of increase that could happen under this arrangement? In effect, under this arrangement-as the Minister says, it is the first time that it has ever happened because it is a 10-year contract-is P and O provided with an open cheque to keep the crew happy at the expense of taxpayers?

speech.speaker: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

talk.start.para: â€”I thought I explained before that the Department can require the matter to go to arbitration. P and O knows that, if it were to come to an agreement with the union which the Department found unacceptable, the matter would be refereed to arbitration. I think P and O can read the newspapers as well as everyone else can. If it looks at the Industrial Relations Commission's current attitude, it would know that it would have a problem with the kind of claim that Senator Calvert has just outlined.

speech.para: The incentive for P and O is the knowledge that the Department will simply refer the claim to arbitration if it does not like what P and O has produced. That is why there has not been a problem and I do not think there will be a problem because P and O will consult. It knows that at the end of the day the Department will just refer it to the Commission and put the claims to the test. If it does not want to take that test, it will consult and make sure that the Department is happy with any arrangements P and O and the union come to.

speech.speaker: Baume Sen M.E.

talk.start.para: â€”I would like to start off by dealing with some questions relating to the arts. Firstly, I refer to the response to questions I asked about film and television in program 6 of the explanatory notes. Senator Aulich asked how the film Green Card scored on the co-production criteria. As I understand it, there has not been a response to that question. I raise that in relation to responses to several questions, including one that I asked, about the definition of an Australian film for these purposes: firstly, of film financing and, secondly, for the showing of Australian films on television to be regarded as Australian content. The definitions seems to be so vague-so chaotic, in fact-that a film can be an Australian film for funding purposes but not for television purposes.

speech.para: There has been a disagreement between two governmental bodies on this score, and it seems to me that this is totally unsatisfactory, particularly when we find that there is no clear-cut formula under the financing arrangements for what is an Australian film. I asked in the Senate Estimates Committee:

Just to get it clear, for a film to be an Australian film for financing purposes, I understand the major proportion of the components, that is, cinematography, editing, acting and so on, have got to be Australian. Is there a simple formula?

The response was no. Then the discussion went on at some length on how and why there is not a simple formula. It is said that there are some requirements under the Income Tax Assessment Act relating to the determination of Australian content. One of the requirements, by the way, is that the subject matter of the film or the proposed film should be taken into account. Naturally, I think we can all establish that Green Card, which is an excellent film and which has done very well, did not meet that requirement.

Clearly, there is a very subjective assessment here about what is an Australian film for financing purposes and a totally different set of assessments about what is an Australian film for television broadcasting purposes. The significant consequence of this is that it is more worthwhile to an Australian television broadcaster to purchase rights to an Australian film which fills up the quota for Australian content than it is to buy a film such as Green Card which, while Australian for financing purposes, is not Australian for television purposes. That disadvantages a film such as Green Card, if it is in fact an Australian film, and it has been given that category for financing purposes. All I am asking is that the Government kindly get its act together. Will it work out what is an Australian film and what is not? If two different Australian governmental bodies cannot agree, perhaps their heads can be banged together so that people know where they stand.

I understand that, when the Australian Film Corporation made a submission to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal on this matter, it was told to go away and that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal was going to take its own view. I understand that this matter has still not been resolved, that further submissions are being made. I regard Green Card as an excellent film, and I am overjoyed that so many elements of the Australian film industry participated in it, although, as I understand it, they were not actors. I ask what criteria the Minister is required to use under section 124ZAA, which says that, where the Minister is satisfied that a proposed film when completed will have a significant non-Australian content, or a film has a significant non-Australian content, the Minister may treat the proposed film or film as not being a qualifying Australian film for the purposes of the relevant division of the Act.

The film industry is entitled to be told what the real rules are. It is argued, for example, by Actors Equity that a film that does not have Australian actors in fact has a significant non-Australian content. Is the Government applying its mind to this matter? What are the rules and what is the Government going to do about it?

speech.speaker: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

talk.start.para: â€”Senator Michael Baume has asked quite a number of questions. I will endeavour to go through them. Firstly, Senator Baume referred to a question asked by Senator Aulich, which in fact has been answered. But it was answered on the basis that Senator Aulich accepted that at least part of the answer was commercial-in-confidence because it related to certain financial details which no-one involved would want to make public. I am sure that Senator Baume could be provided with the same answer on the same basis. I am sure that the Department will contact Senator Baume after the proceedings have finished here on this matter. If he accepts that part of it is confidential, he will be provided with the answer.

speech.para: I can make at least part of the answer that was given to Senator Aulich available now because it does not involve anything secretive and I think it goes to part of the question that Senator Baume was asking about. I should first say that Senator Aulich was provided with documents on co-productions. He got application guidelines, the United Kingdom treaty and the Canadian treaty and a memorandum of understanding with both France and New Zealand. I will read two paragraphs of this answer because it is of assistance:

Key creative participation in co-productions is assessed under a 12 point system where a production is mounted under the terms of the co-production treaty and a 10 point system when a less than treaty status agreement applies, as is the case between Australia and France.

Green Card scored sufficient points for that less than treaty co-production point system and it did so because of the participation of Australians in the roles of writer, director, director of photography, editor and designer. That is how it was done. As to the details which Senator Aulich had requested on the financial structure, they must remain commercial-in-confidence, for quite obvious reasons. If Senator Baume agrees to that arrangement, then there is no difficulty in providing him with those.

Senator Baume also referred to the fact that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal has different standards from the co-production standards that we were just talking about and he is, of course, correct. As I understand it, the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal is currently holding an inquiry into these co-productions. The Department has made a submission to that inquiry. It is to be hoped that at the end of this inquiry we will not have to bang any heads together and that some reasonable agreement will be reached. On the basis of what discussion in the Estimates Committee and in the present debate has been thrown up, I give an undertaking that I will raise this matter with the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories, Mr Simmons, and also with the Minister for Transport and Communications, Mr Beazley, to make sure they understand what priority must be placed on standardising the requirements. Senator Baume is quite right; they are anomalous and they ought to be fixed. I have a document here which explains the points system and I am happy to table that document.

speech.speaker: Baume Sen M.E.

talk.start.para: â€”I thank the Minister for that and I would be grateful if I could have a copy of the document. I am grateful that the Minister will encourage his fellow Ministers to examine this clear anomaly. I am worried also about the lack of a clear formula, as I mentioned in the determination of the Australian content. My concern relates to vague words such as `a proposed film has a significant non-Australian content'. I mentioned this matter earlier. I understand that Actors Equity says that, because there are no Australian actors at all in Green Card, by clear definition that film has a significant non-Australian content. Quite frankly, I hope those words do not mean what they say, because I would like films such as Green Card to be capable of being made and to see Australian entrepreneurs in the film industry and other skilled people getting an opportunity to become involved in the world film market. Actors are not the only people involved in the film industry. They are very important and they give an Australian look to many movies, but there is also a self-evident Australian cinematographic look which is being widely accepted and welcomed throughout the world, as can be seen from the use of leading Australian cinematographers in films such as Dances with Wolves, which is otherwise not an Australian movie.

speech.para: I hope that there will be a clear statement from the Government that section 124zaa is not an incentive to encourage Ministers to treat a proposed film as not being a qualifying Australian film for the purpose of this division, simply because it has a significant non-Australian content.

talk.start.para: â€”The Minister has to have regard to the Income Tax Assessment Act in making any determination. I will not read out all of the relevant section but, as I am sure Senator Baume would be aware, there are references to nationalities and places of residence of authors, composers, actors, script writers, editors, producers and directors. Quite a number of criteria are set down and that is what the Minister has to balance any decision against. However, I will not pretend that this is an area which does not require clarification. That being the case, as I understand it, the Department is looking at doing that as we speak. Whilst an announcement will not be made tonight, I am hopeful that the Minister can make an announcement on the question shortly.

speech.speaker: Baume Sen M.E.

talk.start.para: â€”I thank the Minister for Social Security once again for a very helpful and useful response. I now want to ask a question about the National Film and Sound Archive. I was advised during the Senate Estimates that I would be told-and I was told in a subsequent written response-about the limited access which is now available to people who wish to use the services of the Film and Sound Archive because of the desperate state of some of the other projects: for example, resources have been redirected towards the preservation of nitrate film.

speech.para: As it is evident that the present target for restoring this film will not be met by the time the present special arrangements expire-and there is a program dealing with a great deal of uncopied nitrate film-this project will have to continue beyond that time and, hopefully, the nitrate film will survive until that time. I wonder whether, in diverting these resources to this urgent matter, it means that this very limited access to the services of the Film and Sound Archive will continue for what looks to be several years until this emergency is overcome. The extent of the withdrawal of services by, and access to, the National Film and Sound Archive is very substantial. For example, the response states:
Research and Information: services are withdrawn . . . clients visiting the Canberra office will be free to conduct their own research. Information requests requiring research will not be accepted.
Access to preservation and nitrate copies is withdrawn.
Access to duplicating copies is confined to video materials.
Unaccessioned material will be inaccessible. This includes almost all of the sound and radio holdings, and substantial parts of the film, television and documentation holdings.
Material in the process of removal or reorganisation, at the time of the request, will be inaccessible irrespective of its status.
All services will be provided subject to the limitations of staff availability: there may be significant delays . . .

That is, in obtaining the material which is available. I understand the need for a priority in directing all of the funds to salvaging the material that is deteriorating at a disastrous rate-particularly when we recognise that even when this has been done there will be some nitrate stock left over which will not have been treated and saved by the time the present program expires. Firstly, what can be done to ensure that that nitrate stock is not lost? Secondly, when will access to normal services, which I think the community is entitled to expect from the National Film and Sound Archive, be resumed?

speech.speaker: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

talk.start.para: â€”The answer to Senator Michael Baume's last question is two years. The reason for that length of time does not involve simply these questions of nitrate film and colour film difficulties that have been caused by the temperature at which some of these films have been stored. Rather, this has been brought about by the problem that masses of material have been received over time which have never been examined properly. The truth is that we do not really know what we have.

speech.para: In times of budgetary constraint, it is not always possible to allocate sufficient sums of money to every worthwhile cause. The Minister has instructed the National Film and Sound Archive to give this task of cataloguing-if that is the right word-all of this material a big priority. That does not mean that work on the nitrate problem stops; in fact, it will continue. But if the National Film and Sound Archive were to attempt to provide all of the services it provided formerly, then this cataloguing work would never be done. So priorities have been redirected. It is unfortunate that there is not more money to go around but, as Senator Michael Baume would be aware, there is not an unlimited supply of money available in government at the moment. So the only way that the task could be completed within existing resources would be to withdraw some activities, and they are the activities which the honourable senator has stated correctly. Hopefully, in two years-or even less if the program went well-those services could be reinstated.

speech.speaker: Baume Sen M.E.

talk.start.para: â€”I thank the Minister once again for his helpful advice. In view of his answer, I now feel a little churlish in having to ask a fairly unpleasant question. At the Senate Estimates I asked about the base evaluation of material contained in the National Museum of Australia and also about the cost of restoring Australia II. A deal was done involving its purchase. I understand payment for it, at least in part-I think in large part-was made before the Government actually took possession of Australia II. It was established in the Senate Estimates that about $50,000 was required to refurbish Australia II to display standard. I am not criticising the fact that Australia II was, after its purchase, left in the possession of Mr Bond so that he could use it, I think, as a trial horse against the next yacht. But I wonder why $2m was paid for Australia II before the Government took possession, or was even required to take possession, of it. Were there other bidders in the market? Was Australia II such a hot property that we had to pay for it before we got it?

speech.para: I am interested in the speed at which the Government rushed into this purchase. I am not suggesting that in 1984 Mr Bond was in a financial situation where it was necessary to help out a mate. I think at that stage he still looked as though he had more black than red in his bank account. But why was $2m paid so enthusiastically? Who ordered the purchase? As I understand it, the National Museum did not, because it had no capacity to display it. In fact, it is to be displayed by the Australian National Maritime Museum in Sydney, to whom it has been lent for some years. The National Maritime Museum in fact has a special large area in which to accommodate Australia II and its tall mast.

I am interested to know who ordered the purchase. It has been suggested to me that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) did, or at least he was strongly in favour of it and that view was conveyed. In these circumstances it is reasonable to ask whether the Museum Board and/or the Chief Executive of the National Museum opposed the purchase. Did it involve the diversion of funds that the National Museum might like to expend elsewhere on this very significant piece of Australia's heritage?

talk.start.para: â€”The Department has advised me that it will try to check some extra details on this now, as we continue to speak. Perhaps I can get an answer before we report progress. As a general point, the museum has purchased a lot of material that it has never been able to display; that is not unusual. There is a warehouse full of it in Canberra. Obviously Australia II would be much more difficult to put in a warehouse than a lot of other items; it would require a pretty big warehouse. I can understand why some different arrangement might have been made. I do not know whether the Board recommended the purchase or whether the Government recommended the purchase to the Board. We will try to get an answer for Senator Baume. As far as the owner was concerned, I do not think that in 1984 he looked like he needed much help; I think he was travelling pretty well then.

speech.speaker: Baume Sen M.E.

talk.start.para: â€”The point was made by Mr Blunn from the Department that the museum is required to have a value on its assets. I asked Ms Dal-Bon from the museum how it valued its stock. I asked whether it is on the cost of purchase at the time or a current valuation and I also asked how it appears in the books. Ms Dal-Bon responded:

speech.para: We do not have our collection valued in our books at the moment. We do not have a commercial value of our collection . . .
Mr Blunn interrupted:
Yes, but we are required to.

I do not presume that I was the first person to point out to the museum and the Department that the museum, during the time of its existence, had not been doing what it was required to do. Why has it taken it six or seven years to grapple with this problem and not come up with a solution yet? I presume that a museum knows the value of its items. If something like Australia II is bought for $2m, one would think that it would be in the books either for $2m or some written down value. I understand that many items in the museum have been donated and that it is difficult to put a value on them. Some items that are donated are given an estimated value for tax purposes so that the donor gets a benefit. Presumably they would have a value. I wonder why these valuations are not available.

talk.start.para: â€”Even the greatest among us make mistakes. On this occasion someone very great has made one. I speak of Mr Blunn. Upon mature consideration, reflection and further inquiry, it is apparent that the collection is not regarded as capital and, therefore, the museum is not required to have a value on it.

â€”I thank the Minister for that response. It is interesting because, as I understand it, the Auditor-General disagrees. Mr Blunn has some problems with the valuation. But is that the museum's capital stock rather than its exhibitions? The Auditor-General has been complaining about the accounts of the National Museum for some time.

â€”My understanding is that the Auditor-General is currently satisfied with what the museum is doing. But if the discussion is to be about the collection, I do not believe there is any dispute about the collection being called capital and hence a value having to be put on it.

speech.speaker: Baume Sen M.E.

talk.start.para: â€”I now want to deal with a problem which is referred to in the report of Estimates Committee C relating to unnecessary allocations made in the Estimates for funds which will not be required. The report of Estimates Committee C to the Senate says:

speech.para: The Committee heard with concern admissions from the Department about requests for allocations that were not capable of being spent.

These included an allocation for the salary of a new position, that of the Chief Science Adviser, and the funding to cover a projected shortfall in revenue from entrance fees to Kakadu National Park. This concerned me as a matter of principle. In at least one of those instances it was evident, long before the Forward Estimates would have become an excited glow in someone's eyes, that that sort of funding would not be met.

Is there any process in the Department at senior levels which would ensure that the branches that proceed with this kind of bolstering of its estimates figures are stopped from doing so? One always has a suspicion that, when organisations bolster their cash requirements in excess of what they can possibly spend, there may be some hope in their hearts that they can divert that money into other purposes-that as it will inevitably remain unspent at the end of the year it can be switched within some broad parameters into some area where the organisation is a bit short of money. Firstly, I would like an assurance that this sort of thing cannot happen and, secondly, that the Department would be alert to these kinds of nonsensical estimates which patently and inevitably cannot be spent.

talk.start.para: â€”I make it clear that, while it would be possible that on something like an allocation of a salary for a full year-when clearly if a person were hired it would be for only part of a year-that money could be allocated into other places, it has not been and it will not be. While it is acknowledged that some figures were put into the estimates that should not have been there, there will be no advantage taken of the fact that it occurred. The Department is taking steps to ensure that it will not occur again.

speech.speaker: Baume Sen M.E.

talk.start.para: â€”The Minister is being very cooperative and I appreciate his cooperation. The next problem I have is with the Australian Heritage Commission Act. I asked questions in the Senate Estimates about the extent to which the Commonwealth is bound by the heritage Act in its own actions. Section 30 of the heritage Act requires Ministers who are going to be involved in dealing with heritage, which involves the destruction of a heritage item or an item listed on the--
â€”Or damage.

â€”Or damage, yes. Ministers are required under section 30 to convince themselves that there is no alternative, that their actions are reasonable, et cetera. I am particularly concerned now that in response to my questions I have received a note from Mr Blunn, the Secretary of the Department-and I thank him for it-explaining to me what is a difficult legal matter, that is, a judgment in a recent court action relating to Paddy's Market. I understand that it is not a legal explanation. It is a layman's explanation to me as a layman and that is why I am grateful that he sent it to me.

speech.para: The essence of his letter seems to be that notwithstanding a decision by Justice Wilcox, the Full Court's reversal of Justice Wilcox's judgment seems to suggest that the requirements of the heritage Act become irrelevant if in fact a decision by a governmental body like the Foreign Investment Review Board (FIRB) relates to the actions of private individuals. In other words, the Foreign Investment Review Board can quite happily make a decision-and I remind the Senate that the FIRB is under the control of the Treasurer (Mr Keating)-which would result in the destruction or damage of a heritage object without in fact being covered by section 30. That is the clear implication of this.

In other words, the Government, in this case, does not have to be bound by its own law. There is no requirement in this case on the Treasurer, who is the responsible Minister, to establish that there is no proper viable alternative to the action. Ultimately, the agent in the destruction of Paddy's Market was not to be the Government itself but someone to whom the Government gave approval. This seems to me to be extraordinarily quaint, to say the least. In other words, the Government itself would not be allowed to pull down Paddy's Market and redevelop it unless it met the requirements of section 30 of the heritage Act, but the Government could quite happily give a permit to someone else to do so. It seems to me that if this is so, the heritage Act ought to be changed. The FIRB ought to be bound by this.
The reason that I say that this clearly emerges from the decision is evident from the letter that I received from the Secretary of the Department. According to that letter, the Full Court:
. . . ruled that Yates Security Services did not have standing to bring the case-
and this is the important part-

that the Treasurer's approval of the foreign investment purchase of Paddy's Markets was not invalid as the approval of foreign investment in this case was not a matter which required the application of Section 30 of the AHC Act.
The letter also said:
The Commonwealth decision maker must be positively satisfied of the non-existence of `feasible and prudent alternatives' . . .
Yet, here we have a situation where one of the judges said:
I do not think it can be said that the Treasurer's approval of the acquisition of the lease was, of its nature, a granting of a consent to proceed with the development.
In other words, the development could not proceed in respect of these people without the Treasurer's consent but an Australian could have proceeded to pull down Paddy's Market.

This very quaint dividing line means that there is probably a greater prospect of a foreign developer with a lot of financial backing being able to move in and redevelop a site of some heritage significance which an Australian corporation may well not have the resources to do. Here we have a situation where approval is required from the Commonwealth before an Australian heritage item is destroyed. Yet, because the Commonwealth itself is not destroying it, the Commonwealth is not bound by the Heritage Commission Act. If it is not bound, I think it ought to do something about binding itself. The letter goes on:

In short, while the approval of the Treasurer placed Rockvale in a position where it could proceed to obtain all necessary approvals for the development, it did not in itself determine the question of whether the Paddy's site would have development or not; that decision was in the hands of the Darling Harbour Authority, and the development may have proceeded (with another, non-foreign investment developer) even if foreign investment approval had been refused. Hence, the Treasurer's decision did not, in the opinion of the Court, constitute an action which in itself adversely affected the national estate values of Paddy's Market.
It just resulted in the market being pulled down or facaded. Really, I am wondering what the Government's intention is in this matter. As Mr Justice Pincus said in his determination:

. . . (Section 30) is essentially a prescription of administrative procedures to be observed within government and imposes no obligation upon citizens, who might be adversely affected by invalidation.

This raises the next very serious question: to what extent then are government business enterprises which are dealing with the public bound by section 30? In general, to what extent is the Government considering fixing up the heritage Act so that the Government cannot in fact make decisions which facilitate-and this is the key point-the destruction of or damage to Australian heritage?

speech.speaker: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

talk.start.para: â€”I should first acknowledge that there are serious concerns about the implications of this decision. The Government is currently examining what the ramifications of that decision might be. My understanding of it is that because, for example, the Darling Harbour Authority could give permission for the thing to be redeveloped, pulled down or whatever, the relationship between the foreign investment review power and the heritage Act was not germane and therefore did not count. Given the route of Commonwealth intervention into a number of matters, that decision can cause us concern. So we will be having a look at what that decision will mean to us.

speech.para: In regard to Senator Baume's query about who is bound by heritage legislation, all government bodies are bound by it unless they are specifically exempted from its provisions. So there is no doubt about the Commonwealth being bound. The question is: can the Commonwealth get in the door to have its opinion heard on matters which involve foreign investment? That is something that we have to examine.

talk.start.para: â€”I thank the Minister once again. I just remind him that some little while ago I moved an amendment to the heritage Act to ensure that all Commonwealth agencies were bound to the heritage Act. It is quite clear that the Foreign Investment Review Board, in making determinations, is not in fact bound by section 30 of the heritage Act. Otherwise, according to this judgment, it would not have been able to grant approval. Perhaps I should commend to the Minister that he have a look at the amendment that I moved and which he successfully defeated.

speech.speaker: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

talk.start.para: â€”For a number of reasons, I do not think that this is a motion on which Senator Michael Baume can say, `I told you so'. Even if the same opportunity were to arise again, I would reject the same amendment again. It is quite possible that the Government would seek to extend the exemptions to other bodies. In the debate, the basis upon which I put the need for an exemption was to ensure that government business enterprises were not disadvantaged as against their competitors. The specific case which we discussed was Australian Airlines Ltd.
â€”That was one of them.

â€”It is the one that I remember. I do not have a photographic memory of these things over time. I can remember saying that we did not want to disadvantage Australian Airlines against its competitors be they Ansett Australia, Compass Airlines Pty Ltd and any other airline. That principle would still apply. Added to that now, one would imagine that as Telecom Australia gets a competitor, which it does not now have, the Government may well see Telecom being in that same position. As we open up other areas of Government activity to competition, that may happen.

speech.para: As it does, the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories will be concerned to ensure that some type of memorandum of understanding is entered into with whatever bodies we are exempting from the provisions of the legislation. Even if there is an exemption, the government enterprise will still be paying heed to the environment by virtue of the necessity for it to live up to its end of the bargain in signing a memorandum of understanding with the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories.

talk.start.para: â€”I just want to raise a couple of brief points about the environment. In response to questions I was told that 1,393 nominations to be listed on the National estates are still to be considered by the Australian Heritage Commission. At what speed will this backlog be diminished? I know there has been a very significant reduction in the backlog.

â€”I am informed that, even by the end of this financial year, which is only five weeks away, there will only be a couple of hundred left. The number to which Senator Michael Baume has referred will be substantially reduced in that period.

â€”The Shark Bay situation involves cooperation with Western Australia in a proposed agreement with that State and requires the Western Australian Government to pass complementary legislation. In the Senate Estimates hearing we discovered that the funding requested in the Forward Estimates was not likely to be spent because the Western Australian Government had not passed any complementary legislation to establish appropriate management arrangements, and it seemed a long way from doing so. I wonder to what extent has the Western Australian Government's view that there is a distortion of the State Budget involvement been resolved? Will there be agreement within the near future between the Western Australian Labor Government and the Federal Labor Government over this matter which clearly is of considerable significance?

â€”Negotiations continue with the Western Australian Government on this matter. The Western Australian Minister, Mr Pearce, will be here on Friday for further discussions with the Commonwealth. We are hopeful that the matter will be resolved quickly.

speech.speaker: Baume Sen M.E.

talk.start.para: â€”I would now like to deal with some matters affecting sport. I thought that one of my colleagues would be asking questions about the arts in Queensland but apparently he has not made it. I know that Senator Crichton-Browne will be keen to pursue some of these as well.

speech.para: The first matter I want to raise relates to the way in which the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC), by charging fees for the televising of sporting events, is diverting, from many sports, Australian Sports Commission funding. In many instances these charges are imposed because the ABC has a captive market.

To be able to run international events, such as the World Netball Championships or the World Rowing Championships, Australian sporting organisations are required to have television coverage provided. The ABC has taken the view that, in those situations, if it is to provide television coverage it wants the sporting body to provide the cash. As a result of that, quite frankly, the ABC appears to have stood over quite a few sports.

We see a situation where, for the up coming World Netball Championships in Australia, there has been a $200,000 grant from the Government towards those championships, of which 40 per cent, or $80,000, is going to the ABC to help pay the ABC's cost of televising that event. When the World Rowing Championships were held in Tasmania, of the $250,000 Australian Sports Commission grant, $150,000 went to the ABC. For the World Swimming Championships in Perth, a government grant of $500,000 was obtained to help stage that event, of which $150,000 went to the ABC.

I am concerned about that. If the ABC takes the view that it gets no net benefit in terms of viewers, I suppose that is a commercial judgment that it is making. But it intrigues me that the ABC pays multi millions of taxpayers' money to other professional sporting organisations to get the right to televise their sporting events, and bids heavily against commercial channels to cover events such as tonight's venture, in which New South Wales will no doubt beat Queensland. The Minister rolls his eyes and, as he is a good numbers man, that worries me.

talk.start.para: â€”I lost my money last time.

â€”The Minister was not the only person who lost money last time. It is a matter of concern to me that the ABC is paying large amounts of money to professional sports to televise their events, yet charging large amounts of money to amateur sporting organisations to televise those events.

speech.para: Maybe the ABC could be asked to provide us with some sort of cost-benefit analysis as to whether it receives any other benefits. What sorts of ratings does it get for coverage of athletics, rowing and so on? I just do not know. The ABC seems to be taking a pretty tough approach. As a result of this activity, many amateur sports are coming under very heavy financial pressure. Many of them have approached sponsors for funding. I commend them for doing so. Quite frankly, it diminishes the burden on taxpayers to assist sports if individual sporting organisations can get out and get corporate sponsorship. I commend them for doing so.

For example, women's cricket got one of the oil companies to sponsor it. I commend the oil company for doing so. I wish I could remember its name so I could give it a free plug here now. I think it was Shell-yes, a head is nodding. Women's netball obtained support from another oil company, which I think was Mobil. I am at least getting the good oil on this occasion. I commend these bodies for doing so.

But now, these sporting bodies having obtained this sort of sponsorship, the ABC, which is forcing them and press-ganging them into paying for their television coverage, will not allow the sponsors' names to appear on television. A month or so ago the ABC board determined that sponsorships would not be acknowledged on the ABC.

talk.start.para: â€”That is the philosophy of the Managing Director.

â€”I do not know whose particular political philosophy it was. All I know is that in pragmatic terms it is grossly unfair. It is to the disadvantage of Australian sport, and I hope that the ABC will recognise the error of its ways. This was a decision taken on a philosophic basis and not on a practical basis. It reveals an inability to distinguish between sponsorship of a program which the ABC does not want to get involved in-and that is up to the ABC; that is fair enough-and the covering of an event that has been sponsored. The ABC is not being subsidised when it covers an event that is sponsored by a private body. For example, in the case of the Winfield Cup the ABC spends money seeking to televise a sponsored event.

speech.para: Here we have amateur sport suffering as a result of an ideological and nonsensical decision by the ABC. Even though the ABC, of course, must remain independent, I hope that the Government will be taking the view that the consequences of this decision-and, one would hope, the unintended consequences of the decision-can be conveyed to the ABC from within the Government. But in the replies that I have had to questions since the Estimates hearings finished, we find out that the Australian Sports Commission understands that some sporting organisations have lost sponsorships because of the ABC's decision. These organisations will not have the benefit of that support.

As a result, it may well be that the taxpayers of Australia have to pick up the tab to assist some amateur sports because of the way they are being deprived of sponsorship funding. For example, the Australian Rugby Football Union lost an existing major sponsor because of the ABC's recently implemented policy on the naming of sponsors. The Commission has told me it is aware that Athletics Australia was unable to meet the ABC production charges to telecast the 1991 Australian track and field championships held in Sydney in February. In other words, we are having situations where national sporting events which attract the interests of Australian sports people are not being televised because the ABC is making unreasonable demands on the Australian sporting bodies involved.

talk.start.para: â€”How do they calculate the figures?

â€”We have not had the benefit of the ABC's advice as to how it calculates the figures. I hope that as a result of this debate tonight the ABC will advise us on how it comes to this decision to act in such an unfair and improper way with Australian amateur sport. So the Australian track and field championships, very successful championships with some outstanding performers, were not televised because the ABC would not pay up the cash required.

speech.para: The Sports Commission also understands that the Amateur Boxing Union of Australia was considering approaching the ABC to seek televised coverage of certain events but has not proceeded due to the ABC's policy of charging production costs to the sport. In the past-that is, prior to the implementation of the ABC's charging policy-the ABC provided live coverage of Australian track and field championships. The Sports Commission has advised me that track and field events were not covered by the ABC because Athletics Australia determined that it could not afford the ABC production costs. Instead, Athletics Australia decided to direct its sponsorship dollars, which came from the Australian sugar industry-and if the ABC will not acknowledge it, I will-to the conduct of the event and to the athletes. In other words, money that would normally go to the athletes in the conducting of events, facilities and so on is now-in those situations where the events still proceed to be televised-being milked off by the ABC.

I am particularly concerned in those situations where Australian amateur sporting organisations will not be granted the conduct of games or world championships in Australia unless television coverage is there. We are finding that the ABC, the national television network which many of us had thought was outstanding in the field of sports cover, is now looking more to the sports to cover the costs no matter, it appears, what the viewing audience is like. Would it not be ludicrous if the ABC got very high ratings for a program, having forced the sport itself to provide the costs for that program?

talk.start.para: â€”That is one way to get your ratings up.

â€”It might be one way to get one's ratings up but it is also one way for the ABC to embarrass the Government. I believe that is what it is all about. I think the ABC is seeking deliberately to embarrass the Government so as to force higher funding out of the Government. If the ABC wants to play that game that is fine, but I do not want to see it using the sports men and women of Australia as pawns in a financial battle against the Government. That is what it is doing now. I believe it is a disgrace, and I hope that the Government will do something about it.
â€”I am here neither to praise the ABC nor to bury it.
â€”You had better call in Senator Robert Ray.

â€”What would he do, I wonder. I cannot ask the officials on my left much about this question because it mostly revolves around the ABC which is, of course, not in this portfolio-although Senator Baume does raise a number of matters which cross over to both. It is difficult to say that half of or all-or whatever percentage one wishes to nominate-of a grant from the Australian Sports Commission is being allocated to the ABC when it charges for production costs.
â€”It would otherwise be available.

â€”It would otherwise be available, but when the Sports Commission makes a donation to any particular event that goes into the pool of whatever money the sport concerned has raised for the event. Very often the sports earn a considerable amount. Clearly, if any sporting event-national, international or whatever-is going to arouse the interest of a great many Australians, it will not be the case that the ABC has to charge for the production costs. There will be significant competition from the networks to show whatever event it is so that they can make some money out of it. What so often happens is that the job falls onto the ABC of providing coverage of events which have great significance to a particular sport, but perhaps not so much outside of it, and therefore are not big in the ratings game. In those situations, the ABC will always be caught between two stools: between attempting to do better in the ratings and hence justify-in at least the minds of some but not necessarily in mine-the extensive amounts of Government funding that it receives--
