speech.speaker: Panizza Sen J.H.

talk.start.para: â€”This evening I wish to put on record a brief summary of the life and work of Sister Irene McCormack, the Josephite nun who was so brutally and senselessly killed in Peru last week. By this event, the sheep and wheat district of Trayning in the central wheat belt of Western Australia, where Sister Irene was born, has now been linked forever with the seed potato producers of Hausa Huasi in Peru.

speech.para: Sister Irene was born on 28 August 1938 at Kununoppin Hospital, the daughter of Mary O'Meara and Thomas McCormack. I have had the pleasure to know her older brother since school days. I met Sister Irene when she had been a Josephite for quite a long time. She spent her early days and her early education at Trayning, one of the three sister towns of Trayning, Kununoppin and Yelbeni-hence the KTY local number plate.

Her first contact with the Josephite order was at the Trayning convent. The Josephites had, and still have, a scattering of catholic schools around my State of Western Australia. I am proud to say that I started my education in one of those schools. Sister Irene attended Santa Maria College in Perth for two years and then returned to the farm for one year because her mother thought she was too young to enter a convent. It was at this time that she developed her debating skills with the local junior farmer group, where many learnt debating, including at least three that I know of in this place today.

She also developed her golf and tennis skills, enjoyed the weekly country dance, and during that period took a great interest in Australian rules football, becoming a South Fremantle supporter. She entered the Josephites in 1955, being the only young woman from Western Australia to seek admission that year. She was professed on 6 January 1959 after two years as a novitiate at Baulkham Hills in Sydney, and made her final vows in January 1965.

After spending time at south Perth, she then taught in schools in Kalgoorlie, Boulder, Busselton, New Norcia and Mundaring, and completed her teaching career by spending seven years in the tall timber town of Manjimup. It was at this time that she decided to do something for the Third World countries: she spent one year preparing herself with the Columbans in Sydney. The last time I remember seeing Sister Irene was at a junior farmer re- union-the junior farmer group is now somewhat in recession-held in Perth in early 1986, which she attended with her brother Gerald.

I was amazed that, after 30 years in the sisterhood, she was so much the life of the party and had not lost her obvious love of dancing. Her companions in religion farewelled her a few months after that function to the newly founded Josephite Mission in Peru. The rest is now history. Her work and demise in that country have been well documented in other places. It is interesting to note from a report that the people of Hausa Huasi refused to let her body leave the place and wanted her buried there.

Her wishes must have been well known because her funeral was bedecked with red and white streamers and flowers-the colours of her beloved South Fremantle but, at a deeper symbolic level, the colours of innocence and martyrdom. In their sadness, the family could be excused for bitterness, but it is interesting to record a passage from her brother's speech at her memorial service, held in South Perth, when he said, `We'-the family- `do not bear any grudges against the perpetrators'.
I conclude with the words of Sister Maria Casey, RSJ, head of the order in Western Australia, in her communication with me when I asked for Sister Irene's curriculum vitae. She stated:

We would not wish any motion of our Australian Government to cause further distress to a people already oppressed but would hope that the conditions and issues which caused this event would be addressed in some way.
These people are truly Christian. I am sure that all honourable senators will join with me in expressing sorrow to her family and her fellow Josephite sisters.

speech.speaker: Bell Sen R.J.

talk.start.para: â€”Tonight I wish to draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that the National Union of Students has declared tomorrow as a national day of action in support of Austudy reforms. Tertiary students at most campuses in Australia have organised rallies and activities such as forums, soup kitchens, free lunches, marches and letter writing projects in support of the day of action. Also, Federal politicians will be receiving telephone calls and faxes throughout the day.

speech.para: The National Union of Students represents over 300,000 students. Tomorrow's protest is part of a major campaign leading up to this year's Federal Budget. The purpose of this action is to highlight student poverty because of major inequities in the current Austudy scheme. The theme of the national campaign is, very aptly, `You can't feed a dog on Austudy'.

Too many students are excluded unfairly from receiving any Austudy benefits at all because of this scheme's draconian regulations. Students who do receive Austudy are struggling to survive on the allowances which they receive because those allowances are well below the poverty line. At the moment, only 42 per cent of tertiary students receive Austudy. Of those, less than half-in fact, 46.5 per cent-receive the full amount.

The Government has called Austudy a targeting of those who most deserve to receive Austudy. I suggest that this targeting is quite apt. In fact, it does not miss at all. It hits square on and sends those who are hit straight into poverty. When one has been declared eligible for Austudy and is able to receive it, it really should not be a reason for celebration. The very definition of being eligible for Austudy almost defines a young person as being poor and having very few options available.

A recent survey of students at the Adelaide University showed that most students in receipt of Austudy are living in poverty. About 80 per cent had an income below $10,000 per year, and 23 per cent received only $4,000 per year. The Price report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training suggested that about $12,000 was needed just to cover a student's living costs. In real terms, many students are flat broke; they are starving and increasingly in debt. Some students have been forced to drop out of their studies and others, who are desperate to keep studying, have resorted to crime in its various forms, including prostitution, as reported in several of the daily metropolitan newspapers.

If students manage to find legitimate part time work, they can only earn about one-third of the average income. The Price report, to which I referred earlier, found that, when normal tax is taken into account, students who earn over the current Austudy limit of $4,000 are taxed effectively at the incredible rate of 75 per cent. A story in the Australian on 22 May 1991 was headed `Austudy and Starve or Drop out on the Dole'. That headline is no exaggeration whatsoever. It really is absurd that students who are ineligible for Austudy, and even those who receive it, are better off financially if they drop out and join the dole queues.

The article in the Australian cites one case where an Adelaide university student received a matriculation score of 450 and is studying to achieve her ambition to become a lawyer. However, because of the difficulties of living on Austudy-she receives $115 a week-she is thinking of dropping out. The student, 18-year-old Samantha Maiden, is quoted as saying that having no money all the time means `you lose your incentive to sit down and study because your life is so full of other problems'. This is a young person who has that score and should be studying for law. She says:
It sounds melodramatic, but sometimes you really have to ask yourself, `Do I go and buy this book or do I go and buy some food?' You can't be expected to study when you are totally strung out.

The coalition and the Government recently rejected moves by the Australian Democrats to achieve some urgently needed reforms to Austudy. These included a reduction in the age of independence from 25 to 18 years; a return to the pre-Budget threshold for spouse income, which should be indexed to $19,300, instead of the post-Budget figure of $12,150; and an increase in the personal income threshold.

The demands of the National Union of Students reflect the same concerns and we hope that the Government will take the necessary action to improve the prospects of students who are truly suffering. For tomorrow, the Australian Democrats support the students in their actions and wish them well.

speech.speaker: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

talk.start.para: â€”The tragedy involving a Lauda Air aircraft in Thailand on Monday and three Australians-and I extend our sympathy to the families of those people-highlights all too clearly the changed circumstances in which we all live and the risks that we all take in travelling. All too often we think that those sorts of incidents are foreign to Australia; that such a thing could never happen. We might once have thought we were immune to the violence that so often is part and parcel of life in other countries, but in recent years a number of incidents have caused us to realise that it could happen here.

speech.para: Against that background, we must also realise that our major airport, Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport-handling 200,000 aircraft movements a year, 13 million passengers and 160,000 tonnes of freight-is sadly and dangerously overtaxed. That situation, we are told constantly, is not likely to improve and, indeed, by the year 2005 global air traffic will double and by the year 2010 it will treble. We cannot afford to be lax about the safety of aircraft and the safety of passengers either in the air or on the ground. If we keep delaying making a decision about a third runway and a second airport, that is what we will be doing.

If we continue to pour people in aircraft onto overcrowded runways and if we continue to pour people into inadequate terminals, we will increase the chances of security becoming lax and accidents in the air. We cannot afford to be complacent-not about security, not about safety-and the recent tragedy in Thailand ought to remind us that Australia is a popular tourist destination, just as Thailand is, and the apparent sabotage in Thailand could conceivably occur again. Let us hope that Australia's airport security continues to remain at its present high standard. We can only ensure that will be the case if we continue to develop our airport systems and keep Australian aviation at the forefront of safety.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 7.44 p.m.

question.speaker: Coulter Sen J.R.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 19 April 1991:

question.para: (1) On what evidence did the Minister's letter to the Uranium Policy Review Committee of the Australian Labor Party, earlier this year, conclude that `the evidence points to a significant upturn in the world uranium market from about the middle of the 1990s'.
(2) Is the Minister aware that the 1989-90 OECD `Red Book' predicted that uranium supply will be 49 000 MtU in 1995, and demand only 47 000 MtU, giving an excess of supply over demand of 2000 MtU.
(3) What is the explanation of the discrepancy between the OECD's estimates cited in (2) and the Minister's conclusion cited in (1).

answer.speaker: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

talk.start.para: â€”The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) There are two principal factors which point to a significant upturn in the world uranium market from about the middle of the 1990s. One is the increasing gap between production and estimated demand, which will require additional sources of supply in that period. The other is the large volume of demand for which no contracts have yet been negotiated, which will provide competitive suppliers with further market opportunities.
Supply and Demand

Nuclear generating capacity will increase between now and the year 2000. Outside the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe, nuclear generating capacity is currently about 280 GWe. Forecasts for 2000 range from Greenpeace's estimate of 310 GWe to industry estimates, based on utility plans, of between 323 GWe and 330 GWe. Estimates made by my department suggest that 320 GWe is a realistic expectation.

These figures translate into estimates of uranium demand. Uranium demand is currently estimated to be about 46,000 tonnes U. For the year 2000, assuming a generating capacity of 320 GWe, such an estimate, taking technical factors into consideration in a commercially realistic way, would be 51,000-54,000 tonnes U.

On the supply side, the uranium market is currently undergoing substantial adjustment. In every year since 1985, uranium production has been less than reactor related requirements. For 1989, production was 34,000 tonnes U. For 1990, preliminary estimates are that production was below 30,000 tonnes U. The gap between production and requirements is being met from stocks, which, it would seem, are being drawn down at a faster rate than previously envisaged, and, to a lesser extent, from new sources of supply, such as the Soviet Union. At the current rate at which inventories are being drawn down, they are expected to reach levels, at which utilities would wish to maintain them, within a few years. Soviet penetration of the market, although likely to be significant, will be restrained by both Soviet market strategies and customer perceptions about long-term reliability.

Although it is always difficult to pinpoint when a market will return to equilibrium, the above factors point to the need for a substantial increase in future production, as inventories are drawn down and the existing gap between production and demand widens. This requirement for additional production is expected to occur in the mid 1990s.
Uncommitted Demand

The amount of demand not yet under supply contracts-uncommitted demand-constitutes a substantial proportion of the total demand estimate. For 1995, it is about 18,000 tonnes U and, for 2000, about 38,000 tonnes U. The cumulative amount of uncommitted demand over the period 1995-2000 is estimated to be about 160,000 tonnes U.

Given the degree of market adjustment referred to above, which has involved the closure of many high cost production centres, the amount of uncommitted demand further illustrates the extent of market opportunities for competitive suppliers, such as Australia.
(2) Neither the 1989 OECD Red Book nor its 1990 Statistical Update predicts that uranium supply will be 49,000 tonnes U in 1995.

The Red Book assesses production capabilities and, for 1995, estimates that production capability, including from prospective mine centres, will be about 49,000 tonnes U. The Red Book is explicit in drawing a distinction between production capability and actual production. It points out that actual production is expected to remain below reactor requirements until desired levels of stocks are reached.

For 1990, the Red Book estimated that annual production capability could range from 43,000 to 50,000 tonnes U. As noted above, preliminary estimates are that actual production in 1990 was less than 30,000 tonnes U. Differences of this magnitude underline the fact that production capability is not equivalent to, or even a rough measure of, actual production.
(3) See (1) and (2) above.

question.speaker: Jones Sen G.N.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 22 April 1991:

question.para: (1) What is the price received for Australian crude oil.
(2) What role does OPEC play in regard to the pricing of crude oil.
(3) What price do oil producing countries presently receive for crude oil on the world market.
(4) Is this the price that Australian producers receive for crude oil; if so, why have petrol prices in Australia risen approximately five cents per litre.

answer.speaker: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

talk.start.para: â€”The Minister for Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) On 1 January 1988 the Australian crude oil market was deregulated and since then the Government has had no involvement in the negotiation process for the sale of oil. Consequently, the price which Australian companies receive for the crude oil that they sell to Australian firms or export to overseas markets is determined solely by commercial negotiation between the parties to the transaction.

(2) OPEC is a cartel of oil producing nations, which accounts for about 37 per cent of the world's oil production. The degree of control over the international price of crude oil exercised by OPEC members depends largely upon the discipline of OPEC members in producing within the quotas agreed. In the past their ability to do so has varied widely. On 11-12 March 1991 OPEC members agreed to an informal package of production cuts aimed at achieving the OPEC reference price of $US21 a barrel.

(3) The price which oil producing countries receive for their oil is determined by commercial negotiation with purchasing firms and organisations. The price received is influenced by a range of factors including: the balance between supply and demand; the type of oil being sold, ie whether it is a light or a heavy crude; whether the oil is being sold under a long or short term contract; and the timing of sales, ie whether the oil is being sold on the spot market or sold for future delivery. At present the prices of the international marker crudes Oman, West Texas Intermediate and Brent are around $US20-21 a barrel.

(4) The price that Australian producers receive for crude oil is also determined by commercial negotiation and reflects international prices. Wholesale petrol prices peaked around October last year and have since declined significantly. In fact, the Prices Surveillance Authority (PSA) announced on 10 April 1991 that maximum wholesale prices, excluding recent excise and State franchise fee increases, had fallen below the level prevailing at the time of the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. In general, retail prices have followed the downward trend in wholesale prices of petrol as determined by the PSA. Retail prices will also fluctuate with discounting and competition in the market. The PSA reported on 3 May that retail prices in most capital cities have recently dipped below 60 cents per litre for the first time since hostilities broke out in the Gulf in August 1990.

question.speaker: Macdonald Sen I.D.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 22 April 1991:

question.para: (1) In answer to a question without notice (Senate Hansard, 22 January 1991, p. 141) it was indicated that 23 expressions of interest from various companies had been lodged with the Space Office in relation to the Cape York Space Port development;
(2) Which 23 companies lodged expressions of interest;
(3) Has an assessment of those expressions of interest yet been made; if so what is the outcome;
(4) How is it proposed to choose an ``adequate protagonist'';
(5) What is the likely timetable to choose a protagonist for the project?

answer.speaker: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

talk.start.para: â€”The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (2) The 23 companies which registered interest with the Space Office did so on a commercially confidential basis. It would therefore be inappropriate to release their names without their consent. It should be noted however that it is open to any of these 23 companies to approach any of the other companies which have made public their interest and intentions regarding the development of a spaceport.
(3) No. AIDC Ltd has held preliminary discussions with the majority of registrants in order to establish the level of their interest.

(4) The spaceport project remains a commercial activity which will be required to proceed without Government investment or subsidy. However, it will be necessary for the Government to put in place the necessary legislation and to provide active assistance in relation to such matters as appropriate international government-to-government agreements.

As noted in my Press Release of 19 February, the purpose of the AIDC Ltd activity is to determine if there is a single substantial proponent with access to the financial, technical and management resources which will be necessary to complete the next phase of the spaceport's development and with whom the Government can proceed with confidence.

It is therefore, not really a matter of choosing a proponent; rather it is a matter of vetting and accepting proof of the credentials of those who wish to be the proponent. The final composition of any spaceport consortium will remain a matter for resolution within the commercial marketplace.

(5) The first part of AIDC Ltd's task is to review and confirm the commercial viability of the project. This is due to be completed by the end of May or in early June. They will then prepare an investment package and conduct negotiations with commercial/industrial interests to establish a proponent. This may take until about mid-October 1991.

question.speaker: Coulter Sen J.R.
